author: {'steamid': '76561198027782034', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1697917602}
review: Lily: Child of Geos is a cute, casual puzzle game with an interesting cast of characters. It isn't the most sophisticated game you'll play, owing to it's history as a mobile title. The transition to PC is not without it's flaws, but the game play is fun, the island of Geos is beautiful, and the whole experience is a solid 3-6 hours that you're unlikely to regret.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113348958', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1695619920}
review:
While not the most impressive game, Lili does hold a unique level of charm with the world and designs. For a short experience, you get quite the robust amount of interactions: opting to flower pick the Spirits or help the local Constructs to push the plot along. Upgrade tree is nice, though I felt that opting for one stat and maxing it made the most sense instead of a well-rounded spread. Grab stat is insanely powerful at ALL times, while speed isn't that much of a deal due to the lag of Spirits running away, as well as the abundant use of speed-boosting sandwiches. Still, very fun.

Of the few gripes I have, it took a while to get used to the controls, as left and right are STRAFES and not 'go in this direction', opting for using the stick to steer her around. If you go in a house and there's a guard spirit nearby, if you're not careful it will keep knocking you back INTO the house. I needed to use an invisibility potion, otherwise I might've been softlocked. Speaking of quitting/reloading, there were two instances where I got trapped - once on a wall corner, and another on an NPC - where I just COULD NOT move. Thankfully, small bumps like these do not remove the fun I had with this game and clearing it off my list of 'to beat'.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014763908', 'num_games_owned': 2519, 'num_reviews': 331, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1684634124}
review:
A very simple mobile-port.

From the perspective that this game is for young children: It's decent enough, I doubt a young child would complain much and I bet it would entertain them for a short while. Characters talk in a childish and cute and funny way, the animations are in a cute, cartoonish way.

The game is not voice acted which is a bummer.

Keep in mind you have to use keyboard and mouse as controller is buggy and not fully supported. Perhaps you can get it to work fully by using Steam Big Picture and creating your own config if possible, I did not try.

From any other perspective it's pretty bad.
The options menu is very bad and there's a bug with resolutions, for me it got fixed by playing in Fullscreen Window but this has not worked for many others. There are some solutions in the Discussions forum that might help you.

The main and only mechanic used throughout the entire game is that you jump on the back of enemies and do a very easy QTE to pick flowers from their backs. This becomes incredibly repetitive and boring.
It is incredibly shallow from start to finish. It might work as a toilet break-game on a phone, but not as a PC game.

For 2 hours of gameplay from a mobile-port it is priced too high

Controller is not supported beyond basic functionality of you being able to navigate the basic menus and move around and do QTE's.

Everything shows up as keyboard characters(like Press M to look at your map, for example) except for in the QTE's thankfully, there is no controller button map in the game, it just gives you a keyboard button map(no way to re-bind) and it's not possible to navigate to certain menus with a controller like the Journal and your sidebar hot keys(you get some items on a side bar).

The other game on Steam from this developer is an Early Access abandonware title from 2015.

Not recommended, there are plenty of other games within this same vein that are much better.

review: I got this game for 0.99 a while ago, and you know what? For that price, I'd say it's fantastic. For $15, well... I'd wait until a sale. The game had a lot of charm to it, and I really may come back to it to 100% it, if it's not too tedious. Really liked the world building, I even became attached to a few characters. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197993784884', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1639312749}
review:
"Lili: Child of Geos" is quite harmless and innocent, the graphics are pleasant and downright enchanting up to this day, and its overall ambiance is rather wholesome and heartwarming. It manages to be endearing and full of charm. It also is on the short side, has a very repetitive gameplay loop, and is wearing its unfortunate mobile origins on its sleeve (the camera and controls are not the best).

This said, I would indeed recommend it, but only for children under and around the age of 10, as I think this demographic would like it best and would also be more willing to forgive its shortcomings and to appreciate and enjoy what Lili has to offer. And [b]not[/b] at full price (which is currently 15‚Ç¨). You should make a good use of the 2 hours refund window with this one, what you'll be seeing upfront is what you'll be getting throughout the game, for the better and for the worse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147861397', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 575, 'last_played': 1654388028}
review:
A bit late, but if there's anyone who sees this game beyond the year or two of this game's release, you must know this is a graphical upgrade of a mobile game. That means that the gameplay and UI has [b]not[/b] been altered for PC.

If you're looking for a game that's very simple and is practically a walking sim, then you might enjoy it? The main "gameplay" is plucking flowers off of a moving character. Over and over. It's very early mobile game design.

Visually, it's quite nice! Speaks for itself‚Äî however, on every setting other than Low, the bloom and camera effects partially ruin the art. Scroll through the screenshots and look for the eternal sun glare. There's practically no options or customization of anything. 

Animations are poor, with everything feeling a bit aged and definitely mobile inspired.

I'd generally not recommend this game for most people, even more so now that the company BitMonster no longer seem to exist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029508562', 'num_games_owned': 2558, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1652332650}
review:
Charming and childishly funny. 

Combat is a quick time events minigame, and aside from that Lili: Child of Geos is almost a walking simulator with collectibles. Short and repetitive.

Not a strong recommendation, make sure you're in the right mood and you can enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073521849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1647657692}
review: This game was sitting in my library for years, so I finally decided to play it. It's pretty short, I played on easy and finished it in just under 3 hours. You pick flowers off of these wooden robot thingies in a quick-time mini game. That's most of the gameplay here, and it's just... fine. The characters you meet are somewhat interesting, I was a bit surprised when one told me they would bring about the end times. But otherwise pretty relaxing vibes here. Give it a go if it's sitting in your library collecting virtual dust.

author: {'steamid': '76561198339529905', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1651460523}
review:
I do recommend this game, but I strongly recommend purchasing it on sale if you want your money's worth. I did everything available to do in the game, got every outfit and accessory, and got all of the achievements (which requires 1.5 playthroughs in order to get all the skill stats) and didn't even log a total of 6 hours. 

That being said, Lili is visually exceptional. It's a whimsical game with incredible scenery that reminds me a bit of a blend of Studio Ghibli and Legend of Zelda vibes. I would never have assumed this game could be considered a mobile game. It's a lovely casual play game for a calm and relaxing break.

However, there are quite a few bugs with achievements (I got my 1000 flowers achievement when I had only picked 780ish, for some reason the 1000 vases achievement triggered the unlock of the flower achievement as well. The bird achievement also got stuck on my first playthrough at 179 and would not progress no matter what. Luckily I got it my second time around, however the tracker for it still wasn't functional, it just popped randomly.) There is also, in my opinion, great room for improvement in terms of where the plot could have gone. I would have loved to have more side quests, more dialogue, more information in general as to the background of Lili, Geos, the spirits, and the constructs. Much of it is just expected to be taken at face value, but I would have liked to know and understand more about the world I was exploring. Also, the ending in my opinion was very anti-climactic. The 'battle' with the mayor was much too simplistic and just sailing off into the sea with no epilogue or anything was a bummer. I'd have liked to get an idea of what the constructs decide to do with Geos, what becomes of the spirits (since we see one still there), and what happens to Lili. It also would have been neat to see Lili utilize the flowers she collects as more than just coin fodder. If she was going for a degree in botanical magic I feel like we could have used the flowers to craft our own items, maybe for side quests or even just potions for our own uses. 

I think this game is a lovely experience for a casual game, and I think a younger crowd would especially love it (granted there are a few mild adult jokes like a 'deflowering' joke but easily acceptable for a young teen or preteen to play) so I definitely recommend it, just expect this to be more of a brief atmospheric experience than a true story driven RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981638563', 'num_games_owned': 4007, 'num_reviews': 517, 'playtime_forever': 2052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1172, 'last_played': 1645493791}
review:
[h1]‚ÄúOne day, you will be old enough to start reading fairytales again.‚Äù
~[i]C.S. Lewis, The Chronicles of Narnia[/i][/h1]

Ah, the casual games... Say whatever you want, I always had a very special place in my heart for those. From [b]Br√∏derbund Software[/b]'s [b]Arthur[/b] games to [b]SiMS[/b] and [b]Animal Crossing[/b]. I just love all that. Even though such games aim mostly to people who don't usually play games with complicated mechanics and tons of challenge, I just... I dunno, [i]I need[/i] them in my life. With all that bull that happens in the world around us, it's great to have something cute to relax. Something with no challenge at all, something to make you feel like a little kid again. That's why I loved [b]Nintendo[/b]'s [b]Wii[/b] and [b]DS[/b] so much. Those were like paradise for people who enjoyed such stuff. Unfortunately, nowadays it's hard to find a good casual game. Just because modern market treat casual players as fools and is trying to milk the heck out of them. And it works. Unfortunately. I mean, just look at what's going on. Nowadays, ‚Äúcasual game‚Äù usually means ‚Äú[b]f2p[/b] disaster‚Äù and even [b]Nintendo[/b]'s platform, which was meant to be a home of family-friendly entertainment, can't offer anything special. And that's exactly why I'm always glad to find something like this game here.

It's not like [b]Lili: Child of Geos[/b] is something special. It originated on [b]iPhone[/b] (was called simply ‚Äú[b]Lili[/b]‚Äù back then), it has only four maps / locations, it can be finished without much troubles in only a couple of hours and so on. So... what's with the thumb up? Well, first of all, this game looks surprisingly good. [b]PC[/b] version has a nasty resolution glitch, which can prevent you from changing the resolution through options menu and this game also hates [b]AMD[/b] video cards, but honestly, for [b]2012[/b] game from [b]iPhone[/b], it looks absolutely beautiful. Even today, it's a very charming experience. Especially since it's also very colorful and comes with surprisingly great character design. No, seriously, I didn't expect such a nice job. I mean, you know how it is. When it's about casual games, especially those for mobiles, we rarely get proper design. Most of the time, it's either copy / pasted design from popular [b]AAA[/b] games or some [b]Adobe Flash[/b]-like nonsense. While here? Here, it's something that makes you think of [b]Henry Selick[/b]'s [b]Coraline[/b]. Like I said, very impressive.

The best thing about this game, though, is that it's a casual game done right. If you have little kids? Those won't have any problems playing it. It's a very easy game (especially on low difficulty settings), and yet, it has pretty much everything to be called a real deal. You'll explore, you'll trade, you'll level up and you'll fight enemies. All easy for kids to understand. Talking about enemies, by the way. Another thing about [b]Lili: Child of Geos[/b] is that it's a very peaceful game. No violence here. Like... at all. And even though technically, you'll fight enemies, you'll do that by picking the flowers from their heads. Long story short ‚Äì you catch the evil spirit (in order to make the process a little bit easier, you'll need to level up speed and stealth, which will make you run faster and harder for spirits to notice), you jump on its back and you pick up flowers by participating in [b]QTE[/b]. You know the drill. Just press the right buttons to pick up corresponding flowers as fast as possible (third, and final, stat called ‚Äúgrip‚Äù will help you stay on enemy's back longer), and avoid spikes. On [b]iPhone[/b] and [b]iPad[/b] we were supposed to use touchscreen, which used to make things to feel more realistic (hello, [b]Nintendo DS[/b], miss you a lot, old buddy!), and yet, [b]Quick Time Events[/b] work pretty well too and are actually more comfortable. What's fun about battles in this game is that... theys surprisingly addicting. You know? I already said that this game is very kids-friendly, but even as an adult, it's hard not to feel addicted. That's exactly why this game will let you continue playing even after you'll be done with the main thing. Hunting down evil spirits? It's just way too addicting.

You can also make money by picking up flowers around you. Which is not nearly as fun as fighting spirits, but first ‚Äì you'll make enough money from spirits anyway, and second ‚Äì it's a very cute addition, which aims mostly to add the atmosphere and prevent you from feeling bored when you'll run from [b]A[/b] to [b]B[/b]. There's a story too, of course. Way too generic, but still, it's there and, aside from the main storyline, there'll also be optional objectives. You'll need to take pictures in certain spots, you'll need to plant trees and so on. Very cute and heartwarming stuff, which the entire family will be able to enjoy. Talking about families, while kids will totally enjoy bright colors, cute characters and heartwarming gameplay, parents would enjoy the nods to the old video games. [b]Zero Wing[/b], [b]The Oregon Trail[/b], [b]Super Mario Bros.[/b], etc. All of those got funny nods here. Heck, we'll even get ourselves [b]Link[/b]'s hat and [b]Navi[/b] ‚Äúpet‚Äù from [b]The Legend of Zelda[/b] series! How cool is that?! Sure, it's nothing special, but... you know. Fun stuff.

Talking 'bout hats and pets, by the way. [b]Lili: Child of Geos[/b] is one of those games that makes you want to get [b]100%[/b] completion. There isn't [i]that[/i] much stuff in here, and yet, collecting money to unlock new clothes (hello, [b]Barbie[/b] games!) and new hats? It's just... very addicting... somehow. There'll be important stuff too. Which means that not all purchases will be about cosmetics. But that's actually a bad thing. How? Well, see, one of the worst things about this game is its balance. Or lack of it. See, in [b]Lili: Child of Geos[/b] you can just grind for win. Collect enough money and you'll get yourself a key that will unlock all the doors that lead to treasures. All the doors in the entire game. Also, while you won't be able to level up right away, grinding for potions will compensate for lack of stats, so... yeah. Like I said, grinding is the answer to everything here. And it sucks. It's not like it ruins the entire thing, though. I mean, [b]Lili: Child of Geos[/b] is far from being a hardcore experience. And I don't... think that complaining too much about balance in kids-friendly game that can be finished in only two hours is a good idea. I mean, when you play [b]Corel Wild Board Games[/b], you don't complain about [b]AI[/b] not being as good as in [b]Fritz Chess[/b]. It's a different kind of fun with different purposes. It's all about cute characters, charming animations and heartwarming atmosphere. So, honestly, who cares? The game does its job.

And when it's about doing its job? [b]Lili: Child of Geos[/b] is absolutely brilliant. You run around, you collect flowers, you help funny-looking citizens of [b]Geos[/b] and you fight enemies in a very cute non-violence way. Bright colors, nice graphics and cute character design included. As a person who played a lot of such games (like, [i]a lot[/i] of them), I must say, I'm impressed. In other words, don't expect anything big and complicated here, but if you're looking for a family-friendly game like [b]The Dog Island[/b], [b]Falling Stars[/b] and [b]The Island of Dr. Frankenstein[/b]? That's it. This right here is exactly what you're looking for. A nicely made cute and charming game with easy gameplay and heartwarming aftertaste. Something you play with kids, or when you need a simple game to feel better during the cold winter nights. Just make sure to get some hot chocolate and you're ready to go. Dixi.

review:
A delightful, charming, and light-hearted game, full of quirky characters and gentle nonsense.  I played this game a few years ago, and it maintains a special place in my heart.  Not overly complicated, and the story isn‚Äôt terribly deep, but it‚Äôs sweet and enjoyable and refreshingly non-violent.  As long as you don‚Äôt have unrealistic expectations about this game, it is a genuine delight.  

It‚Äôs also nice to see a female character who isn‚Äôt pink, scantily clad, covered in makeup, or reduced to a romantic interest for some male lead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028846059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1635539596}
review:
This game is so basic that while it's vaguely entertaining for twenty minutes it gets old very fast. the visuals are cute but many little things are clunky. Whenever you talk to  character the camera swings wildly after, which really throws me off. The character models re very same same since they're all wooden creatures. The primary game loop is so repetitive and easy that it becomes pointless trying. You can also buy a skeleton key to open all doors whenever you make 6000 gold (not hard). Just seems like such a waste and I wish I could refund it. Would probably be a good game for children but there's no voice acting and the plot doesn't direct you very well if you're too young to know a lot about game design. 
Further to this, the main character has zero personality  or really backstory. It's such a meh game if you're not 6.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985939935', 'num_games_owned': 4189, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1630859707}
review:
M√∂chte vielleicht ein RPG sein, schafft das aber nicht wirklich.

Pros:
- Die Grafik ist ziemlich h√ºbsch geraten. 
- Die Welt ist an sich ganz nett konstruiert - aber eher f√ºr eine junge Spielerschaft (< 12 Jahre vielleicht)

Cons:
- Spielt sich eher z√§h und wirkt was die Steuerung angeht etwas unpolished. 
- Auch wenn man viele Charaktere zum ansprechen hat - nur wenige haben etwas interessantes zu sagen. 
- Dialoge sind nicht vertont. Klar - Sprachaufnahmen sind teuer, aber sie h√§tten das Spiel vermutlich bereichert.
- Das Gameplay beschr√§nkt sich auf Rumlaufen, das Pfl√ºcken von Blumen und K√§mpfe in Form von Quick Time Events.

Misc:

author: {'steamid': '76561197992694498', 'num_games_owned': 2769, 'num_reviews': 450, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1407407300}
review:
[h1]Pretty good for a mobile game[/h1]

Lili child of Geos is a very simplistic yet beautiful game which could be relaxing.

It's a third person game where you play as a girl in an open world environment while doing various tasks. It's isn't hard, more on a relaxing side. The store page says it's similar to Zelda, tagged as rpg but I don't think it qualifies as anything like that.

You basically have a map of a city and just run around doing quests which by the way lack variety and imagination in general. The game is very repetitive although it's very short. But when a short game feels like a 50 hours one that means the tasks are boring.

Nevertheless the game is pretty fun if you don't expect much from it.
The level design is pretty good and running around in that beautiful world is fun. It's a chill game with no pressure or hard tasks.

There are some challenges for the achievements which might be little annoying due to being repetitive and janky controls. But nothing too bad, i've seen much worse. You will need to run a lot, to same places, get the collectables and other items.
I think this game is perfectly suitable for children. It's colorful and cheerful.

It was a mobile game and it's pretty old game by now but it looks pretty good and I can't say anything bad when comes to graphics. Not a blockbuster level of quality obviously but it's cute and charming including the main character, side characters and all the areas are really cute and creates a charming atmosphere.

Animations are better than many games which came out recently and I was really surprised about that. Great job devs.

When it comes to sound it's decent. Music is fine and fits the mood of the game well but there are no voice-overs.


It's a decent game if you want something cheerful and relaxing. It's pretty short and lacks variety in tasks but it's definitely worth picking up on sale.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Relaxing
[*]Cute
[*]Pretty graphics
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Repetitive
[*]Janky movement
[*]Lack of activities
[/list]

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32930811-Kosmos%27s-Cosmic-reviews/?appid=704030][h1]Follow my curator page for more[/h1][/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198050929976', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1618806906}
review:
Adorable little simple game, no real "combat" given the only "action" is centered around pulling flowers off of weird pinata looking demons, the focus of the game is exploration and collecting items and cosmetics. Its very rough around the edges and budget-y but very charming and a nice little 6 hour game. 

As of 2021, i can't recommend purchasing it given the dev company basically doesn't exist anymore. I recieved this game as a gift in 2016 and only got around to finishing it recently when i found out about the physical ultra limited editions that got released lol. Happy to say i OWN them now but i really feel bad that this game got abandoned so fast, no modding updates, no patches, its just dead, like many indie titles on steam. Bit sad innit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025518269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1682173203}
review:
I enjoyed this game, but I'm giving it a thumbs down because I can't stand developers that can't take a moment to add Steam Cloud support so I don't lose my progress. If that doesn't bother you, read the review below.

This game has fantastic art direction and looks incredible for an UE3 game. I experienced no issues and ran the game free of technical issues. The KB/M controls seemed good, but I used a controller. You can't remap keys. The game doesn't support 21:9. It supports 4K, and some tinkering will let the game run over 60fps.

The game is fairly simplistic and only moderately challenging even on the hardest difficulty, and felt like the developers were aiming to attract children as their primary whales. This was an iOS game that was ported to PC and PS4. You can tell by the structure of the game it was designed with micro-transactions in mind and to be played in small repeated bursts. And yet I played it for 6 hours and had fun exploring and playing.

It's charming, relaxing, and something to chill out to for a few hours. It's heavy on repetition so be warned you'll be breaking thousands of pots and scaring hundreds of birds. I didn't do all these objectives, but completed most of the game. The adventure elements are rather light, and while it has some Zelda homages, this is not anything close to a Zelda game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162718177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1610480543}
review: I bough this game in probably 2016, and played it for a solid 30 minutes before quitting becaue my graphics card wasn't running it well. I just restarted it with a new perspective (and new graphics card) and I don't have a negative thing to say about it. It's a beautiful game, and something (mostly) relaxing to play. The most non-relaxing part of the game is litearlly just pulling flowers off a creature while timed. And even then, it's a beautiful game. It's adorable, fun for all ages, and just a good chill game. It rewards you for talking to everyone, and has SEVERAL pop culture/gaming references. 10/10 would highly recommend.

review: Lovely cartoony, bright and colourful graphics, a fun little story and lots of bashing things for coins. Lili is exploring the island of Geos and ends up helping the underdogs, the 'constructs' that live and work there as slaves. This is a short but fun little game suitable for all ages and abilities. I enjoyed collecting the flowers and chests and bashing the pots for coins to unlock better skills and new outfits. The characters are really funny at times and you will definitely have a smile on your face at some of the funny characters and dialogue. This game is well worth the small price that is being charged. No bugs or crashes and a very pleasing experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999282226', 'num_games_owned': 972, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1593559689}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is a mobile game ported to PC, with little changed from that. The game can be summarized very easily, so I'm just going to do a Bullet Point review for this one.

-Story revolves around Lili, a student from a magical academy, who comes to the island of Geos to pick flowers. She gets involved in the local conflict between wood constructs, and plant Spirits. As it goes along you learn more about her past.
-Gameplay revolves around speaking to people for sidequests, and performing QTE minigames to pluck flowers from spirits. The entire game is essentially these QTE events, which are picking flowers and avoiding bombs.
-Spirits are rated on score, so there is a score chase element.
-Story is very simplistic, game is only a few hours long. Can get repetitive since once you've seen how one spirit works, you've basically seen them all - there's just more bombs, or more thorns.
-There is no traditional combat, and no puzzles (beyond "How do I get in this room" or "Where is this NPC")
-Some unlockables, some new abilities to buy, mostly improvement of basic stats, like movespeed and grip strength. Strongly recommend maxing movespeed as soon as possible. There are some costumes as well.
-Other very minor minigames, like a shellgame, exist, but for the most part it's dialogue and QTE events. There are collectibles to find around the world as well.
-Several achievements would need a NG+ to do in any reasonable fashion.

Cute little game that I got on super sale. Not sure I'd recommend it to a lot of people? But it's you're looking for something small, bright, cute, or potentially child friendly, you'll find that here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055949901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1708064360}
review:
On a whim I bought this game in 2017 after it was recommended to me by a friend - the graphics were enticing and it wasn't too expensive. 

However, my first experience with the game lasted <15 minutes. Had Steam had a return policy at the time, I would have returned it immediately . I even began questioning my friend's character and taste in games. This game was nothing like I typically played. The combat system involved plucking flowers off creatures that looked like they were covered in wall siding, and the challenge level was close to 0. 

BUT---in the middle of 2018, I was having a rough time with my career and personal life. My typical go to games weren't cutting it. I wanted to be distracted, but I didn't want to play anything too challenging or dreary. I decided to give this game a chance, and boy, am I glad I did.

This game brought a serenity I hadn't felt in a long time. It was simple, wasn't high stakes, and didn't make me feel worse after playing it.

If I would describe this game in one word it would be "pleasant". You can't stay sad and play this game - you have to pick one. 

Is it for everyone? Nope. But if you like simple and cute games that don't require a lot of mental effort, this is a good one. 
It is short, I probably completed it in 3.5 hours - and the achievements are mostly collecting flowers or breaking pots which can get a bit repetitive. 

Even now in 2020, if I ever think of games that are just "pleasant" my mind first goes to this game.  
But I do sometimes wonder what kind of futuristic society this world takes place in. Is it post-apocalyptic? Man vs machine? How did the automatons get on the island? Who knows. I suppose it doesn't matter. Just enjoy the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077720967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 153, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1588131394}

author: {'steamid': '76561198137728235', 'num_games_owned': 2231, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1612901953}
review:
It's... Cute.

I couldn't justify running this on a tank so I ended up never playing it. Recently bought a lackluster laptop that could run it okay and finally played it. Because I had it forever and I probably got it in a bundle or something.

The game is downright beautiful. The lights and particles along with the shiny textures scream tropical. The colors are flush and pop in a very delightful way, and everything is just polished and looks very good.

Gameplay is simple, make money, take out baddies, gather rare flowers, solve quests to get more flowers. It's fun, however, the game is well over before you really can get irritated by the way some of it is structured. So short in fact, that trying to explain specific situations in which the game acts up, or is just unfortunate mechanically, will feel like I am spoiling the game. 

The game is worth a look... But I'm really no sure about how much you should pay to get it. My game time says 8 or so hours, but that time was filled with arbitrary things like kicking jars, scaring birds, picking flowers, and starting over to max out a skill i didn't have enough points to in the main playthrough. And doing things like picking flowers, kicking jars and scaring birds have their achievement progress locked to your save, so you can't multitask while unlocking your last skill either. Not a gripe at all, but I'm just putting it out there so you can attempt to gauge how much of that time was spent... doing nothing.

I guess the most similar game I would relate this to is, Starfox Adventures. But without the puzzles. Just adventuring and killing one enemy type. at 15 dollars I would much rather you save a few more bones and play something else, but if you manage to find this game bundled with something else, it is a nice cute stroll. I am happy I played it. And recommend you do so if it is already on your list of games you own, or at a sub 10 price... If you don't have means to play starfox adventures, or something like that. The game takes a real big liking to Zelda... Maybe go play that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262626587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 373, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1609732157}
review:
What is Lili ?

I was disappointed with this game, sometimes you simply cant trust the tags on the games' page, got this thinking it was in fact a rpg-focused game but it isnt, its something completely weird, first of all I love the artstyle and graphics, the game is GORGEOUS and I would love if we got this artstyle on an actual RPG game from the likes of zelda or a platformer, but what we got is mostly a walking simulator, you just walk around this town talking and knowing more about its residents with sometimes mundane tasks throwed in like grab 5 flowers scattered arond or find a key to open a door to another section of the map, the game main focus besides walking around and talking is "purifying" those spirits around the map, which is such a weird stuff to focus on a game like, your main focus is rid the evil of those spirits, how do you that ? you simply run after them (they flee if they spot you) and them you jump and grab on them which will start a weird minigame where you have to drag flowers out of them... WHAT ??? and you complete missions you get upgrades to last longer and complete this minigame faster, thats pretty much what the games revolves into, i have no idea what the devs are smoking and why they decided to make the game like this, its just a walking sim with a weird minigame throwed in the mix, nice graphics ? yes but that doesnt excuse the boring, repetitive and unconventional gameplay loop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059190436', 'num_games_owned': 2769, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1570646803}
review:
This game is surprisingly beautiful, for a port of a mobile game from five years ago. The environments and the characters are brilliantly designed. The story is short and simple (you can probably beat this game in less than three hours if you don't try to 100% it), but satisfying enough.

The game does try too hard to be funny at times, and some jokes just don't land, but for the most part it's charming. The soundtrack is nice but gets repetitive fast, and so does the gameplay. This is essentially a flower-picking game (you beat enemies by plucking out flowers that grow on their backs), but a very pretty one. It's very chill and the "combat" is not violent at all, so it's ideal for kids.

I thought it was strange that this is described as a RPG, because the only RPG-ish element this game has is a choice on how to level up three stats (speed, stealth and grip), which don't really matter all that much.

I wouldn't reccomend paying full price for this, but definitely consider it if it's on sale.

- You play through the game, you collect a lot of tedious things and you're done.

Personal opinion: 
[Honestly, there's not much to say. Aside from the pretty graphics, there really is nothing outstanding in "Lili: Child of Geos" which I would consider to talk about. The story's presentation is weird, some might like it for the quirky humour here and there but this is as far as it goes.
For the gameplay, well, I wouldn't mind it as much if the story would be interesting. Games with going from A to B can be great, just take a look at OneShot. Yes, there's just a little more gameplay in "Lili" but it becomes just unbearable when you don't get a satisfying reward (in that case a good story) out of it.
And the grinding tasks don't make it any better.
The game looks good so it is a shame that it drags itself down so much.]

Price: [BAD]
- If it's not at least on a 75% sale, don't even think of buying.

Game length: [5-8 hours]
- You'll invest most of your time collecting annoying stuff for the achievements (collect 1000 etc...), the game itself is rather short.

Bugs and/or crashes: [NO]


Recommendation: [NO] 
--------------------------------------------
Final rating: [b]34/100[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198011098141', 'num_games_owned': 949, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1567459563}
review:
A pleasant way to spend the afternoon.  Lili is a simple game with cute graphics and charm.  You explore four areas doing simple fetch quests and "defeating" spirits.  The spirit "battles" consist of quick time events, however they aren't that quick, you have plenty of time to press the correct button.  There is no dying in this game, if you lose a spirit battle you just get knocked down.  

There are many achievements, most are easily obtained.  There are some I skipped, such as collecting 1000 flowers and breaking 1000 vases.  The flowers and vases respawn when you revisit an area.  I played with an Xbox controller and it doesn't tell you what the buttons do.  The Left Trigger is a speed sandwich, which increases your speed to catch spirits as they run away.  The Right Trigger is a flash bomb, which will remove thorns and bombs during the spirit battles.  The Y button is the invisibility potion, which you can use to get past certain enemies with shields that knock you back from reaching an area.  You can also press X to use the flash bomb, however that doesn't have any effect during regular game play and you press the trigger to use it during the spirit battle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060588795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1558384876}
review: Lili is a short cute 3d experience, not a platformer and not very challenging but I found it relaxing and enjoyable for its runtime. I was a little miffed that not all achievements could be obtained in one playthrough and the save system gave me a little anxiety (it worked properly for me but I've heard mixed things about it) but aside from that I have little complaint. If you want something easy and relaxing or a game any child will enjoy and that is appropriate for anyone then this one is worth a buy on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091528070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1530500675}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997615915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1558888196}
review:
In short: Short and relaxing Adventure where you follow Lili, a student, in her research of flowers on a mysterious Island.
Turns out you will try to free the people of this Island from their "evil" masters.
Originally a mobile game, Lili:COG is a really neat little game that will take you to a nice Island where you roam around and help people do quests. I recommend it if you are looking for something light and relaxing to kill few hours (5h max I'd say). However, this is not worth 15‚Ç¨, try to get it cheaper, around 5‚Ç¨ or less.

(+):
* Relaxing gameplay
* Beautiful world and graphics
* Nice dialogues and colorful NPCs
* For what it worth, this is a "family friendly" game, if you have a kid, that's a good buy

(-):
* Some achivements are bugged (not a big deal unless you are an achivements hunter)
* One quest is badly created and throw you in the incorrect direction. Nothing the community HUB can't resolve however, just search for it in the discussion.
* Not worth 15‚Ç¨. I would recommend it around 5‚Ç¨ or less.
* Option does not allow re-binding of keys (not a big deal either as very few keys are used)

author: {'steamid': '76561197998754194', 'num_games_owned': 1111, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1558880931}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051443870', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 712, 'last_played': 1498564754}
review:
Thought I had wrote a review for this. Oh well, I received this game from my brother as he thought I would enjoy it and it was alright.

You are a student from some magical academy looking for a flower that you want to do a thesis about. The story is about as detailed as a Saturday morning cartoon which doesn't get better. However, I did have a lot of fun with the combat which involved plucking them off hapless Spirits to get their masks that proved a real challenge.

Customization in here is fairly limited, there's a lot of cameos to a lot of older games, and achievements that aren't difficult at all rather mind-numbingly grindy. I can't tell you how many hours I've had to put into breaking pots for one of them. This game is nothing more than a waste of time, but that could be said of any game really.

It's simple, it's got some okay graphics, and a couple charming characters. Apart from that, there's not much to this and would really recommend it if you want something to do that has almost zero stress.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171388381', 'num_games_owned': 476, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1557692837}

review:
To sum it up, a nice, casual and relaxing adventure. Can be comlpeted without any hardcore effort, even with max ratings (for all achievements there might be a tiny bit of grinding but not super time consuming really... 6hs tops for 100%)

You can play at your own pace and complete the collection tasks in more than one way if you don't wanna just fight spirits
Graphics are nice and smooth, and contribute to the relaxing environment

Worth to give it a try and enjoy

author: {'steamid': '76561198205774116', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1575840672}

author: {'steamid': '76561197989621015', 'num_games_owned': 1273, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1422639165}
review:
Beautiful art with a lot of exploration with some amusing characters. 
But sadly that doesn't keep you attached to the game for long until you get bored of the lack of gameplay. The minigames, flower picking and chatting with NPCs grows boring quite fast. 
I agree with the mobile game vibe others have mentioned. Probably not worth it even on sale. 
I got my copy in a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015035258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1524568858}
review:
This is a very charming game with nice visuals and likeable enough characters. The gameplay is simple, so this can be played if you feel like winding down.

My main gripes are it is a little short and some of the achievements are ridiculously grindy (not a problem if you don't care about getting those).

author: {'steamid': '76561198009966841', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1545603010}
review:
A nice short fantasy game. 
It reminds me a little of Zelda: Majora's Mask due to the masks references, the Koji Kondo's Soundtrack Style, and also the concept art. 
However, the game is a neat exploration game. There's not really a combat; instead, you actually have to hunt spirits to retrieve their flowers. 
Stunning visuals and amazing soundtrack. 
A good game to be bought on Christmas time. You'll enjoy it as I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002524605', 'num_games_owned': 351, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1542500222}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is full of hilarious and beautifully rendered characters, heartwarming side quests, and is just overall a fun, refreshing return to the type of games that made my childhood. It's like if Legend of Zelda and The Secret of Monkey Island had a terrible, wonderful lovechild and it was raised by Lara Croft. I seriously had SO much fun playing this game- everything is entertaining, even down to the item descriptions!

Cons: The controls can be a little bit wonky at first, but are actually quite easy to get used to and don't impede gameplay at all. Occasionally the words and the graphics don't quite get along, but again- it never affected my ability to play.

Takeaway: A unique, fun experience that combines all the things I love about Platformers & Puzzle games (irreverent humor and challenging- but not impossible- play).

author: {'steamid': '76561198016782188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 212, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1540734188}
review: Don't let the pretty visuals and charming desing fool you. This is a phone game and play as such. Extremely shallow.. controls like a phone game and function like a phone game. They upgraded the graphics but the entire game design and controls should have gone a full overhaul to make this a proper PC game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995248317', 'num_games_owned': 2401, 'num_reviews': 236, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1468744605}
review: Gorgeous. Absolutely stunningly pretty, with animations, characters, and environments that look like something out of a Pixar film... but the game has nothing else going for it. The writing, gameplay, sound design and music are all middling, if that, and the whole thing wraps up far too quickly. It feels like an unfinished game, or the product of a small group of (very talented) artists without support from other disciplines. Either way, only worth a cursory glance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031525340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1538278023}
review: Cute little game.  The humor is what really makes it.  The game mechanics are pretty basic and the quests are fairly simple. Despite all that it was still super fun to play.  I would recommend it if you want to play an easier game with a lot of quirky character.  If your one of those people who explore everything and talk to every character then this would be good for you.  I was surprised by how much I enjoyed this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970653174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 238, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1537938954}
review:
It's as if a non-combat-based Pokemon game were combined with an exploration game, and then marketed to pre-teens... and it contains [blatant] refs to slavery(eh) and cannibalism(!!!).  Yes, you read that right.

Pros:
* Novel "combat" system.
* Fun characters.
* Four mildly varied areas.
* Has three stats (and three stat-boosting equipment slots) - which are all equally useful, when you come right down to it.

Cons:
* Easy to farm for the "skeleton key" - I never bought even one disposeable key.
* Getting the bigger achievements requires really tedious farming - I'll pass.
* Probably a bit simple for teenagers, but shouldn't be played by Jr High-School age kids.  (I enjoyed, after I reset my expectations)

NOTE if you do buy: If you don't get a 3-star win on any combat, be SURE to click "rematch" - else, you may not be able to try 'em again.  Only says this after the 1st combat or two.

TL;DRL 6.5/10 if full price - else, maybe 7.5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962165418', 'num_games_owned': 2158, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1510830657}
review:
There was this MMORPG for a while called "Free Realms". It was extremely bright and colorful, because it was set up as a "for kids" MMO. Nobody died, the focus was on harmless exploration and minigames instead of lots of combat (although it had some), there were concerts and lots of outfits to collect...

That's what Lili - Child of Geos reminds me of. Lili arrives on Geos Island, where wooden constructs are held in service to various spirits. Lili, researching for her degree in plant magic, can climb onto these spirits and pluck the magic flower from their back to defeat them and make them blast off.

Yes, this IS referred to once as "deflowering them". More on that in a bit. 

Aside from that you do a lot of exploring around the island, collecting things, breaking pots, breaking into people's homes, running sidequests...

That's another part of the MMO comparison.

The third part is that much like Free Realms was, Lili - Child of Geos is GRINDY AS HECK. In my 4 hour playthrough I broke about 140 pots and picked about 245 flowers, for example. The top-tier achievement for each of those requires 1000 EACH. I beat about 20 spirits, but it wants me to beat 50 and rematch 5 and 3-star all of them and...

So that's clearly not going to happen. 

Aside from that, Lili really wants to be a noncombat Zelda game. (You can get the hat and fairy, and two of the treasures you can find on the island are the Sword of Masters and a weird golden triangle thing that's probably important to SOMEbody.) 

The thing is, it's full of weird dumb "Gamer" humor to the point where Lili herself is a huge video game geek and just spends a while identifying meme quotes from video games in one of her side conversations. You've got jokes about 'deflowering' and pixelated 'naked' photographs of the wooden (sexless) constructs at the same time as you have bright bloomy landscapes and "collect 20 gems" gameplay.

Man this game ... I can't figure out who it's for. Kids? Sarcastic adults who hate violence? People who just really like when a game lets them wear hats? ... Rare fans?

I enjoyed the experience but I'm glad I got this for only a few dollars. At the current non-sale price of $15 it's a HARD no, no matter who you are. If it were on sale, it could be a provisional yes depending on how you feel about doofy humor and using a controller instead of the hideous mouse controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042777104', 'num_games_owned': 365, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1503928637}
review: Ho apprezzato molto questo gioco per le poche ore che mi ha donato, in Lili: Child of Geos ci si immerge in un mondo fantastico popolato da esserini magici assolutamente carinissimi. Il sistema di combattimento √® qualcosa che non avevo mai visto, molto originale: dovrete staccare dei fiori dai totem malvagi che vogliono fermare il vostro compito di portatori di pace nell'isola. Dateci un'occhiata, mi piacerebbe un seguito! [b]3.5/5[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198115565879', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1526777439}
review:
I'll go over each of my initial thoughts I had while playing the game.

The environments are beautifully made, and I was always excited to see what each new area was going to look like. 
My favorite zone in particular was Rust Grove.

Rust Grove also had the best music track, in my opinion. The other songs were... a bit more ordinary, but not bad.

With the environments being first, the characters are my second favorite thing about this game. They are interesting and silly, and some have a decent amount of dialogue that I recommend clicking through and reading. Their designs are also very quirky and refreshing.

The story is cute, but it's rather short and plain. Nothing spectacular.

The gameplay is nice, but fighting Spirits got kind of boring after a while. Unless you're like me and you want to complete everything, you may not feel that way.

As far as bugs are concerned, I didn't experience any while playing.

A personal pet peeve of mine is grammar mistakes, and this game had quite a few of them. I'm not going to tell you to skip out on it because of that though.

I bought Lili: Child of Geos while it was 60% off, and played it for around 10 hours getting all the trophies, and doing everything it had to offer. 

Overall, I recommend this game only if you have nothing better to play. I don't think it's worth the full price, so I also think it's best if you wait for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141815402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1526615358}
review:
I wanted this game for a long time, but never had a computer even close to being able to run it until very recently.

Man, am I disappointed. 

The story was incredibly short and rather lacking. The characters were pretty one dimensional and Lili's character development in the game is more awkward and strange than anything else. I get the message they were going for but it's really forced and doesn't really make sense. In the end, I really had zero attachment to any of the constructs or even Lili. There was potential for so much to be done with the constructs and their backstories and even the backstories of the spirits but instead it's just tiny bios that get shorter and more nonsensical the further into the game you go. 

A lot of the references to other games also feel forced. Everything regarding WoodBored bored me and made Lili look like a pretentious brat. A lot of the humor really relies on a certain type of player...

"Combat" is EXTREMELY repetitive and the vast majority of achievements are absolutely mind numbingly grindy. The 1k flowers isn't so bad because flowers from spirits count. But... 500 vases? Scare 500 birds? Extremely boring. The nice towns were just not enough to make vase hunting really worth it, especially since money is such a nonissue there's not much reason to hunt them down during normal gameplay. I wish I were kidding that most of my time spent in this game was kicking vases and scaring birds. The birds actually glitched on me, too. It stopped at 306 and I had to make a second save just to finish that.
I felt no sense of accomplishment from really anything in this game. It was a series of fetch quests mostly and overuse of a flower picking minigame.

The one thing I liked is the one thing that drew me to the game in the first place but even that had some disappointment as I progressed. It really is a pretty game. The constructs have some decently varied designs other than Wanderer and his many clones (soup guys). The spirits, however, were all nearly identical. Their masks were the only thing that was different between them. Sure, their bios varied, but then the later spirits you encounter have absolutely barebones entries. There's no reason to care who any of the spirits are aside from the Mayor.

This is fairly ranty so I'll end this here. 

In short, I really can't recommend this even to people who just want to pad out their achievements. It's easy but just not worth the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017111032', 'num_games_owned': 1851, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1526172295}
review: I went into LIli only really knowing that you had to gather flowers from pesky fairies and left it having experienced a short romp through a graduate student trying to help overthrow an oppressive class structure that may or may not involve cannabalism--all without doing anything more violent personnally then plucking flowers. It was delightful and charming and I just might go back and 100% it if I need a smile on a cloudy day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060958951', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1524459349}
review: Honestly, it's fun for all ages. A bit simplistic, sure, but it's because that's how is was supposed to be made. The dark/adult humor embedded inside the game will go right over a kid's head, making the game that much enjoyable for mature gamers alike. It's a collectathon intertwined with lore and other odd twists, making it a very good "beginner" game. Solid 9.5/10 for what it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025403989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1521639004}
review:
Prima di mettere la mia valutazione sono andato a controllare il prezzo sullo store (14.99euro) e poi andato a rivedere quanto lo pagai io scontato (3.99euro).
Sotto queste condizioni, mi spiace, ma devo bocciarlo, perch√® per me conta il primo prezzo. Se lo trovate a molto meno per√≤ fateci un pensierino.
Intendiamoci, il gioco non √® terribile, ma l'esborso non √® giustificato a fronte di contenuti davvero miseri. E non solo.
Il gioco consiste nel liberare una isoletta dal giogo di una banda di spiriti cattivi, comandati dall'autoproclamatosi sindaco locale, anch'egli uno spirito come i suoi scagnozzi.
L'isola √® costituita da una serie di mappe (5 o 6, ora non ricordo bene) lungo le quali si incontrano dei personaggi amichevoli (costrutti), fiori da raccogliere, vasi da distruggere e bauli da aprire. I vasi e i bauli danno come premio una certa quantit√† di denaro e gli ultimi anche degli oggetti, a volte utili per missioni secondarie (loffie e pochissime) che vengono assegnate dai costrutti. I fiori invece possono venire convertiti in denaro nell'unico negozio dell'isola per acquisire potenziamenti od oggetti (ma anche abiti per la protagonista, inutili, solo estetici).
Potenziamenti ed oggetti servono per migliorare e/o attivare tre caratteristiche della protagonista: il movimento in stealth, la velocit√†, la capacit√† di aggrapparsi agli spiriti (pi√π √® alta, pi√π tempo si rimane aggrappati). Ma a cosa servono? E' presto detto: lungo ogni mappa si trova una serie di spiriti che vagano a caso. Bisogna avvicinarsi e saltarci addosso aggrappandosi. Alcuni per√≤ fuggono appena sanno di essere visti, quindi la velocit√† serve a rincorrerli pi√π rapidamente e la capacit√† stealth ad avvicinarsi senza essere visti.
Una volta aggrappati sugli spiriti parte la fase focale dell'intero gioco: un combattimento che funziona essenzialmente come un Quick Time Event. Sullo schermo appaiono i 4 tasti del pad da premere e bisogna farlo velocemente prima che il tempo scada (si ha pi√π tempo con una capacit√† di aggrappo maggiore). Nei negozi si possono acquistare anche delle bombe accecanti che in questa fase sono utili a disorientare per un poco lo spirito e rallentare la sequenza.
Il grosso problema di questi eventi √® che sono confusionari e poco divertenti: mi sono ritrovato pi√π volte inondato di icone da premere, decidendo di premere i tasti a cazzo e riuscendo lo stesso nell'impresa. In altre parole, il fulcro del gioco √® questo, ma quando arrivava il momento mi veniva voglia di sbuffare, talmente √® fatto male.
Tutto cos√¨, fino allo scontro finale compreso: 

1- entri in una nuova mappa
2- fai un paio di missioni secondarie (puoi anche non farle)
3- uccidi i 3-4 spiriti che ti vengono indicati
4- passi alla mappa successiva

Non tenendo conto degli achievement il tutto √® completabile in circa 3 orette (o anche meno). Davvero pochissimo.
Gli achievement sono altra cosa: alcuni prevedono la raccolta di 1000 fiori e 1000 vasi e mille altre cose... uscendo ed entrando nelle mappe questi oggetti si risistemano, quindi si dovrebbe fare avanti e indietro in continuazione per arrivare agli achievement. Il problema √® che raccogliere 1000 oggetti vagando per il nulla cosmico puzza davvero di riempitivo per giustificare 15 euro.
Le ambientazioni per√≤ sono davvero molto belle ed evocative, anche se con interazione nulla. Ma dopo un poco vengono a noia. Anche la canzoncina di sottofondo √® molto carina, Zelda Windwaker Style. Solo che va in loop e dopo un po' comincia a sfiancare.
Il gioco √® tutto in inglese. Ora, non √® proprio un inglese facile (con alcuni costrutti che distorcono le parole), ma non √® questo il problema: la storia √® meno di mediocre, non c'√® un vero interesse a seguire le vicende, per cui all'ennesimo siparietto parlato (tramite fumetti, non vi √® doppiaggio) leggere diventa anche molto fastidioso. Perch√® quello che i protagonisti dicono non interessa a nessuno (due uccelli chiedono alla protagonista di togliersi gli occhiali per vederle gli occhi, e la cosa va avanti per linee di dialogo: interessante).
L'ho giocato con il pad, ma la mappatura per l'uso degli oggetti in game √® davvero scomoda e confusionaria. Forse √® pi√π apprezzabile usando mouse+tastiera.
In definitiva, a parte i difetti elencati, i due punti di forza sono essenzialmente l'aspetto visivo e il senso di leggerezza e di pace che il gioco trasmette.
Ho letto di bug qui nella community, ma io non ne ho trovati. Se mi fosse accaduto qualcosa di spiacevole, avrei azzannato il prodotto in modo molto peggiore.

4/10 (6/10 se lo trovate a non pi√π di 5 euro)

author: {'steamid': '76561198151990669', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1520861513}
review:
Lili Child of Geos is a fun RPG game where you play as Lili, a Student who is on Geos in order to gain research for her paper of Vegi-Magical Plants. You spend the game collecting these plants as you watch the story unfold. It is a short (roughly 4-5 hours) and light hearted game. The graphics are breath takingly beautiful and the characters each have their own little quirks. If you are interested in seeing this game in action then please have a look at my Playthrough on YouTube: https://youtu.be/gpBEcGyvRF4

All in all, I highly suggest this game for anyone looking for a quick 10-15 minute break from anything as it does not require a long sit down and immense amoumnts of attention, and the music and scenery are quite relaxing.

review:
An indie-game from 2014. A bit short (completed the main story in 4 hours) but still some achievements to go.

Graphics: 9/10 (9/10 in 2014)

author: {'steamid': '76561198014987559', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1435255403}
review: A cute puzzle point and click game with amusing dialogue. It's well made and I honestly enjoyed it! The plot was alright, but the setting was really nice (good character design, nice landscapes, fun, warm colours) and the puzzles were fun and din't feel unfair. Would recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198055915053', 'num_games_owned': 390, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1518943771}
review:
An incredibly fun and cute but short game, you run around collecting flowers of spirits, and break pots for gold which you can use for some upgrades or change your outfit a little.
Not really any replayability, unless you (like myself) didn't get everything the first time round, uninstalled and then reinstalled it at a later time, and have to play through it all again.
Great atmospherics, and a nice relaxing soundtrack.
While I do recommend getting this and going through it all at least once, I have to say that you should wait for a seasonal sale.

review: Love the characters, envorinment, and references! The gameplay can get a bit repetitve and the camera can be a bit wonky, but overall really enjoyable and super cute! Perfect if you're looking for a world to get lost in for a bit, but I'd reccomend waiting until it was on sale, like I did.

review: This is a really cute game. I wasn't expecting much when I started it, but it really started to grow on me. The graphics are beautiful and I find the music relaxing and I love the art style and character designs of the spirits and mail man. This game brought a smile to my face and had me hooked running around collecting flowers and treasure. If you're playing with a controller, it can be a bit unresponsive at times and accessing the inventory items were annoying because i never knew what button used what item and I would use my items by accident when hitting the wrong button.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077636973', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1512075912}
review:
[b]IMPORTANTE:[/b] Non fatevi condizionare dal "pollice" assegnato a questa review, ma piuttosto leggetela per intero cos√¨ da farvi un'idea completa del gioco. Inoltre, in fondo alla recensione potete trovare un video di gameplay del gioco nel caso lo vogliate vedere "in azione". 
Un enorme grazie a @jckl per avermi regalato questo gioco permettendomi di recensirlo !!
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Lili: Child of Geos nasce con dei presupposti ed un contesto particolari: √® un progetto mobile succesivamente portato su PC, il che renderebbe comprensibili alcune mancanze del titolo, ma d'altro canto gli sviluppatori sono ex-dipendenti di Epic Games, che quindi dovrebbero essere in grado di sfruttare l'Unreal Engine (motore utilizzato per questo gioco) al massimo delle sue potenzialit√†.

Il risultato √® un'incredibile via di mezzo: un gioco che √® piacevole da giocare e scorre senza problemi, riuscendo anche a intrattenere con [u]una storia e dei personaggi vivaci e ben caratterizzati, ma che scade in meccaniche di gioco semplici e ripetitive le quali non forniscono al titolo la minima rigiocabilit√†[/u].

[b]Parlando di gameplay[/b], il gioco si basa sull'esplorazione dell'isola di Geos (suddivisa in 4 aree) con lo scopo iniziale di raccogliere alcuni fiori che la protagonista dovrebbe usare per completare un progetto scolastico; le pieghe della storia ci porteranno poi a combattere degli "spiriti" e quindi migliorare le nostre abilit√†, rompere vasi ed aprire casse alla ricerca di denaro per poter comprare oggetti e potenziamenti.

Il problema principale √® che [u]l'unica componente action del gioco si riduce a dei "combattimenti" eseguiti tramite Quick-Time-Event[/u], mentre invece i dialoghi, il completamento di piccole quest secondarie, l'esplorazione delle abitazioni e la raccolta delle risorse sono estremamente semplicistiche e risultano quindi ripetitive a lungo andare.
Si pu√≤ quindi notare come, in realt√†, [b]il paragone che viene fatto dagli sviluppatori tra questo gioco e mostri sacri come Zelda o Psychonauts in realt√† cade a pezzi[/b], perch√® la complessit√† di Lili: CoG non sfiora minimamente quella dei titoli sopra citati, n√® tantomeno la sua longevit√† √® paragonabile.

Analizzando invece [b]la grafica[/b], si pu√≤ dire che il colpo d'occhio offerto dal gioco, grazie anche all'[u]ottima scelta estetica effettuata dagli sviluppatori[/u], risulta molto piacevole con alcune scene e paesaggi che hanno veramente un look fantastico; con il controller alla mano, per√≤, si possono notare varie cadute di stile dovute a effetti post-processing (non rimovibili dalle opzioni grafiche) totalmente fuori posto che vanno quasi a rovinare l'impatto visivo generale: in particolare un'aberrazione cromatica fuori luogo ed un motion blur di scarsa qualit√†.
[b]La musica di sottofondo[/b], anche se non conta tantissime tracce diverse, riesce ad accompagnare piacevolmente il giocatore durante le 6-7 ore richieste per completare il gioco.

Una nota dolente ricade - ahim√® - sul [u][b]doppiaggio[/b], praticamente assente da ogni personaggio (inclusa la protagonista)[/u] se non per alcuni versi e vocine che vengono utilizzati in corrispondenza di animazioni durante i dialoghi per sottolineare un particolare stato d'animo. I personaggi risultano comunque interessanti e spesso anche simpatici nel loro essere "cartooneschi", ma avrebbero giovato grandemente da un doppiaggio che caratterizzasse ancora di pi√π le loro personalit√†; in ogni caso la protagonista risulta subito molto carina, simpatica e vivace anche senza un doppiaggio.

Anche [b]la trama alla base del gioco[/b] - semplice ma non banale, anche nelle tematiche trattate - ha delle potenzialit√† che si sarebbero potute rendere molto meglio dedicando pi√π cura ed attenzione al lato narrativo del videogioco; la storia risulta comunque un buon accompagnamento per le avventure della nostra Lili sull'isola, portando il giocatore a provare un senso di appagamento quando riuscir√† finalmente a sistemare la situazione sull'isola di Geos.


[b]PRO:[/b]
+ Un ottimo stile estetico, colpo d'occhio sicuramente piacevole
+ Protagonista carina, vivace e simpatica, vi affezionerete facilmente
+ Storia semplice ma coinvolgente, buon accompagnamento durante il gioco
+ Ambientazione azzeccata, personaggi e atmosfera ben caratterizzati
+ Controlli fluidi e interfaccia dei menu facilmente navigabile
+ Completo supporto ai controller
+ Carte collezionabili di Steam

[b]CONTRO:[/b]
- Meccaniche di gioco semplicistiche e ripetitive
- Longevit√† non eccezionale e rigiocabilit√† pressoch√® nulla
- L'assenza di doppiaggio pesa notevolmente sulla narrativa del gioco
- Prezzo troppo elevato per un gioco portato su PC da mobile
- Effetti di post-processing fuori luogo
- Implementazione degli achievement penosa, trofei stupidi e con trigger pessimi


[h1]Voto: 6.5/10[/h1]
Non √® difficile notare che il gioco ha una sua anima e un buon potenziale, ma la scelta di meccaniche semplicistiche e ripetitive (probabilmente dettata dalla natura mobile del gioco originale) e la realizzazione tecnica non troppo curata rendono il prezzo pieno di 14.99‚Ç¨ totalmente fuori luogo per quello che il titolo ha da offrire. Se trovato in saldo a ~5‚Ç¨ per√≤, questo titolo sar√† sicuramente in grado di offrirvi qualche ora di piacevole rilassamento mentre vi avventurate in esplorazione dell'isola.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=__0sG4ewHEM

author: {'steamid': '76561197996147456', 'num_games_owned': 571, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1508305007}
review:
It's a charming game and the protag is a cutie but that's about all that's going for it. 
As far as gameplay goes, the story/main objective is very repetitive, and the only instances of any actual combat or difficulty come from QTEs. Surprisingly the game was also very sluggish and on a PC that as of right now is perfectly modern so I was very displeased by the performance drops. 

[b]Pros[/b]: Pleasant characters, nice look, charming style, very easy, approachable to most people I imagine.

[b]Cons[/b]: Inexplicably poor performance, dialogue is not voiced, instead it's text with moving models/faces which is sort of ridiculous for a modern title. The island can be a bit large/winding to navigate comfortably, and as travel/backtracking is required if you are impatient it can really hamper the experience.

[b]Bonus Con[/b]: The developers abandoned a more ambitious and better looking title to rush this one.

[h1]Overall Score 6/10 - Worth a play, but only if it's free or heavily discounted.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198041150936', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1510387608}
review:
Things you'll do in 'Lili: Child of Geos': Pick flowers, smash pots, torment spirits, drop out of school, overthrow a corrupt and cruel government, free slaves, collect hats, and rescue a guy's pretzels. 

Despite the game's simplicity, it manages to be utterly addictive. The world is gorgeous, and the characters that fill it quirky and adorable. The game's humour is also fantastic, and there's a bunch of references to well-known media. 

Some advice I have for new players: Don't bother buying keys. Convert your flowers to money and you'll quickly have enough to buy the skeleton key, thus rendering buying small keys a pointless waste. I had enough for the skeleton key before reaching the third zone (there's four in total). Also pick as many flowers, smash as many pots, and rip the flowers off spirits as much as you can. Even if you don't want the achievements for it, it'll still be helpful in getting resources. 

All in all, it was a very cute, quirky, and memorable game. Possibly one of the best I've ever played, in fact. There were a couple of minor issues (slightly awkward camera controls, occasionally getting stuck), but nothing game breaking. It's a solid 10/10 for me. And tbh, even if the rest of the game totally sucked, I'd be inclined to at least rate it a 7 for the fact that there's a genderqueer spirit. Nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198286511673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1510334189}

author: {'steamid': '76561198039943297', 'num_games_owned': 716, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1510310917}
review:
I expected to play through a short, not too interesting point and click game, instead I got a... well still short but quite intriguing 3D adventure ‚Äúexploration‚Äù game, if you can call it that. 


[b][u]Positive:[/u][/b]


[list]
[*][b]Story:[/b] Quirky, light-hearted characters and story (which still has a message you might/can think about for a bit)
[/list]


[list]
[*][b]lore and world:[/b] The lore and world feels huge compared to the shortness of the game! Every character is unique and fun to talk to, every spirit has his or her own characteristics and there are a lot of lore items to gather. I would love to explore more of this world... Or just have it be bigger in general.
[/list]


[list]
[*][b]References and humor:[/b] I found the references to other games and things quite funny and the tone/humor in general made me chuckle from time to time. 
[/list]


[list]
[*][b]Graphics:[/b] Good looking for what it is, of course no high end graphics but I enjoyed the art style and the looks of it (also rainbow colored paint pooping birds.... !!!)
[/list]


[list]
[*][b]Outfits and Collectibles:[/b] Yeah most of the Outfits are the same just differently colored but outfits being rare nowadays without having to pay for them makes this a plus. There are also quite a few hats and masks to gather and a few pets. Makes my inner perfectionist smile tho <3.
[/list]


[list]
[*][b]Sound/Music:[/b] the music fit perfectly most of the time. The last area felt a bit off sometimes as it went into action-heavy music even though I was just running around collecting flowers. All in all it didn't feel bad, definitely not one of those games that makes you hate the music because you just can't listen to it anymore but also not super awesome like Nier or Kingdom Hearts. 
[/list]


[list]
[*][b]Controls:[/b] More of a positive even if it has some flaws but the option to play with a controller saved the game for me. I personally used the controller even though the game doesn't fully explain which button does what (accidentally used some items trying out the controller, but meh). Main reason was the flower plucking mini game (aka ‚Äúfighting the spirits‚Äù) as it felt awkward with the mouse (although the idea of actually plucking the flowers is awesome! And it makes a lot of sense for a former mobile game). With a controller it's a lot easier and I'm happy they support controller usage (playing the game with mouse and keyboard only would've probably ruined it for me). 
[/list]


[b][u]Negative:[/u][/b]


[list]
[*][b]Length:[/b] Very, very short with only 3 hours to finish the game (achievements not included, going to need a few more hours for the more grind heavy achievements) and probably even less time if you just do the story part
[/list]


[list]
[*][b]Side-quests and npcs:[/b] Very little side quests and a lot of npc were unused after introducing them to you, felt like a lot of wasted potential (maybe I missed something or it is bugged for me)
[/list]


[list]
[*][b]‚ÄúBugs‚Äù:[/b] minor bugs but nothing that a bit of wiggling around couldn't fix, the quest marker being buggy and not disappearing was a bit more annoying (achievements were fine for me, only missing 2 of the more grind based achievements)
[/list]


[list]
[*][b]False advertisement:[/b] I would recommend watching a video first if you can't decide. I read the description on steam before writing this review and most of the points they make are just not true. It's by far no Zelda game (I haven't played the other two games they give as a reference) and other things they state are also... no really true. No ‚Äúhuge number of quests‚Äù, [spoiler]there actually is no choice (or not a lot, yes you do have the choice if you want to fight the spirits or do quests to progress)[/spoiler] and definitely no reason to play it for 40 hours (except MAYBE if you want to have the best score in every spirit, but why? Or if you want to play it once a day, but why again? xD)
[/list]


[b][u]Neutral;[/u][/b]


[list]
[*][b]Difficulty:[/b] As I only played on normal I can't say a lot here. Normal difficulty felt OK and appropriate, had to redo maybe 3-4 fights cause they somehow threw me off, but the game isn't supposed to be hard IMO.
[/list]


[list]
[*][b]Skill tree and items:[/b] I mean it's nice to have stats and it felt like they actually did a bit but they still felt glued on. Could've easily done without them. Same for the items, I rarely used them and the bomb sometimes even made it worse.
[/list]


[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b] I would recommend the game. It is a small indie gem and I enjoyed my time with it, especially because I bought it on sale. The full prize of them game feels a bit expensive, I'd say it's more of a 10‚Ç¨ game give or take.


I would definitely buy and play a bigger more fleshed out version of this game! More areas, more quests, more story, etc! And maybe then the advertisement would actually be accurate ;)
