author: {'steamid': '76561198026325298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1430693740}
review:
[h1]Score: 7/10[/h1]

[b][u]Similar Games[/u][/b]
Animal Crossing

[b][u]Summary[/u][/b]
Lili is out sailing to find the island of Geos which is for whatever reason super rare to find. She finds the island and plans on collecting flower samples from the island. The island consists of wooden constructs and spirits. The constructs are essentially ill treated slaves and only Lili can help because your a human. Thus your goal is finish your school project by grabbing onto the mean spirits and... deflower them. As Lili runs around grabbing and deflowering male/female spirits she also collects things. You can buy stuff at the shop as well. You also level up your grab, stealth, and speed skills.

[b][u]The Good[/u][/b]
The art style is amazingly fun and colorful. The pull flowers mini game is actually quite fun considering how simple it is. The music and characters are quite lovely as well. More then anything this game just has that casual goofy fun vibe going for it.

[b][u]The Bad[/u][/b]
It doesn't have actual speech in the conversations. It advertises itself as a Legend of Zelda when it play more like a Animal Crossing slash flower picking similulator. I would also say that the game suffers from being to simple. You'll be left feeling that the game could have been a legend of zelda if they would have tried for it. The game tends to shove video game references and trivia down your throat.

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]
Its a casual fun game. Don't go in expecting a grand 3D platformer because this is just a phone game on steroids.

[b][u]Value[/u][/b]
As beautiful and playful as this game is it really isn't a huge value. I can only suggest paying around $4.

author: {'steamid': '76561198226275828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1431888300}

author: {'steamid': '76561198176251917', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1429849817}
review:
If I have one thing to say about this game, it's that any Zelda series fan should pick this game up. This game is the dev's love letter to gaming in the '90s. The world is beautiful, the characters quirky, and the entire game will bring a feeling of childhood nostalgia for any Gen X-er. 

Those with kids who are on their way to be second-generation Hylian adventurers will like Lili. The difficulty is adjustable so both the young ones and parents can enjoy a bit of a challenge. The game is short but never feels grindy, a few acheivements notwithstanding.

I played with a 360 controller and the hit detection for collecting items was a bit unforgiving at times, but I'm guessing that isn't the case for keyboard/mousers. That was my only real issue with this game.

Personally my favorite part of Lili is its humor. You'll notice a lot of screenshots with other videogames being referenced and also with Lili playing the straightman to a world of silly spirits and constructs. This is also the only game I have ever played where every single house has a toilet. Ironic that it's a game where all the characters are wooden dummies.

So a thumbs up from me, and I look forward to any sequels or new games from this team.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038735008', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1430342555}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993409048', 'num_games_owned': 948, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1428233289}
review:
Typical console port. No spoken dialog, only mumbled few-word phrases like "heee-llooo-hooo", but often pages of uninteresting text dialog to read. No intro (at least I didn't get to see one), few simple controls, repetitive tasks all the time.

In the 2 hours I managed to play, it was all about breaking pots, opening chests and occasionally jumping spirits to pluck flowers off their backs. The map is a pain and full of unclear markings, keys that open all doors of a level can be bought fairly soon after collecting a few flowers, and most of the quests are pretty silly. Not just silly because all you do is run around and by chance figure something out, but also silly because the surrounding stories' scripting is of pretty low quality. A ninja sword for a pirate? C'mooon.

To think that I could've played 2 more entertaining hours of Titanfall instead... *sigh*

author: {'steamid': '76561198077677697', 'num_games_owned': 467, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1430039681}
review:
Visually Beautiful!
At the start of the game, I'm struck by it beautiful visual. Lili Child of Geos is one of the best beautiful visual game that i have ever played.

In this game, you'll be playing as Lili. A student of weird botanical major that exploring the island of geos to find a good speciment of flower. Like all of klise game out there, while in there, she became a hero that freed the citizen from the evil mayor.

The story of the game is not one that you will remember. The quest and the level system are really bland.

The only thing I like is the game visual, and the refreshness of the minigame and unique character found in the island.

Well, this game is not the best game out there. But it's worth to play at least once :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197973630631', 'num_games_owned': 2729, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1429048377}
review:
I really don't know what to think of Lili: Child of Geos. The game started as an iOS game, to developer BitMonster's credit, the PC release has end of improvements, to the graphics and gameplay. However, you still get the inkling its not that far removed from its iOS origins.

[b]Pros[/b]
Funny, beutiful, and unique coming of age story that is generally fun.
Lots of collectibles with plenty of pop-culture nods and winks

[b]Cons[/b] 
Combat gets tedious quickly, achievements are very grindy.
Bit too easy, a bit too simple.

[b]Overall[/b]
Considering the time it takes to play through, I'm not sure its worth the price (¬£15). It may sound a wee bit elitist but Lili: Child of Geos is just the type of "casual" game you'd expect from something designed for iOS. Last word, it's fun enough if you want something pretty, amusing and simple to chill with.

For a full review, visit my blog  on the [url=https://noisybark.squarespace.com/ogawd-1/2015/4/17/flower-power-a-lili-child-of-geos-review]NoisyBark Website[/url].

author: {'steamid': '76561198116697980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1694887246}
review:
"Lili is a quirky adventure RPG hybrid with stunning visuals, silky-smooth graphics, a cinematic story-line, and a fresh new way to deal with enemies."

Quirky yes.
Adventure maybe.
RPG no.
Hyrbid wat.
Stunning visuals yes.
Silky-smooth graphics, oh yeah (GTX680).
Cinematic story-line wat?
Fresh new way to deal with enemies... ONE WAY.. Repetitive.

Finishable under four hours with extensive exploration and side questions. 

It is playable and enjoyable although the mechanics are lacking in several areas. Story is "whatever" but the dialogs are kinda funny and targeted at somewhat older peeps.

Dunno... Get it on sale.

review: I picked this game up as it was on sale and it looked interesting. Gameplay wise it has an interesting mechanic. Combat is not overly complicated, though the difficulty ramps up to the point you need to be on the ball to get your 3 stars. The story line isn't the most original, but its quirky and fun. The art style is the best bit of the game and as another reviewer put it, if they could get the gameplay to be more engaging and imho lengthen the story a few more hours this game could be a huge hit. At the moment its almost like a beyond good and evil light...

author: {'steamid': '76561198038728155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1428824152}
review: A simple yet adorable game. It references many other games with it's costumes and treasures. Also, despite the setting seeming a bit childish and cartoon-ish, the game actually has a bit of a mature undertone to it. If your looking to kill a few hours picking flowers and hunting down treasure, as you take in the beatiful world of Geos, give this game a Try. At a rather slow pace, I did full completion (story, all treasures, all costumes, etc.) in about 6 hours. Short and sweet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075868257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1417675276}
review:
I thought long and hard about whether to give this game a thumbs up or thumbs down, and it was a very tough decision but in the end I just couldn't ignore the feeling of emptiness that I got from this game.

TL;DR:
Go on youtube and watch a video of this game actually being played before you buy it. If you still think you want it, go ahead, but don't say you weren't warned.

The graphics are beautiful, the world is beautiful, the character and object designs are really nice, and there's even a hint of a decent plot in there. So where did it go wrong?

When it comes down to it, this 'game' is pretty much a flower-picking simulator. You can have as many textures, shaders and polygons as you like but when your core gameplay consists of picking flowers off the backs of tree sprites, you have a problem. Had this been a 3D visual novel or a point and click I'd probably be able to give it a straight thumbs up, but I just cannot get over that fact that this game's core 'gameplay' element is flower picking. People compare this to Zelda, but it's nothing like Zelda, there's exploration but there's no real puzzle element to it, no tools or weapons - just free roaming, talking and flower picking.

I get the impression that this 'game' was made by a 3D modeller to show off their work rather than someone who makes video games. This is one of the massive downsides of modern game making tools, anyone with next to no experience in making games can create a game, but because they don't have experience it falls very far from the 'masterpiece' they are dreaming of. It's like a paint brush, in the hand of an artist it creates masterpieces, in the hand of a child it makes a mess. This is almost the opposite of that - give a 3D artist the tools to make a game and they create a beautiful work in which not much happens. This game proves definitively that games should be and are much more than just good graphics.

I can't bear too much of a grudge because I got it on sale for about ¬£3, but I feel like this 'game' is something designed to sit down and gaze at lovingly rather than actually be played. Whoever did the art for this game is definately a true artist, even better than the artists for lots of popular, well selling titles. But whoever came up with the gameplay should either spend a long time evaluating what they think games are about or just not be allowed to manage gameplay at all. 

All in all it's pretty tragic really, because this game could have been a real masterpiece. Instead it just leaves me with a very empty feeling, somewhere between admiration and regret, like a beautiful rose being picked before it could bloom or a promising young life cut short thanks to a tragic accident.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079918200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1428854398}

author: {'steamid': '76561198189155037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1440127504}
review:
Relaxing, fun, whimsical and light-hearted game. For a non-violent game, it may seem to cater to children, but it's equally fun for people who are simply looking for a stress free game to pass their time with.

Stunningly beautiful graphics. The quality can be adjusted to advocate for smoother gameplay on lower end computers. Even at the lowest setting, the game is still beautiful.

Relaxing, whimsical music that's both suited to the game and theme, and easy listening. Lack of voice-acting is certainly not an issue here.

A truly great gem. Definitely recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198125933199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1472362278}
review: It's basically a bully the bullies simulator, where a sentient mailbox vommits letters at you. I feel like I'm missing some back story from how cold the opening was, but it really didn't detract from me getting stuck in to the begaining and learning the ropes of combat, if you can call it that, but your motivation however selfish Lili's may be initially feels very justified, like shooting Nazi's, it's has a mind set along the lines of "Of course I will topple this government, it's corrupt." the best part is you don't actually harm anyone in the process, pacifism for the win. Characters seem innocent and in need of your help, while bad guys seem uncareing and unworthy of your pity, there are side quests, mostly consiting of find x item and return when you do, so non time sensative my favorite kind, your main goal is to develop a substantial collection of magical flowers. Why? I don't know, apparently Lili is a colledge student wrting her Thesis, that's just what I've gathered from her saying explicitly that to several NPC's. Also no voice acting, so if you hate reading diolouge that dosen't scroll unless you tell it to, like in older adventure games, it really dosen't matter, seeing as you get quest markers on the map, you could possible just ignore all the talking and fallow the markers to beat the game, maybe occasionally need to hit Esc to see the next non marked goal. It's pretty and fun, and I bought a potion that makes butterflies like me more, also it's full of Pop Culture Tresure chests.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142431895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1435317398}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998871723', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1618582369}
review:
Simple game but very beautiful and engaging!  It's rather short, I beat it in less than 6 hours, but I thought it was worth it (although I got it on sale). You mainly pick flowers, kick open containers and explore, but that's all you need. It's a fun quirky game with amusing characters. Half the fun of the game was just looking at it. Where limited game play leaves off, the adorable design picks up the slack. This is definitely a game for those people who love to get to every chest and go through every door. There's some cute hats, masks and outfits to collect too.

I have only two cons for the game. First, if you see the cute flying french bulldog in the banner? Apparently they took the dog away for newer buyers of the game. I obviously didn't buy the game just for the dog, but it was still disappointing (and throws the term "complete edition" into question). Second, there were a few loose ends left unresolved, so that feeling of completion was marred a bit by a few unanswered questions. I also got the impression from some of the dialog that this is a sequel to another game, but I don't think it is?

Regardless, this is a very well-made game, and I still definitely recommend this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198080692382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1504005790}
review:
[h1]AN EXCITING JOURNEY ABOUT... COLLECTING FLOWERS?[/h1]

The concept seems rather boring, but put some quirky characters, interesting world design and beautiful visuals on the mix and thus is born [i]Lili: Child of Geos[/i]! A mixture of [i]Yume Nikki[/i] and [i]FEZ[/i] on a 3D environment, Lili's journey to complete her degree in something quite close to botany is not only a banquet for the sight, but also an entertaining non-violent alternative to not-always-so-subtle gaming references and somewhat-intelligent humor. However, as most indie games that try to inovate, the title has remarkable flaws or raw concepts.

The story is not impressive or captivating, but the funny and varied cast of characters sure compensate to what could be a dull, uninspiring experience with a cute message that didn't stick because the road to it was so "meh". Although the game has no voice overs (despite a few heys, yep and "SOUP, SOUP SOUP!"), the dialogues flow smoothly, soon making you feel like you know the pers... no... construct you're talking to.

Gameplay-wise, there's not much on store. First, there is no such thing as full controller support (if you want to play with a controller, that is) as the store page implies. This is actually a [b]partial controller support[/b] where you'll get to use the analog sticks to move the mouse cursor on menus and get XBox controller inputs only during the "fights", making you get used to how 1, 2 and 3 translate on an XBox controller or simply use the keyboard when those item slots are necessary. After the early struggle, you'll soon find that the only interesting thing about the game is its "unique" way to deal with enemies -- which is actually a far more simplistic and fast paced [i]Shadow of the Colossus[/i], but with smaller enemies. Simply put, you jump on their backs and try to cope with a swarm of commands indicating where you can pull flowers, thorns or bombs, carefully not to dry the "grip" matter as that will make you fall off the enemy. With a decent score you get to collect that enemy's unique mask and learn about it. Other than that, running (walking is exclusive to houses), collecting flowers and the few RPG elements are clunky and raw. There was a lot of room for improvement, but clearly the developers wanted to seel a gorgeous game with that one fresh feature that you won't even get to play that much.

Speaking of features, content is another thing [i]Lili: Child of Geos[/i] lacks. There are no puzzles at all, unless the game giving you the answer to stepping on buttons is considered a puzzle now days. For an exploration game with no actual combat, puzzles could make the experience far more enjoyable! The world layout is entertaining, but soon falls flat as the areas are pretty much narrowed corridors without much places to go. No no dear, you cannot jump or swim to anywhere you want to explore -- not that there are many places you think you could jump to anyways. You won't have to work much to get the god-mode items (e.g. the skeleton key and the treasure map), either, so instead of having the slightest hint of challenge on a casual exploration game (because even though it's casual, doesn't mean it can't be challenging), you can just keep running, collecting flowers, kicking vases and collecting flowers from the back of spirits. As for the outfits and hats, considering how short the game is and how useless they are (only there for cosmetics and eventually some lore relevance), there could be a larger variety -- like letting us use the Mario collectable hat as an actual hat instead of hinting on a reference-NPC that doesn't even exist.

[u][b]Pros:[/b][/u]
[list]
    [*] Gorgeous graphics
    [*] Runs smoothly at highest settings on a medium rig
    [*] Interesting designs
    [*] Quirky, funny characters
    [*] Nice music
    [*] Some subtle and funny references to the gaming world
    [*] An exploration game with few RPG elements and a weak focus on flower collecting
[/list]

[u][b]Cons:[/b][/u]
[list]
    [*] Partial controller support instead of full
    [*] Gameplay feels clunky at times
    [*] No puzzles
    [*] The only inovative mechanic is uninteresting and might become a burden if you're not a fast catcher
    [*] There could be more hats
    [*] There could be more pets
    [*] Flowers could be more relevant
    [*] There could be more items and shops
    [*] Some game references feel stupid (if I can call the Portal 2 thing a reference)
    [*] Extremely linear considering what an open world can offer
    [*] Extremely short considering the potential it had (you can clear the game and most of the achievments on a single day, maybe two if you decide to take on the 1000 vases and flowers)
[/list]

All in all, [i]Lili: Child of Geos[/i] is a funny one-time experience with a lot of wasted potential. Gorgeous graphics and funny characters, but poor controller support (considering the developers promised full support), lack of content and short playthrough. Doesn't justify the full price, but worth checking out at a nice discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990598113', 'num_games_owned': 896, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1428365744}
review:
I wasn't expecting to play Lili: Child of Geos for 5 hours straight and beat it in one sitting, but here we are. 

Lili is purly about exploring towns, NPC interaction, and taking down baddies with quick button presses, more akin to Wack-a-Mole then your typical QTE. 
The game is not extremely deep, and I have mixed feelings about the majority of the character designs, but it was a truly enjoyable ride and, if the last few achievements weren't grindfests, I would be putting in the effort to 100% it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002551061', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1428386166}
review:
(mini-review)

(Note: I have over 40 hours of gameplay on the iOS version of this game.).  Lili is a great little puzzle/search game in the stylistic vein of Mario and Zelda.  Very well coded and dripping with consumate cuteness.  The game won't appease shooter fans or players that want zombies and gore but for an indie game, at $10, this game is a gem.  I finished it on iOS, liked the game so much, that I bought a second copy for my PC.  Recommended. 

8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976789959', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1426726019}
review:
A beautiful game.  With artstyle, fedelity, and tone consisitancy; Every thing works.  I don't think i've ever played anything like it, but it reminds me of playing games as a child.

There is the mixed blessing of tone.  It was a great pallet cleanse to a lot of modern gaming, around the general tones of Disney and Pixar.  There is an obvious conflict and the "bad guys" are cruel without reason.  The dicotomy works, but it would take "Game Theory" levels of itching out information to dig the story deeper that "the bad guys are bad because".  Not that I'm oppose to that, I'd be curious.  Also, "Living Constructs" raises certain questions, but nothing in the story cracks that open.

Very minimal combat, and mostly a game of tag that ends in a flower picking minigame.  I certainly think their intended audience was children, with the tone and major gameplay mechanics.

I would certainly recommend this to other game developers.  I beat the game in two sessions (4~5 hours) before completeing a couple cheivos prior to boarding the ending sequence.  I'm curious if the choice moment allowed the other option.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025834191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 228, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1426668952}
review: Lili: Child of Geos is although a port, a splendid game which relies on witty humor, good storytelling and rich environments and characters to keep you engaged. The general gameplay involves talking with the constructs while catching the spirits and playing a flower collecting minigame. The reasoning behind the whole world and the actions of are slowly revealed to the player as they progress and talk with the inhabitants. The game is a relaxing experience and a nice change of pace to what is typical of the market, a full recommendation for this game...oh it also has hats.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042831386', 'num_games_owned': 598, 'num_reviews': 627, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1430937094}
review:
[h1]Short version: 83%[/h1]
A beautiful and violence-free exploration game, which may have carried some of the repetitive tasks too far, but the unique setting, characters, and the seldom-seen game mechanics really make up for it.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
Lili: Child of Geos is hard to categorise. It‚Äôs not an RPG, adventure game or a walking simulator‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs more of an exploration game with heavy emphasis on item collecting (hence why people call it a flower picking simulator). With some adventure elements in the mix, including ‚Äúfights‚Äù, which are actually simple minigames.

Don‚Äôt let the simple gameplay fool you though. Lili is an engaging game about exploring the world of friendly wood constructs and helping them out with their requests. (This usually involves gathering some items or ‚Äúfighting‚Äù an enemy.) It‚Äôs not a community simulator like the Animal Crossing series, but has some similarities, including the same non-violent, relaxing charm.

Technically it was ported from iOS, but the only thing that may give it away is the very simple control scheme; the developer practically remade the whole game for PC, which includes astonishing, yet not intrusive visuals‚Äì all presented by the Unreal 3 engine‚Äì and brand new game elements. It is a version made with love (which sadly doesn‚Äôt extend to provide support for technical issues), and if you start playing it, you will feel that love too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012571768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1422258543}
review:
[h1]Charm in Spades[/h1]

The first thing you'll notice about Lili: Child of Geos is the absolutely stunning visual aspect. The world is rich and vibrant, with colours and structures that are nothing less than a joy to take in; from a crumbled and dilapidated residence to a light and woodsy forest, the visual design of this game is a real treat. 

The next thing that sticks out is the simplicity of it all. Lili runs about collecting flowers as they spring up for use as currency to purchase upgrades which make the main task of the game a bit easier. Essentially, you chase down an enemy, leap onto it, and hold on as you race against your own fading strength to collect a rare flower from it, furthering your progress in the game.

Finally, you'll notice the life in the game. L:CoG has you playing a likeable character amidst a cast of silly and quirky personalities who really bring this world to life. From a heartfelt postman with an odd way of delivering letters to an out-of-place group of spirits bent on destruction, there's so much to discover in the conversations with people alone, even though some of them are more than you bargained for (such as a photographer who stalks you or a woman who serves cannibalistic soup). In some cases, the storytelling can be surprisingly subtle [spoiler](Towards the end of the game, you can see a pair of glasses at the top of a tower, hinting that Lili's father had possibly visited previously)[/spoiler] or even a bit powerful [spoiler](such as the dismantling of your mentor or the creepy and sinister feel of the Mayor.)[/spoiler].

Rife with secrets and easter eggs such as a knockoff Master Sword and an E-tank lying about in a house, my experience was nothing short of satisfying. Lili: Child of Geos harkens back to the late nineties/early aughts, before "collect-a-thon" was a derogatory term. It revives in me a feeling of nostalgia for Spyro and Crash Bandicoot but also the wonder of a new experience, and for all of that, I sing its praises. L:CoG is not a long game, by any means, but it is an experience that I highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007039384', 'num_games_owned': 666, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1410943564}
review:
SALE ONLY GAME.

This game is fun, and it is very polished, BUT it spends way too much time reminding you that it was inspired by better games.

The majority of the 'items' that you collect in the game are unusable, often refences to other games, only visible in your inventory screen, and far more exciting than any of the actual usable items you will receive.

The game is packed with arbitrarily placed invisible walls. Especially the first couple of areas. They've designed and built an exquisite world for this game, and then decided that they don't want you to actually explore it. You can't walk through a lot of bushes, jump on walls, walk down the beach, climb on roofs, or even go down some passageways. I honestly don't understand what the decision process was during this whole thing. Beautiful environment that is begging to have every exquisite inch explored, climbed on, and jumped over, but no you need to walk on the path.

The enemies are unchallenging and repetitive. Not really a bad thing, because you spend so much time doing other stuff, but... well, it is a bad thing. It's definitely a weak point. It's not good. I at first thought that it was because it was targetted at children, but my friends kids (5 and 7) also think the enemies are too easy.

It is crazy short for what you're paying. I cleared it in about 5hrs, and then spent about an hour looking for other, secret, things to do, but didn't find anything.

After all of that, I am recommending it, because I enjoyed playing it. I like this game, and I want them to fix it, make a sequel, and keep making games.

review: I'll admit I didn't get too far in Lili, but the gameplay in the first hour seems too stereotypical of the RPG genre, and the writing comes off as contrived. I was all too aware of the uselessness of the tasks I was performing. It's a pretty game, but no depth so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168114460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1425944990}
review:
This is a more playful and colorful family friendly game, a welcome change from all the grim and hardcore games on the market today. Its more about exploreing then beating up the bad guys so if your looking for a tough chalange then you might be disapointed as even on the hardest seting I blew though it in a few hours and spent the remainer acheavement hunting. There are no lives, no health, if a bad guy throws you off like a bucking bronko then you just dust yourself off and try again. 

The story plays out like an old cartoon, fun but full of holes. The characters are intresting to look at and some of the comments got a giggle but don't look for actual depth behind them, the game is incredable to look at and I could spend all day just looking around enjoying the sights, just wish a game that focused so much on exploreing gave us more to explore. I felt like just when I was geting into it, it was over. 

If your looking for a silly family firendly game to kill a few hours then this is worth checking out as a nice breath of fresh air, though you might want to tone down the settings a bit as its a bit intensive unless you on a gameing system. If you want something tough to test your skills and earn braging rights then look somewhere elce cause this isn't it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073488017', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1425250317}
review:
Finished (including a few little extra things after the credits)! A super cute and relaxing game!

A WARNING about a potential bug (near-end SPOILERS):
Before the final battle with the mayor in Serfside, the background music changes to a scary theme and a red dot appears on the map showing where the mayor is. If instead of fighting him right away, you leave the area and come back, the music goes back to the area's normal theme and the red dot disappears. I couldn't find him in the area so I quit the game and reloaded, and this time the red dot indicating the mayor returned and I could find and battle him!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042222366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1509949013}
review: I know this game has a lot of negative reviews, but I actually really like it. Something about the combination of the music, gorgeous scenery, and hilarious dialogue makes it highly entertaining. Yes, I wish there was a little bit more to do than pick flowers, but when you think about all the video games out there, many of them are very simple. Most importantly, this game makes me feel better when I'm anxious or upset, and I think that makes it worth everything.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042234061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1424486367}
review:
A pesar de que este juego tiene todos los elementos que deber√≠a tener para gustarme, no puedo dejar de considerar que es algo escaso como producto final.

La idea original no es mala en absoluto, aunque est√° poco desarrollada y es tremendamente absurda. Lili, una estudiante, de Vegi-magia necesita recoger flores ex√≥ticas en la isla de geos para su proyecto final. En la isla descubre que las flores crecen en la espalda de unos abusivos y malintencionados espiritus que han implantado un sistema de apartheid oprimiendo a otros seres llamados constructos. As√≠ que Lili tiene la doble tarea de recoger estas flores y libertar a los constructos, saltando a la espalda de los espiritus y arrancandoles flores.

Este "saltar sobre la espalda y arrancar flores" sustituye de forma relativamente pacifica a una resoluci√≥n violenta de conflictos, lo cual es algo original y la din√°mica es divertida y con una dificultad creciente, y aunque en un juego normal solo he fallado una √∫nica vez a la hora de intentarlo, tiene cierta complicaci√≥n conseguirlo perfectamente a la primera en cada espiritu. 

Graficamente es muy colorista y suave, me recuerda al majora's mask, con lo que estoy encantado con este apartado. 

Mis pegas se centrar√≠an sobre todo en el hecho de que es un juego tremendamente corto y no excesivamente complicado. Solo unas 4 horas de juego para conseguir todas las busquedas y un sistema de logros que te invita a recolectar objetos sin parar cuando no hay absolutamente ninguna complicaci√≥n para encontrarlos. Se echa en falta algo m√°s de diversidad en las din√°micas de juego, lo de arrancar flores de los espiritus se queda algo soso enseguida, podr√≠an haber implementado otras formas de luchar contra los espiritus sin necesidad de recurrir a la violencia, pero que aportasen alguna variaci√≥n. En definitiva, el juego carece de complicaci√≥nes imprevistas lo que quiz√°s, a√±adido a sus graficos coloristas sugerir√≠an un target infantil, ¬øcierto? error, y en eso se basa mi segunda queja.

Lili est√° -en mi opinion- sobresexualizada. El juego hace dolorsamente obvio que no es una ni√±a a pesar de su aspecto ani√±ado y hay momentos (escasos, aunque bastante incomodos) en los que se alude implicitamente a su atractivo fisico como intentando vender el personaje como una "waifu" o amor platonico para jugadores masculinos (o mujeres gays si os gustan lo videojuegos, gui√±o, gui√±o). No os tomeis est√° acusaci√≥n como criterio para jugar o no el juego ya que se basa completamente en mis sensaciones, pero s√≠ que diria que "Lili: Child of Geos" se ha dise√±ado con un publico adulto en mente por estas razones, y el juego es, como he dicho antes, un pel√≠n demasiado simple para un p√∫blico adulto.

Est√° en ingl√©s, lo cual es una pega si es que eso te supone un impedimento.

review: This game makes for a fun distraction between serious games. It's funny, charming and pretty easy, players looking for a challenge might want to start at Hard difficulty. This is also great for kids or for kids and adults to play together - it's balanced well enough and is entertaining for all ages. Gameplay can get repetitive but the game is short enough so it doesn't really become a problem.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994442752', 'num_games_owned': 2371, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1424065155}
review: It's a cute little game. You run around a fairly small island completing simple fetch and exploration quests.  As you explore you will regularly play a simple low-violence combat mini game to defeat your enemies on the island.  The games biggest strengths are its colorful graphics, pleasant music, and chuckleworthy sense of humor.  It's a relaxing easy game that doesn't outstay its welcome.  If you never play it you wont be missing an all time classic, but I had fun in the 4.5 hours it took me to get 100% on this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066511137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1480314152}
review:
Great Relaxing game, not a huge story line and rather easy... everything.

There is really no action and the upgrades are almost useless (Except the run speed)

You can get a skeleton key right off the bat which makes the key vendor useless (I got the skeleton key before i found the key vendor.

Great game. i do suggest you get it if you want to play a simple relaxing game as the Grahpics are amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136516068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1602437757}

author: {'steamid': '76561198062713417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1493363301}
review:
Pros:
-Friendly for ALL ages (including adults...trust me!)
-Gorgeous Graphics and environment
-Unique combat (picking flowers)
-Achievements + Cards!
-Emmersive! 
-Adorable characters and dialogue which actually made me laugh at some points

Cons:
-Very easy
-At some points it can be repetitive 
-Very Casual (Might be a pro for you but for me it was a con, however it was still very enjoyable!)
-Unecessary stealth components which a lot of games seem to be adding almost as an afterthought

SPOILERS:





Do not buy invisibility potions or anything stealth
Only upgrade speed
You can even use the sandwiches to get past the guards (what you needed the potions for)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970379758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1423342905}
review:
I think it's best to think of this game as one meant for kids. That's not a bad thing. In fact, I'm glad that kids these days can be introduced to gaming with such charming experiences.
That being said, "Lili" isn't exactly non-violent. While the most brutal thing you do is pluck a flower from a tree creature's back, there's a strong sense that the confrontations are very personal. The tree creatures end up being humilliated, though not mutilated.

"Lili" is charming, pretty, and, surprisingly, funny. The humour here works, in large part because the writer wasn't trying too hard. It's exactly the kind of slightly absurdist affair with affinity for randomness that I remember enjoying a lot back when I was 15.

What "Lili" is not is a deep game. The environments are pretty, but they're not "explorable", in the sense that you can look behind a corner and sometimes even find some secret stash, but you won't find this activity very compelling. There's no emergent narrative to it. The game's main collectible and currency, namely flowers, feels like a wasted opportunity. There's only one variety of flower and you never need to do anything specific in order to find them, because they just grow everywhere. I was kind of hoping that I was going to build a collection of unique specimens, but that's not the case.

I played this game with mouse and keyboard, and in this configuration it's more difficult than it would be on a tablet. During encounters with the tree creatures, the ones that have flowers growing from their backs, plucking a flower requires a mouse gesture rather than a click. This is fine on its own, but mouse gestures are slower and more awkward than their touch screen counterparts, and the timing doesn't seem to have been adjusted. As a result the minigame feels more difficult than it should be.

review: Relaxing & cute :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197998504206', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 965, 'last_played': 1424529128}
review:
Do you love finding every chest, opening every lock, and breaking every vase in a game, the more the better? Try Lili, then--it's chock full of all of those!

I find Lili a relaxing break: gentle music, lush scenery, and really, really strange characters and dialogue. I have trouble turning off the game, not because I want to beat one more monster, but because I want to talk to one more character to see whether there's another weird things to hear. (Though they really could use a good copy editor.)

Lili is up at the top of the list of my favorite casual games. I'm keeping it around for grumpy days to lighten my mood.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970329288', 'num_games_owned': 2788, 'num_reviews': 1451, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1422518562}
review:
Lili is a quirky adventure RPG hybrid with stunning visuals, silky-smooth graphics, a cinematic story-line, and a fresh new way to deal with enemies. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o_hTIPEU9Eg
On the mysterious island of Geos, Lili will meet a number of hilarious locals, explore beautiful environments, solve some puzzles, and even challenge an oppressive regime or two along her way. If you've enjoyed Zelda, Broken Age, or Psychonauts come on an adventure with Lili! And if you have never played any of those games, come with us on a journey which will make your sides ache with laughter, where you will get to know and love Lili, and maybe even shed a tear or two. - Recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561197962402602', 'num_games_owned': 2596, 'num_reviews': 361, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1423638639}
review: Pick flowers and do lame QTE fights. The art style is gorgeous, but the game still isn't fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025680527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1423673820}
review:
Fun game. Child friendly, grandparent friendly, Zelda fan friendly. Entertaining, even during the first five minutes. Quirky characters that kept making me smile.

So many games try to hard and fail to capture the charm that this game has. This one pulls it off without feeling like baby's first adventure game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056282033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1423445667}
review:
To be honest, I expected a lot less from a casual game like this, but I was surprised.
It's really fun, follows an interesting story-line and I don't even have to tell you, the artwork on this is beautiful.
Not to mention, the witty, cute references, dialogue between characters makes this game hilarious.
If this game is on sale, I'd recommend picking it up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042346128', 'num_games_owned': 688, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1423347735}
review: The game looked a little Ehhh at first. When I first joined, I was just amazed! The Graphics are amazing, the smoothness of everything just really catches my eye. Don't get me started on the voices, and sounds you hear inside the game. I love the music that's constantly playing :) I have not gotten far in the game, Nor do I understand the story line that well. I do not like to read the long texts. Maybe add Voice Narration for all the text? Also would love if you could play this game in windowed mode. Other then that, 10/10 for a Single player game like this. Amazing, I do recommend to all my friends :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025065576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1422961065}
review:
There's a lot going on in Lili: Child of Geos.  Too much to slap you with a witty pair of sentences and run away giggling.  So here's some proper paragraphs for you kids as I lead you on a bold coming-of-age adventure where you learn to part with three to five of your dollars but no more than that; an adventure where you learn if great art direction with a bit of humor can make up for some flawed gameplay and a very basic story:

You will take control of Lili: a young crossdressing botanist with daddy issues on a quest to "deflower" a population of anthropomorphic gardens.  Okay, okay.  That is only technically true, you cheeky reviewer, you.  It's a very inclusive, cheerfully bright, and quite original game, although the daddy issues still stand.  And in fact they stand in the way of me giving this game an unqualified recommendation.  

I'm talking not about Lili the character, but the game itself.  It is so proud of its roots that it spends too much time placing them on display rather than nurturing its uniqueness to blossom into a memorable classic.  Lili brings a lot to the table, but what's ultimately going to keep you playing (or not) are its story, characters, and setting.  Lili: CoG tries to follow the likes of games like Monkey Island by having a story-focused game supported by a strong sense of humor.  The story itself is unchallenging, boiling down to: bad guys are bad guys and it's up to you to put things right.  Bless it, it tries to do more by giving Lili a personal dilemma that comes into conflict with her objectives, but when it comes time for her to choose, there's really no consequence to the choice you make.  Although, I guess we can hand out a gold star for at least letting the player make a choice.   

Okay, so the story is middling, what does this have to do with that whole roots/blossoming/flower-metaphors-for-a-game-about-flowers  line you were banging on about?  Well, presumably if the story is lacking, it could be supported by its humor.  And the game has some wonderfully funny moments.  Unfortunately, you might just stop playing before you ever get to them.  A lot of the jokes in the first areas of the game you explore take the form of references to other games and the games industry, and praise toward the games that inspired Lili.  And, as many of us know, references aren't really jokes, especially since you have to have a pretty broad knowledge of games to appreciate most of them.  I did get a grin or two out of these, but it wasn't until the second half of the game when the earnest chuckles came; when Lili started being Lili instead of her various daddies' girl.

I know anybody reading the length of this review is probably ready with their metaphorical throwing produce if I don't get to talking about the gameplay soon, but this is a very hippy-dippy, rainbow colored, mostly non-violent, interactive experience and there's a bit more to be said.  This game.  Is.  Beautiful.  No, really, it is.  The birds even poop rainbows!!!  It could sell itself alone on its art direction (it's a shame it comes a bit too close to doing that).  Without an army of artists and polygons, Lili creates a vivid, bright, painterly world that is going to stay good looking for decades.  The environments feel very open, engaging, and wholely Lili's own.  Lili is a realistically proportioned human exploring a luminous world populated by wooden robots and grim-looking masked spirits none of which are short on personality.  It's got a bit of a Miyazaki vibe to it, but it's ultimately Lili's own world, and it's truly charming.  

Right, gameplay.  In Lili, you chase down spirits, jump onto their backs, and try to yank off the flowers that sprout up with your mouse, while avoiding hazards that threaten to knock you off and let the spirit escape: interesting, arcadey, surprisingly challenging as the difficulty ramps up.  It's refreshingly different from many other adventure/action/RPG hybrids that will mostly have you swinging a sword around at the things you want maimed.  It isn't quite perfect, though.  It works okay with mouse controls, but does feel imprecise at times and can get a bit frustrating when the things you want appear in dense clusters of hazards.  It seems designed with touch screens in mind, but I only used the mouse, so I can't comment on that implementation.  

The RPG elements, especially, seem misguided.  Upgrades are handed out at odd intervals and never seem essential, especially with items providing boosts that don't so much compliment your skills in running fast, stealth, and hanging onto enemies, as render them completely irrelevant.  The increments from leveling up and getting items aren't entirely unnoticeable, but the RPG elements could have gotten cut and nothing would have been lost.  In fact, the stealth aspect to the game is really non-existant.  You won't have to worry about things like which way the enemy is facing, what cover you place yourself behind, or the amount of lighting on you.  Stealth is merely a stat that determines how close you can get before the enemy automatically notices you.  If stealth games really turn you on, as they do me, just know that this isn't a stealth game, but a perfectly fine arcadey affair.  And, you know, you can just have a stealth-sandwhich and be invisible, so why the stats at all? 

I'll admit, I only played the game on normal difficulty.  The game does have easy and hard settings, but as an adult with adequate reflexes, I found Lili to be fairly easy to get through, but challenging to get through well (you are scored for each enemy you face and given a small reward in the form of a mask for doing well).  I'd say that makes it ideal, but then, I'm not sure exactly who this game was made for.  The simple saccharine story and visuals make it seem like a casual game for parents to play with their children, though I think even with an easy setting, reflex challenges might prove inherently difficult for younger kids.  But if it's just meant to appeal to the children of the 90s, now present day indie gamers, the difficulty is on the ball in terms of gameplay.  That audience will probably find the story a bit too easy, however (unless you want to get meta and compare Lili - the character's - struggle living in her father's shadow to Lili - the game's - struggle to emerge from the shadow of monumental games like a terribly clever gamer whose review will be super influential).

So who is Lili for?  Well, me, I guess.  I mostly enjoyed it and I recommend it if you think the strengths I've just beamed into your head outweigh the bits that are mediocre - and those bits are just mediocre, never really bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019202086', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1409106819}
review: This is a fun little game. Most games these days have high stakes and higher body counts. And that's great, but Lili gives you the opportunity to stop and pick some flowers. Along the way, you'll explore an island full of quirky characters, colorful environments, and pots to break. So just relax, take in the scenery, and chase after some spirits.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990059591', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1422938318}
review: Its a good looking game made in UE4. Its a great time killer. I got it for $2.99 and I feel it was a great deal for this game. I wouldn't tell anyone to buy it for its full price of $19.99. The whole point of the game is to use this little hipster chick to find flowers.  The start and ending were very weak in my opinion but I feel the look of the game made up for the lack of content. Can't wait for more indie games to come out through UE4 after seeing how good looking this game is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096103033', 'num_games_owned': 646, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1510049115}
review:
This game is right on the price that it is worth but you should really take the time to relax while playing this game. 
It is a very colorful are open game and great graphics and visuals. It is a great breathtaking game , now the story is short and sweet and has a nice feeling tone to it not much of it to be honest. The camera controlls are great controller works dandy and the only thing I can complain about are two little things. One the voice acting , there is none just text speach followed by a voice of that person. Well if you already made that person make a noise or say "Hay" followed by a few other voice commands why not just finish up the whole dam thing. I mean that game is shorter than the chat dialogs so there were some loss of effort that is clear to see. Now last the music , very well put in and done , but there is only one whole song set into this game. Either that or I cannot tell because they are more same sounding than nickleback. Seriously I wish this game had diffrent tone settings on music and it lasted more than 10 mins Its like hearing your favorite bands most played to songs over and over a few times. You're not sick of it , but....CHANGE it. 

Over all I give a good 6/10 would get pooped on by colorfull birds again trying to pick flowers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975183383', 'num_games_owned': 587, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1422985115}
review:
"Lili: Child of Geos" es una aventura sencilla, inocente y agradable, apta para todos los publicos. Con un acabado gr√°fico muy bonito y colorido, unos personajes bastante curiosos y una buena banda sonora, el juego nos invita a recorrer junto a Lili, una estudiante de bot√°nica, la extra√±a isla de Geos, desentra√±ar sus misterios y ayudar a sus habitantes, los Constructos, frente a sus creadores, los Esp√≠ritus.

El juego es una aventura en tercera persona. En √©l, tomamos el control de una adolescente llamada Lili, la cual toma tierra con su bote en la isla de Geos. Lili es estudiante de bot√°nica, y ha venido a la isla a estudiar las extra√±as flores que crecen en ella. Pero cual es su sorpresa cuando, al llegar, se empieza a encontrar con unas criaturas de lo mas extra√±as, formadas por madera y piedra, que se hacen llamar Constructos. Al parecer, en la isla moran unos seres llamados Esp√≠ritus, los cuales crearon a los Constructos para hacerles las tareas mas pesadas. Lo malo es que los Esp√≠ritus tratan a los Constructos muy mal, y ah√≠ es donde Lili, sin comerlo ni beberlo, se ve encumbrada como la liberadora de los Constructos del yugo de sus creadores.

Para ello, el juego cuenta con 4 zonas diferenciadas en las hay muchos personajes por conocer, misiones por hacer y secretos que encontrar. A lo largo del juego, adem√°s, nos ir√°n apareciendo Esp√≠titus a los que hay que ir derrotando mediante pulso y habilidad.

No hay sangre en este juego, ni muertes, ni acci√≥n explosiva. "Lili" es un juego tranquilo y ameno, un cuento, en el que lo que cuenta es disfrutar de sus paisajes y de su banda sonora, y dejarse llevar. No es un Zelda, o un Tomb Raider. No espereis grandes puzzles, terribles secretos o temibles enemigos. "Lili" es un juego sencillo para evadirse un rato de los malos rollos del mundo. Y punto.

La unica pega que le puedo ver es que no est√© traducido al espa√±ol. Para darle mas duraci√≥n, han metido bastantes logros. Y dentro del juego hay varias cosas que hacer que llevar√°n su tiempo, como consegir vencer a todos los esp√≠tius con 3 estrellas, encontrar todos los cofres ocultos o, los mas pesados, recoger 1000 flores o romper 1000 vasijas.

Quizas su precio sea algo elevado para lo que puede ofrecer a los jugadores habituales de PC, ya que apenas presentar√° grandes retos salvo acabar la aventura y poco mas. Con una rebaja, lo recomiendo, sobre todo para gente a la que le guste las aventuras sin complicaciones, lo quieran para sus hijos, o quieran olvidarse de la violencia gratuita por un rato.

Y bueno...  Lili es adorable...  que le vamos a hacer.

Valoraci√≥n: 6,5 / 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198128707759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1423441307}

author: {'steamid': '76561198173842847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1422783851}
review: For a game that first appeared on IOS this is  a great port. Seriously it is. The main selling point for this game is collecting. Thats it, just collecting.  You collect items like hats, various other cosmetics and flowers. thats it. But it never gets boring. even when u pick flowers off the Spirits that never gets boring. This game is pure fun. I never got bored playing it. Not once. I cannot recommend this game enough. Get it while its still on sale. I promise you will not regret it. I give  a well deserved 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094376847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1420031265}
review: This was a fun game - it was bright and colourful with enjoyable and vibrant (but not intrusive) music. I liked the gameplay and the story. It was well constructed and timed (I don't know if you could have extended the existing premise any further). It makes for a fun afternoon of gaming and is definitely replayable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171117306', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1423711912}
review:
Wow, what a fantastic game. 

Pros: 
-Stunning Graphics
-Easy to use and fun game play once you get used to it (I used a controller)
-Great interactions
-Original Background, characters, and storyline

Cons:
-Initial controller adjustments(Starting the game, the controls felt wonky but very easy to adjust to)
-Game Length (All the hours you see here are how long it took to beat the game. I also play like a scavanger so im collecting as much as i can)


All in all, this game was so much fun to the point i was scowering the internet for a sequal. If you have a sick day from work (like i had) or some time off, take a few hours and beat this game. Well worth the money.

PS: If you are strictly a action/hack and slash player, this is not the game for you. This game is all about adventure and discovery.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045805308', 'num_games_owned': 147, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1422959766}
review:
[b]TL; DR -Cute game adapted from mobile but not worth the price of admission. [/b]
[url=https://draconicrosegaming.wixsite.com/website/single-post/2018/07/12/Lilli-Child-of-Geos---Draconicrose-Reviews]Read the polished review.[/url]

[h1]Story[/h1]
You follow Lili on an expedition where she ends up on a misterious island ruled by an evil mayor. PRetty standard child fantasy fare.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Graphics are the best part of Lili Child of Geos. They're gorgeous cartoony graphics and make this a nice game to take some screenshots.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Gameplay is pretty easy though it's obviously meant to be a tap game, especially when you're on the back of boss creatures. You mostly explore and grab collectibles otherwise. The menus are awkward to use and the controls were clearly adapted at the last minute, making them clunky. 

[h1]Sound[/h1]
Nothing to write home about but the voice acting is kinda cute.

[h1]Other[/h1]
The game is packed with multiple geeky references which give the player a cheeky wink. We both know you'd rather be playing those other games. There is also no tutorial telling you how to play the game so hope you can find it out on your own.

[h1]Score[/h1]
[b]3/5 - Mediocre[/b]

review:
This game is cute and very beautiful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002864416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1422633074}
review:
Lili is a sweet and enjoyable little family game, hampered by a lack of polish and a rather threadbare plot.

You play Lili, of course, a young student who arrives on a thought-to-be deserted island in search of flowers.  Once there, you discover that a race of beings called Constructs are working as slaves for vicious little critters called Spirits.  Naturally, you'll battle the Spirits, free the Constructs, do a little soul-searching, and save the day.

The gameplay is charming, but fairly limited.  You'll walk around, talk to people, do fetch quests, and fight Spirits in what are essentially QTE mini-games.  You jump on their backs and pluck all of their flowers out, avoiding thorns and shedding bombs as you go.  Defeated Spirits merely run off in a huff; everything is very non-violent and kid appropriate.  There's also a gambling mini-game that is fun for a few spins.

Sadly, there isn't much story to tie it all together.  It's clear that the evil Mayor will be the Big Bad from the get-go, so not much mystery there.  Lili's only real drama is whether or not to abandon the Constructs to turn in her project on time, and I doubt anyone will be very confounded on which path to choose.  Lili will also exchange letters with her professor that hint at some deeper family trauma at play, but it's only brought up at the very end of the game and nothing much is said of it.  Exploring that a little further might have added some real heart to the game and made it feel a bit more substantial.

Of course, many of the game's shortcomings can be traced to its origins as a smartphone app, with an emphasis on sharp graphics and simplistic gameplay.  Make no mistake, the game is quite beautiful, but the transition from app to Steam product was less than ideal.  The game feels a bit unpolished all over, and the achievements are a total mess - some are bugged, others pop up erroneously, and many are tedious grinds which are completely inessential to clearing the game.  The game was perfectly playable on my end and didn't crash, but the whole thing felt rushed.

And yet, with all that said, I'll give the game a mild thumbs up.  It's nice to see a family appropriate game on Steam, especially with a female protagonist.  It looks great, has pleasant tunes, and the writing can be quite funny in places.  You can tell that the adult writers were slipping in a ton of gags to either amuse themselves or any parents nearby.  It all goes down easy and most people will get a few hours of fun out of it.  That said, I got the game for 85% off - I wouldn't pay anything close to the base price of $20 for it.  Something in the $5 range is more appropriate.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989581142', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1409309648}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999453540', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1529834205}
review:
TL;DR: Everything about Lili: Child of Geos is a pleasant surprise. (Well, almost everything.)

But seriously, I'm not sure where to begin. The game is gorgeous, for starters. Don't be deterred by the fact that it was previously a mobile iOS game -- Lili: Child of Geos is a complete overhaul, and even playing on the lowest graphical setting I found myself just looking around in awe half the time. Everything about Lili's world is memorable, from the world design to the characters. There's a lot of wonderful dialogue and description text, and finding all of it feels like its own reward.

The gameplay is light, but clever. While exploring the world, you kick vases, pick flowers, and open chests, but more importantly, you chase down jerkface spirits so you can leap on their backs, yank out all their spirit flowers, and wear their masks in mockery. The whole thing is oddly relaxing and occasionally reminiscent of Fruit Ninja. But it was also the place that, for me, the controls fell down a bit, None of the control schemes available felt all that functional to me. On some spirits I'd effortlessly pick all the necessary flowers in a few seconds, but on others I found myself desperately grabbing at the same flower over and over, my clicks never connecting. I should also note that achievements seem buggy; I was occasionally awarded achievements I didn't actually earn.

But all in all, I adored the game world and the characters, and I really liked the innovative approach to dealing with enemies! Lili: Child of Geos oozes personality, and it's a game that I'm sure I'll keep coming back to for a good laugh.

review: Now this may seem like a silly little game but its actually really fun and interesting. So lots of people say its "just picking flowers and breaking pots", which is slightly true hah, but once playing it its really fun! You go around on a task and visit different places on the island of geos. You also talk to harmless little constructs and fight these things called spirits. How you fight is by picking off the spirits "life" flower. The spirits also throw bombs at you that are very very annoying. But overall its a very interesting and fun game. Graphics are nice, Design is quite well. Worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994012228', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1422452648}
review: Lili: Child of Geos is a great little adventure and when on sale is definitely worth a pick up. The locals are interesting and quirky and the game puts you in a fun little zen like state trying to find secret items and chests to unlock. The only thing I have a problem with is it's a short game. Three hours long if you take your time and the game can get repititive quickly. But, it's the atmosphere and fun situations that make the game really worth it. Check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112928489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1425720308}
review:
I can recommend this game really much.

Bad Points first tho: the actual Story is pretty short. After 4H of playing I have completed the main story and unlocked every Item, got 3 stars on every enemy and completed every single side-quest.

Now going on with the good points: I love the aesthetics; not too realistic with a little cartoony, handdrawn look to it. Some good athmospheric light effects as well as good shader technology. The map is really well designed, with love to every detail. Also the character models are always unique characters, with effort and creativity put into everyone (except the Spirits, they always look the same, just the Mask differs), while you gotta say that those squeaky voices got a littly annoying after a while. Also the main character, Lili, has a well thought-out character and a athmosphere fitting look. The gameplay mechanics are also something new and nice to experience aswell as easy to learn. I've got to mention the native controller support the developers have put into the game (It's often overlooked by indie studios) is also a good job and easy to work with. Aside from all this, even the dialogues are written incredibly well and are always fitting, sometimes funny, and very entertaining ( some spelling issues in items' descriptions :/ ).

Especially on sale, totally worth its money.

Before you go, always remember that there are TONS of video Game references or direct Links in the whole game. Try to find and understand them all!

"It's dangerous to buy games alone! Take this review!"  ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198041949592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 605, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1492818370}
review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is an adventure game.



[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

Has 3 different profile slots.
Options is in-game.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

You are playing as a girl who is stranded on a beach and you are trying to find a way to get off the beach. Quickly you will realize there is something else going on and ofcourse you will be the one that has to fix it. The game has alot of walking, talking and exploring. There are some "evil" spirits around and managing to defeat those will grant you stats boost. The game has alot of collectables and a large numbers


You can play fullscreen or windowed mode
Has difficulty settings.
Able to toggle the music.
You are able to toggle Invert Y and X,
You have a mini-map at the bottom corner and abigger map at the bottom bar if you press ESC.
Mini map is shown with interactions.
Nice graphics but weird animations.
The game has alot of collectables.
Music is meh.
Game feels a boring.

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

Game is for kids?

-------------------

I Give this game a 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198001490367', 'num_games_owned': 650, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 460, 'last_played': 1422512710}
review:
Relax ,Fun exploration, and Fantastic atmosphere.

You play as young botanist named Lili who is sent to discover Geos island as a part of her student project.
The game is about exploration and meeting. As you progress the storyline, you will discover more friendly woodman, Spirit as enemy. and collectables in different and charming area. I've to say I really love level designs and characters.
Sure, it's mobile port which I expect simple mechanism. Chasing and play minigame as main combat. picking flowers, explore and complete side quests. character customization, soft RPG elements, and fun dialogue (A lot of references from other games).

However, the control feels quite delay and a bit clunky. And combat parts work like repetitive minigame.
But I've to say it's really relaxing and very enjoy experience for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134013654', 'num_games_owned': 307, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1422432266}
review:
+ Simpatico e non impegnativo, dalla grafica accattivante e molto curata che associo ad i Legend of Zelda su Nintendo Wii (quello, oltre all'abitudine dei costrutti di nascondere denaro in vasi sparsi ovunque).

- Musiche ripetitive e controlli non sempre agevoli. La trama √® un mero pretesto. Fin troppo breve considerando le potenziali risorse a disposizione (il mondo di gioco, personaggi, quest secondarie, etc.).

7/10, consigliato se in saldo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061348853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1642877263}
review:
Avec sa jolie ambiance √† la Mario Sunshine, ce splendide jeu d'aventure saura s√©duire tous les publics. Plein d'humour, de r√©f√©rences et d'agr√©ables musiques dans un style assez FF, il met toutes les chances de son c√¥t√© pour plaire au joueur.

Je suis habituellement tr√®s nulle √† ce genre de jeux, soyons honn√™te, mais la possibilit√© de choisir son niveau (j'ai pris le mode "facile") m'a permis de passer un tr√®s bon moment (environ 12h de jeu) sans m√™me me prendre la t√™te.

Les points forts : 
[list]
[*]les beaux graphismes color√©s, 
[*]la grande rotation de l'angle de "cam√©ra" avec des petits d√©tails comme l'effet de "flare" sur l'objectif, 
[*]la libert√© d'acc√®s √† l'ensemble de la map au fil du jeu
[*]l'humour et la gaiet√©
[*]une histoire simple mais suffisante pour la coh√©sion du jeu
[*]des succ√®s coh√©rents avec l'avancement de la partie
[/list]

Quelques petits points n√©gatifs malgr√© tout : un peu lourd √† faire tourner en r√©solution maximale, uniquement en anglais, des box de dialogues plut√¥t √©normes et pas de doublage. Rien qui ne g√™ne le gameplay mais qui aurait pu faire de Lili Child of Geos un jeu impeccable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022165765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1422537538}
review: Beautiful little game. Excellent for when you need to relax. It has the graphics and atmosphere of a Double Fine game, combined with the soothing grind of gathering in an MMO. Not for everyone, but incredible for the ones that appreciate these things.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971064955', 'num_games_owned': 1231, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1422311248}
review:
Pretty, and I'm a sucker for a game with non-male protagonists.

But, Lili really goes out of its way to perpetuate crappy gender stereotyping. For something that's clearly aimed at a kids' market, having dialogue that touches on non-human spirit entities that are "female" caring about their weight and appearance is, to put it mildly, gross.

Do not recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997194818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 1399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1097, 'last_played': 1535046633}
review:
This is a mobile port done right. From start to finish, Lili: Child of Geos is a blast. Memorable characters, quirky design, and a fantastic environment make this casual game worth playing. The shift of focus from "combat" to the chase is quite welcome, and dialogues with the different characters you encounter were surprisingly amusing. The weakest part of the port was disappointingly with its implementation of Steam Achievements, one of which is broken, and of the others that there are simply too many mindless ones (do [i]X, Y[/i] times).

My biggest complaint is with its ridiculous $20 price tag (the mobile version costs $2.99); although the developers have indeed done a great deal to enhance the PC experience, over 600% mark-up is unacceptable. It's on sale frequently enough that [b]my rating reflects a sale price,[/b] as it would be lower by several points at full price.

7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960478145', 'num_games_owned': 2351, 'num_reviews': 616, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1417365605}
review: A little exploration there, a little charm here and the combat is actually interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977060919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1421686503}
review:
Fun, Light hearted, Short, and has amazing graphics. I recommend.

Has a lot of gaming references like mario, zelda, portal 2, ect for some reason.

This is not an "Action game" so don't expect any fightings or combat of any kind.

Was expecting some kind of intro cinimatic (or an intro of any kind) but didn't get one was just plopped into the game. Also was expecting some kind of ending cinimatic or scene but there wasn't one either. Bug maybe? I restarted a few times didn't get intro scene or anything. Beat the game twice with same playthrough somehow. Didn't get an ending scene? Just some credits.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970262379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1421714945}
review:
Your character is a vandal masquerading as a garrulous student on an ecologically sensitive island.  The majority of the gameplay consists of running around kicking over vases, stealing flowers, breaking into peoples homes and assaulting NPC's from behind.  The anti-slavery storyline (however thin) is to be applauded, but the sub-plot involving a stalker is problematic.  Those with an addictive personality may want to steer clear of the gambling mini-game.

No technical issues other than an overly narrow FOV and lack of fine grained settings for graphics (the depth of field effect can get annoying).

author: {'steamid': '76561198044155024', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1421181523}
review: A really lovely game. Something seemed oddly familiar about the whole thing, but it was somehow nostalgic and original at once. The island is a really beautiful place, pretty, and plenty to explore, with a great soundtrack to match, really cute. The characters were just as charming. This was a really fun game worth a few hours of gameplay and I really recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975628345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1421108905}
