author: {'steamid': '76561198086276748', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1429653781}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is a very peculiar and unique game. It is a game that children and adults (channel your inner child adults!) can play and enjoy.
[u]Graphics[/u]: When the graphics are set on 'Fantastic', which is the highest value, the game is gorgeous. The view of the island itself is magnificent and the lighting in-game makes the entire game seem somehow enchanted and magical.
[u]Storyline[/u]: The storyline is pretty simplistic and one should not expect a complex and in-depth storyline from this game. The plot itself is that you are Lili, a botanist and student sent to the supposedly 'uninhabited' island of Geos to collect samples of flowers to bring back home for your research project. However, you find that the island is not empty and that there are creatures (constructs and spirits and many others) of a different variety. 
[u]Gameplay[/u]: As you read in the upper section that Lili is a botanist, you may assume that you will pick flowers throughout the game. Yes, you are correct! You will be picking countless of flowers, breaking vases, talking to goofy individuals, scaring birds, finding items, and fighting spirits (yes, you will pick the flowers off of their backs!). You should not expect a hack-and-slash style or a difficult puzzle from this game.
[u]Humor[/u]: This game is hilarious. If you actually take your time (like I did) and talk to everyone and read everything, it turns out that our heroine is a gamer! And there are Zelda and Super Mario references (and many more) throughout the game as well as things and topics that would be considered 'inappropriate' are slightly implied so that if your children are playing it, they will not understand. If you are playing it (an adult), you will laugh your butt off!

Overall, I truly enjoyed this game. No, it is not difficult but it is hilarious. It is a relatively short game (I would say approximately 3-5 hours if you don't take time to look at anything, read anything at all, explore, or do side quests), and the only reason I have 9 hours game-time is because I wanted to receive every single achievement (and I also kept going afk while in-game). This game is a good way to unwind after playing a scary game or having a bad day. The hilarity of this game is what kept me coming back!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035595036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1421035074}
review: Lili is a short, colorful, whimsical game. The graphics are wonderful, but there's no audio which is kind of a downer considering how little dialogue there is. The gameplay gets repetitive real fast, so I suggest completing the side quests and not worrying about the spirits. In 4 hours, you can fully beat the game and side quests, but I think you can rush it in 2 hours. I recommend it for children or gamers looking for a cheery, nonviolent filler (on Steam sale).

author: {'steamid': '76561198042838346', 'num_games_owned': 5512, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1421016562}
review:
Une chose est ind√©niable, Lili: Child of Geos est un tr√®s beau jeu. Les d√©cors sont idylliques et on a plaisir √† d√©couvrir l'√Æle, malheureusement je n'ai pas accroch√© autant que je l'aurai esp√©r√©. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=373788118 Premi√®rement le jeu commence tr√®s abruptement, sans aucune cin√©matique pour se mettre dans l'ambiance alors qu'il y aurait eu de quoi en mettre plein les yeux d√®s le d√©part. Ensuite premi√®re difficult√© : les contr√¥les. La jouabilit√© n'est pas g√©niale car les touches ne sont pas reconfigurables et sont faites pour un clavier QWERTY. Le support manette n'est quant √† lui que partiel et il faudra tout de m√™me utiliser le clavier pour l'inventaire ou pour ouvrir le menu.

Pass√© ces probl√®mes de d√©part le manque de doublage nuit √† l'immersion qui est tout de m√™me importante dans un tel jeu, apr√®s je comprends que c'est un jeu ind√©pendant qui n'a pas forc√©ment les moyens de faire appel √† un prestataire externe pour r√©aliser les voix de son jeu.

Le sc√©nario est simple et lin√©aire : dans le r√¥le de Lili on s'aventure sur Geos afin de remplir un devoir de fin d'√©tudes sur les fleurs de l'√Æle. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=373786837 On rencontre alors des √™tres faits de bois appel√©s les "Constructs" qui ont √©t√© cr√©√©s par les Spirits afin de les servir. Compatissante √† leur cause, Lili va tenter de mettre un terme au r√®gne des Spirits en affrontant le puissant Maire avec l'aide de son entraineur. 

Au niveau du gameplay on passe beaucoup de temps √† ramasser des items et je me suis vite ennuy√©e parce que cela semblait √™tre le c≈ìur du jeu. Du coup on se balade et on ramasse des choses sans trop savoir pourquoi et on reste distant par rapport √† l'histoire et des personnages. On peut acheter des tenues ou trouver des chapeaux et des compagnons mais rien qui n'ai un int√©r√™t autre qu'esth√©tique. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=373788289 Je ne suis pas √† la recherche d'action √† tout prix mais un peu plus de qu√™tes et surtout des qu√™tes plus int√©ressantes aurait √©t√© un plus.

Les "combats" √† base de QTE sont assez simples et c'est l√† qu'est le probl√®me : tout au long du jeu on arrive √† vaincre les Spirits sans trop de difficult√© et √† la fin le Maire est extr√™mement dur √† battre ! Je dirai que c'est mal dos√© √† ce niveau l√†...

Aussi, le bouton qui sert √† tout est assez frustrant, combien de fois ai-je poursuivi un Spirit pour finalement ramasser une fleur ou parler √† un personnage au moment o√π j'allais l'attraper.

Pour r√©sumer c'est un jeu sympathique mais je m'attendais √† un univers plus riche et plus immersif, je suis un peu d√©√ßue mais j'ai tout de m√™me appr√©ci√© le jeu.

[quote]Lisez d'autres avis sur ma page de curation : [b][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9002662/]Kitsune's Guide[/url][/b][/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198024443754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1421099552}
review:
Anyone who recommends this game to Zelda fans should be told to shut up and play a Zelda game. Pretty graphics and interesting NPCs with witty dialog does not a Zelda make.

It's not even a matter of lack of combat. Anyone praising or bashing this game for that are off the mark. The nature of this game is aimed towards the casual player. Recommend it to someone who doesn't typically play games. They'll appreciate the overall experience despite the shallow gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005786627', 'num_games_owned': 2673, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1420602303}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016627432', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1420409913}
review:
My boyfriend and I played this game together and greatly enjoyed it (overall).

Overall rating: 8/10
Objectionable Content: Mild? (bordering on 'some'?). There is some "humor" that is questionable both in taste and apropriateness for younger audiences. *See end of review for details, including trigger warnings and warnings for parents.

As far as the rest of the game goes, the atmosphere and evironments are absolutely stunning and worthy of screenshots. and the music is varied and well-suited. There is a bit of a Zelda-esque atmosphere which comes as no surprising seeing all the little Zelda references sprinkled throughout the game. It was refreshing to play a game that was not violent, yet still involved "beating the bad guys." So many of the characters you meet are adorable and hilarious, and have succeeded in getting laughs out of both of us. It is worth talking to all of them; they say some of the most ridiculous things. The gameplay centered around a very simple concept: pick flowers, though it was a pleasant surprise to find that it could be still be challenging sometimes. I would easily recommend this game to most of my friends.

Pros:
+ Fun, non-violent gameplay
+ Gorgeous visuals
+ World worth exploring (not overwhelming like big sandbox games)
+ NPCs worth interacting with
+ Nice soundtrack

Cons:
- The aforementioned tasteless jokes (why it is 8/10 and not 10/10. they were pretty gross.)
- Unexpected spike in difficulty between areas/levels.
- Does not clearly state its save mechanism (it's autosave, btw) and does not indicate what triggers a save
- Bit pricey for the length. I wouldn't pay more than ~$12.
- No replay value (one achievement needs ~half a 2nd playthrough but that's it.)

*There are a small handful of instances in which sexual harassment is normalized or made into a joke. Fortunately, they are few and far between, and most are easy enough to ignore and move past, but I can see a couple of the jokes being potentially triggering - especially since you would not see it coming from a game like this (we were very surprised ourselves). None of these jokes are a big piece of the game, but it's enough to make it not an 100% all-ages friendly game. To be more specific,
TRIGGER & PARENT WARNING: Stalking (creepy photos of Lili and her butt in one NPC's place), Sexual harassment (abuse of power/authority), Sexual abuse (1 joke).

author: {'steamid': '76561198028458130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1553555995}

author: {'steamid': '76561198156584607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1535163096}
review:
BEAUTIFUL! 
Game is simple. World is full.
Though it is short story, the world it creates is worth just getting to revisit. 
I find myself opening it up frequently as if traveling to visit with old friends. 
You should come visit! And if not, well then i guess i get to keep my 
secret little paradise to myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062269122', 'num_games_owned': 1154, 'num_reviews': 290, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1419578937}
review:
Un GTA para cr√≠os. S√≠, como lo le√©is. Control√°is a Lilly, que es una cr√≠a en un mundo de fantas√≠a donde va de ac√° para all√° hablando con los seres de ese mundo y haci√©ndoles recados, que es lo que ser√≠an las misiones de un GTA. Mientras va de ac√° para all√°, Lilly se inflar√° a recoger objetos, que son los que le servir√°n pra ayudar a la gente de dicho mundo. Adem√°s, puedes ir recogiendo dinero y flores (que vendes por dinero) para as√≠ comprar nuevos objetos, como unas zapatillas para correr m√°s r√°pido o una AK-47 con la que asesinar a todo el mundo. Esto √∫ltimo me lo he inventado, insensato.
Tambi√©n puedes personalizar el aspecto de Lilly, pero a esta chorrada no le dediqu√© mucho tiempo. M√°s bien, ninguno.
La trama central es que hay una serie de monstruos que van de ac√° para all√° correteando y que son "los malos" del juego. Tu deber consiste en capturarlos y arrancarles unas flores de su espalda, y poco a poco ir√°s liberando zonas del mapa.
Todo es muy infantil y on√≠rico, excepto las ganas de violencia extrema cada vez que aparece un habitante del mundo del juego con forma de buz√≥n de correo que lo √∫nico que hace es interrumpir lo que estoy haciendo.
El juego es bastante corto, pero para un cr√≠o que no se va a aclarar mucho le sobra, sobre todo si se va a poner a personalizar a Lilly y ayudar a todos los habitantes busc√°ndoles los objetos que necesitan. Adem√°s, cuando por fin acabas el juego, puedes explorar libremente el mundo.
Como digo, para un adulto este juego no tiene el m√°s m√≠nimo inter√©s, pero est√° bien para ir empezando a inculcar a los peque√±os en el noble vicio de comer pizza y jugar a videojuegos sin que te de un solo rayo de luz solar.

[b]¬°Qu√© exagerado eres! ¬øUn GTA para cr√≠os?[/b] Pues claro, hay que ser el mayor analfabeto del planeta para no darse cuenta no hay que tom√°rselo de manera literal, ya que he repetido mil millones de veces que suelo exagerar y no pienso dejar de hacerlo aunque reviente el universo.
[b]¬øC√≥mo es de dif√≠cil el juego?[/b] Pues el cazar a "los malos" es algo complicado, as√≠ como arrancarle las flores de la espalda, pero el resto es bastante f√°cil. Me infl√© a recoger monedas porque pensaba que las iba a necesitar y acab√© el juego con Lilly mirando cat√°logos de mansiones en Marbella y yates de lujo.
[b]¬øEs demasia√±o mo√±as el juego para un adulto?[/b] S√≠, pero se puede soportar. Son peores los cartelitos con supuestas frases de Paulo Coelho en Facebook.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088381654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1420061587}
review:
This game is a super casual game, and yes, you pretty much pick flowers and smash pots. It's not difficult at all but it an odd way, it was really fun. Definitely something you can just relax and play. It reminds me of a game that would be on Wii-U due to its cute charm. I got it on sale for under $3 and I suggest everyone do the same.

Pros:

+ GFX are nice
+ The characters are really odd and interesting
+ Has a great charm and there are some cool game references like Zelda and Mega Man
+ Honestly, fun to play
+ The surroundings are really fun to look at
+ I could argue that it is the best casual game I have ever played

Cons:

- Too easy, not challenging at all, you can get a key to open all locked doors at the beginning of the game, the items are useless, I didn't even need to use them
- Moving between areas, the game kind of freezes for two seconds when opening red doors, annoying
- When using a controller, some times the right stick will drift to the left, it can be fixed just by moving the right stick, but I don't think this game was designed to support controllers at first
- Full price for this game is too much, I beat it in 6 hours and got 42/46 achievements, $20 is too much

Overall, I'll give it a thumbs up. Just get it when it is on sale and don't expect it to be something super epic. It's just to have fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005647931', 'num_games_owned': 1650, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1419983736}
review:
Lili is a decent a reasonably creative collectathon that I can't imagine getting more than 6 hours out of. It's worth picking up on sale, but not for the full price of $20. 

Pros:
- Looks great, especially considering it started on mobile. A lot of that probably comes down to the fact that most levels are cleverly designed to avoid needing to draw more than 20 feet in any direction, but the game does run on Unreal. 
- Usually clever writing. Not perfect by any means, but it's generally entertaining.
- Strong world design. The descriptions comparison to Tim Schafer's work is pretty accurate in the world and character design. 
- The main mini-game is fun. It involves trying to pick flowers off the head of a spirit as it runs around and sprouts bombs and thorns to make you miss. It's reasonably challenging to win the later rounds with a perfect rating, but you're going to breeze through it if just passing is enough for you. Mileage will vary heavily here. 
- Lots of hats. Every spirit (52) and most quests (something like 12?) will give you a hat. There are also at least two pets to find, but the costume changes are limited to palette swaps, unfortunately. 

Cons:
- Very limited graphics options. You get a few presets with no descriptions of what any of them actually do. I don't think many people are going to have trouble running the game, but Highest turns on an incredible level of depth of field. I'd have liked to be able to turn that off. 
- Short. I finished it in 3 hours. That was enough to defeat all 52 spirits (most with 3/3 stars), complete nearly all of the quests, and find around 60-70% of the collectibles. 
- Controls are a bit wonky. Particularly the camera. 

Notes:
- Achievement hunters beware! Lili has a ton of achievements and *most* are near enough to completable in a sane person's playthrough. Then there's "Break 1,000 vases." I only got to 120 despite making an effort to break any I came across. You could probably get an extra 100 or so by going out of your way to look for them, but the full 1K is going to take some serious grinding. 
- Trying to play it on a standard touchpad would be a nightmare. 
- The description compares this to Zelda, but the only similarities I can find are some of the humor, Wind Waker's art direction, and the fact that money is completely and utterly useless in both games. Don't buy it hoping for puzzles or Zelda-like combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993237798', 'num_games_owned': 814, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1416375738}
review:
Adorable and with a beautiful art style, Lili: Child of Geos is a refreshing and imaginative game packed with fun humor, quirky characters and wonderfully crafted areas to explore.

Gameplay is simple: you're Lili, a young student visiting the island picking flowers for a school project. As you stroll around collecting, you'll bump into lots of interesting folks with fun things to say, little quests for you to do and treasure to find.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=343844996
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=343845084
The game has no combat involved. Instead, you encounter evil spirits to be purged by picking flowers from their backs. It's a mini game that was intended for tablets and phones, but still translates decently to mouse controls and is easy to pick up. Various challenges are thrown in when picking the flowers, like prickly thorns to avoid and timed bombs to fling off. It can be a bit repetitive though as it's the same minigame for each spirit.

All in all, Lili is a charming adventure in a beautiful and creative world. Great for kids, casual gamers, and anyone needing a nice dose of childlike wonder and joy.

review: While relatively short compared to most Adventure games, Lili is a very fun game.  The format is easy for new players to pick up quickly, and the story and humor should keep the more experienced players entertained.  Masters of adventure will probably find it too short for their tastes, but I found that it didn't outlast it's entertainment value.  I still plan to go back to 100% the game later on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017746934', 'num_games_owned': 1646, 'num_reviews': 487, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1476514379}
review: It's a very casual, very charming, very pleasant 3rd person adventure through the most endearing, beautifully rendered world I've seen in a game. Featuring a cast of quirky, funny characters, the game is fun for all the family!

author: {'steamid': '76561197980220433', 'num_games_owned': 589, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1460837003}
review:
A friend bought me this game during the sale, but its charm alone is worth the MSRP of $20. I thought I would play for like 10 minutes just to try the game out but a little more then an hour had past before I finally shut it off.  It is a fun explorative game, down the lines of similar platformers like Zelda or Dark Cloud.  

Except this game has a child like charm attached to it, so you won't find any swords or any weapons for that matter.  Even bombs are fairly harmless and the worst you'll be doing in the game is picking flowers off of evil spirits.  Its a very zen like experience to gameplay.

There are tons of characters with their own charms, and the graphics play their role dutifully.  If you're looking for a deep story look elsewhere but if not and can open your heart to a game that has a story closer to a childrens movie you will find alot of enjoyment.  Talking to NPC's and admiring the little details in every scene.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020748121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1419527625}

Es una pena que con una presentaci√≥n visual tan buena se quede en un juego ideal para los m√°s peque√±os de la casa, entre otras cosas por su baja dificultad. A pesar de todo por su bajo precio es recomendable ya que por lo menos por lo visual merece la pena echarle un vistazo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982811208', 'num_games_owned': 1221, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1419248983}
review:
Ja was soll ich sagen, ich wei√ü ehrlich gesagt gar nicht warum ich mir das Spiel gekauft habe. :D
Die Screenshots haben mich angesprochen und es war im Sale f√ºr knapp 4‚Ç¨. ^^

Es ist ein sehr stark vereinfachtes RPG, was die Gameplay Elemente angeht. 
M√ºnzen und Blumen sammeln, "Skillpunkte" (3 passive F√§higkeiten, die Punkte werden im Spielverlauf freigeschaltet),
ein paar optische Items zu Charakteranpassung, K√§mpfe gibt es auch nicht im eigentlichen Sinne. Eigentlich ein Spiel das in fast jeder Hinsicht nur das mindeste hervorbringt. 

Und doch macht das simple Spielprinzip irgendwie Spa√ü, die Grafik ist recht h√ºbsch, der Stil erinnert mich an Viva Pinata.
Es gibt einige lustige NPCs und das erkunden der Insel (4 Areale) macht Laune. Ein super Spiel zum abschalten, wenn man gerade keinen Kopf hat f√ºr anspruchsvolleres Material. F√ºr den vollen Preis kann ich es nicht empfehlen, da es daf√ºr einfach nicht genug bietet (4 Stunden und ich bin durch, ohne mich zu beeilen) aber f√ºr ca 5‚Ç¨ ist es ok.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998056243', 'num_games_owned': 816, 'num_reviews': 430, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1419253973}
review:
This game surprised me. I well knew that the game was only a simple game, all it was about was picking up flowers (lol?) and quick time events fights. So I was prepared to a mediocre game with a good artistic style.

Well, it's much more than that. The style is in fact very pleasant, I would say very well designed levels. You get 5 different levels in which you can free roam (you can't jump so no platforming sessions). Every level is quite different from the other and very suggestive. Every level also comes with its own background music.

The 'fights' consist in getting close enough to the enemy, and triggering the QTE (with the mouse cursor, or with ABXY buttons of the 360 controller). It is a nice QTE, compared to the average QTE in other games. During the fight you also can choose whether to use or not some powers (flash bombs).

The Character can be upgraded and customized (although the outfits are different almost only in colors). The flower picking is not tedious, comes spontaneous while you walk around enjoying the scenery.

When I saw the achievements....picking up 1000 flowers....I thought it was crazy. But no, in fact in only a few hours I did everything in the game and it really was no hassle. I enjoyed every part of it. It is the exact game I was looking for: it is nice, fun enough, and not complicated at all. It is a perfect game for children, or for grownups that want to relax from all the other FPS and action games, and dedicate themselves to this relaxing game. You don't have to reflect, you don't have to plan anything or else, just sit back and enjoy this little game. 80/100

author: {'steamid': '76561198033995360', 'num_games_owned': 2161, 'num_reviews': 441, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1419215647}
review:
Une jeune √©tudiante en doctorat sp√©cialit√© plantes magiques (ne rigolez pas, il y a bien des docteurs en sociologie) part en exp√©dition sur une √Æle √©trange r√©put√©e pour sa v√©g√©tation et ainsi parfaire sa th√®se. Elle va y d√©couvrir deux peuples loufoques et caricaturaux, tr√®s vite trouver ses marques et se m√™ler de la politique locale dans une ambiance de dessin anim√©.

Lili est un jeu qui n'en est pas vraiment un. Sans √©nigmes, avec un gameplay r√©p√©titif, un int√©r√™t ludique plus que relatif, une courte dur√©e de vie et un open-world √† la surface limit√©e, il ne peut m√™me pas √™tre consid√©r√© comme un jeu d'exploration. S'il se classe parmi les jeux d'aventure, Child of Geos tient plus du Penguin Island que du So Blonde. C'est avant tout un jeu d'ambiance, d'atmosph√®re, de contemplation - les d√©cors sont magnifiques et le character design nous offre une galerie de personnages aux allures extr√™mement sympathiques sorties d'un film d'animation. Les r√©f√©rences grossi√®res √† l'univers vid√©oludique sont nombreuses et quelques pointes d'humour gentillet sont toujours bienvenues. L'aventure est tellement bon enfant qu'on pourrait l'imposer √† tous les gosses de France si le jeu b√©n√©ficiait d'une traduction. Au final, par ses rares mais tr√®s solides qualit√©s, si ce n'est aux petits anglophones, Child of Geos s'adresse √† un public extr√™mement cibl√© : ces √©ternels touristes qui d√©barquent dans l'amphith√©√¢tre pour la premi√®re fois √† la mi-semestre en sandales et le caf√© √† la main. Ceux qui savent √† quel point perdre du temps, lorsque c'est fait avec plaisir, est une bonne chose ; je parle de ceux qui sont incapables de s'ennuyer m√™me enferm√©s dans une pi√®ce vide pour peu qu'ils aient un capuchon de stylo et une gomme. Je parle des nostalgiques de la place Delfino qui ont d√©pens√© tant d'heures √† y tourner en rond, les fain√©ants qui pr√©f√©raient fl√¢ner sur Mercant√Æle plut√¥t que d'aller enseigner l'h√©ro√Øsme √† quelques gobelins √† coups de Master Sword. Si vous vous reconnaissez dans ces tranches de non-vie, attrapez la main de Lili et allez lambiner en sa compagnie. Un beau petit voyage vous attend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067593641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1417501730}
review:
Although I do recommend this title, I do so for specific reasons. Specifically from a design aspect, I find the mechanics to be a fascinating way to have a non-combat oriented game that still proves to be challenging, interesting, and altogether very different.

The mechanics are pretty simple as far as a concept goes: you are a student botenist, and are collecting rare plants to study for a report, and thus go to an island. However, when you get there, trickster spirits get in your way and steal whatever flowers you have collected. To get them back, you must ride them like an unbroken bronco, plucking them while trying to hang on. All in all, very different, and definitely worth studying, especially if you have any interest in game design. Outside of this main gameplay trope, shall we say, there's a fair amount to explore in this world, with flowers showing up around every corner, plenty of people with well fleshed out personalities to talk with, and an interesting stat system to learn to make future, more difficult spirits more manageable.

Then there are the aesthetics. This game is absolutely gorgeous for the few resources it takes. The textures are well placed and the models are incredible. The animations are so carefully crafted, that it draws you into the magical island you have entered. I haven't found anything that feels out of place, or that jars me from the experience of the game, even with all of the collectable hats you can find for your main character.

Now the story is why I recommend this game with caution. Although it is fairly well written, it definitely is aimed towards a target audience that I am just not a part of. I believe this game to be designed with players younger than me in mind, older children into the preteen age. I feel like most children could get something out of this game, although I'm not completely sure how young too young would be for this particular title. However, being in my early 20s, this story simply doesn't compell me personally.

Now even with the somewhat childish atmosphere and story, I still found myself truly enjoying the game. It's not my favorite game, by a long shot, but for what it is, it does offer some decent entertainment for when I just want to relax and play a game that reminds me of the titles that got me into gaming almost 20 years ago.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007823333', 'num_games_owned': 570, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1590142182}
review:
It's a short, adorable, absolutely beautiful game about collecting flowers and making friends. It's exploratory and challenging, just enough to keep you interested in what new, spiffy thing is waiting to be discovered. The story is simplistic but comes with an interesting choice around the midpoint, and it's always good to see an intelligent female protagonist who dresses like an actual person.

Then you take a break to get a pop, and realize that the inhabitants of the game are only capable of eating each other. That the cute little artifacts you've been finding are remnants left by people who have died here and been trapped in slave-bodies, bereft of the memories of their former lives. That the disassembled man giving you advice can't really die. That the vibrant landscape is a beautiful prison. That smiling, clever Lili is one bad fall away from waking up with a barrel for a chest and no memory of who she was.

Kids' game, folks. For kids.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037586730', 'num_games_owned': 793, 'num_reviews': 415, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1486330336}
review:
Lili is a fairly good port of what I believe at one point to have been an ipad game.

Initially, it struck me as not too good because it does suffer from invisible wall syndrome. However, I kept playing and got quite into it, the game is actually pretty good on the exploration and "questing" front, even if it doesn't have a massive map. I did find that the game was rather heavy on the "collecting items" front.

Music is very good, and the sound bites work well to enhance the text which makes up the dialogue as there are are no full-text voices. The dialogue in this game has lots of humour, and the story it tells is good.

The Graphics are very nice, cartooney not photorealistic. The design of the maps in the world are likewise very well done.

I did encounter a bug that prevented the in-game cursor from loading, but this was easily fixed by switching resolutions in-game. The game is listed as having full controller support, but you shouldn't be playing with a controller. It is simply not suited to this.

Overall, while it isn't the most amazing game out there, it does provide for a fun game that you can probably get through in an afternoon, if you have one free. I will say that if you're after a heavy RPG, don‚Äôt go for this. But if you want to buy this for a more easy-going RPG, or one suited to children, then this is a good choice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039155266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1418607416}
review:
I'm going to keep this review short. This game is AWESOME. It's really relaxing and the characters are really fun and interesting. Lili's character is interesting, albeit a bit under-developed. The "combat" is very low stress and is legitmately fun. You wont find yourself cursing rampantly if you mess up (at least I didn't find myself doing that). The only thing this game needs is more... more levels, more travels. I'd love to see DLC's in the future, although I know it is a small dev team. In closing, this game is fun, pretty, and may remind you of some of the old 3rd person RPG's from N64-PS2 era gaming (not only because of the references), it just needs more content.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198036338106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 839, 'last_played': 1418028956}
review:
I have mixed feelings about this game.  I thought I was getting a full "Zelda"-like game with a female protagonist and a unique combat mechanism, but this was just "Flower-Picking: The Game," with occasional optional fetch quests.

I'm not even sure what demographic this was meant for; the dialogues, humor, and videogame references are older-teenager appropriate, whereas the gameplay is simplified enough for an elementary student to master.  Likewise, The main character looks like she's 15 and acts like she's 12, but is supposed to be a graduate student, and has apparently played every old school videogame on the planet except for Zero Wing... even the other characters in the game couldn't place her age.

What I liked about this game:
- The visuals and character designs were interesting, creative, and well-crafted.  I really enjoyed the overall look and atmosphere of the game, and the attention to detail of the artists.
- The game's frequent references to other videogames and movies, the dark humor, and the sassy side comments.  It was worth it to keep talking to characters and to read all the Mayor's signs.
- The balanced learning curve.
- The ability to pick up wearable items like ridiculous masks, videogame hats, and flying pets.

What was okay:
- The core game mechanic of picking flowers off spirits' backs.  While there was an increase in difficulty as the game went on (the introduction of thorns and bombs, the movement patterns of the spirit, the need to score higher combos of non-thorn flowers), there was not enough variation for it to feel appreciably different after about the 8th enemy.  The only real distinguishing factor from that point on was how long of a combo you needed in order to win 3 stars; early enemies only need 8-12 flowers in a row, whereas the final boss takes a chain of 30-40 flowers.  As you can imagine, by the 52nd spirit this minigame had worn out its welcome.
- Sometimes you will be able to complete optional side quests instead of fighting, which fall into one of four categories: "find all the hidden things," "visit that place you just visited," "fetch an item from the chest you just opened," or "fight that spirit you just fought"... O.o
- Four Hand Monty's "if you are short on cash and don't want to break vases" bonus ball-and-cup minigame.
- The oversimplified inventory system that consists of three tiers of armor for each of your three stats, three one-use items that I rarely ever used, two kinds of currency, two levels of keys, a cheater's map, and a bottle that summons butterflies for no reason.  That's it, unless you count the treasure trophies that only exist for flavour.

What I didn't like:
- Being constantly interrupted by either Mailbox, or the Mayor, or the fish, with long blocks of dialogue that you can't really skip.  I'm all about witty banter and story progression, but considering you need to play through the game twice to get all the achievements, it would have been nice to be able to bypass the excessive chatter.
- The big mid-game "choice."  I played through the game a third time, just to see what would happen if I chose the alternate path, and it was totally not worth it.  I was expecting at least a cutscene with the Professor.
- The rainbow bird poo.  Seriously?  That needed to be a thing?
- The achievements.  Some of them made sense, like the ones for beating the spirits, but some of them were needlessly tedious such as the "break 1000 vases" or "scare 500 birds." Additionally, these achievements are not cumulative across multiple playthroughs, you must break all 1000 vases using the same save file.  
There is also one broken achievement for this game: "unlock all doors."  It seems there was a discrepancy between the PC version and other ports, with the PC release only having 22/28 unlockable doors programmed in.  Thus, the achievement cannot be unlocked without manually altering the game code (you can find instructions for this online, but I personally didn't want to risk irreparably damaging my game data just for 100% completion).  [Edit 12/19/14: The broken achievement has been removed from Steam, so you can now get 100% completion!]

Overall, I would give this game a 7/10.  I liked the setting and the humor, but the core gameplay and the achievements were tiresome and boring by the end.

review:
This game took my breath away. At the start it asked if I wanted it to automatically set graphical setting; I said yes. It set them to the lowest setting for the game, but I would never have known if I didn't check what it set them to. The game lost almost nothing visually at it lowest setting.  

The games "high mouse sensitivity" is needed for the action parts of the game. I still had to set it to medium for myself to comfortably play with my specs.

+ Great game 

-  Barely worth the full price though

author: {'steamid': '76561198006077632', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1417824131}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is a game with massive potential that would've been excellent if it were actually made for the PC, and worst of all it's not even the developer's fault.

Seeing this game in the Steam Store, the first thoughts to come to mind were "This looks fantastic" and "Why haven't I heard of this before"? Unfortunately the answer was evident in about 10 minutes. This is a mobile port - a fantastic looking one that trumps most indie games made for the PC proper in terms of looks, but a mobile port nonetheless and that permeates the game to its core. 

This game is obviously a labour of love and it shows. But that it's also a mobile game utterly annihilates all of its positives - there's a "but" for each and every one.

‚Ä¢Every inch of the world looks fantastic, but you can't interact with it beyond walking around it.
‚Ä¢All of the levels are utterly distinct, but there's only four of them and they take 20 minutes to beat.
‚Ä¢The characters are well written and distinctly funny, but you never get more than half a dozen lines out of even the most prominent ones. 
‚Ä¢There's sidequests and optional content, but they're all threadbare.
‚Ä¢Design is solid all around, but assets are reused to a comical degree - I had trouble telling NPCs apart. 

Threadbare describes the game as a whole. Combat altering inventory items? Great idea. There's three of them and they're thrown at you, though. Stat increase system? Great idea. Shallow as a puddle, though. Climactic mid-sequence about abandoning previous life choices? Great idea. It consists of three and a half lines of dialogue either way and falls completely flat though. 

Worst case is the combat (or "combat", but there's enough high-octane explosives involved that I think you can safely ignore the whole nonviolent billing) - you perform the same unchanging minigame twenty or so times and then the game is over. Fifty-five if you're aiming for completionist. 

For a mobile game these are all more than excusable. Hell, I've no doubt that had I played this on a mobile device it would rank up there with the best; Dead Space iOS and Infinity Blade. But I didn't, and for a PC game, to put it lightly, it kicks it straight in the balls. Right in there. And it isn't the developers' fault. But that's just how it is. 

At it's best Lili: Child of Geos is an exercise in frustration at lost potential the likes of which I haven't felt since Crash Twinsanity.

Even though I wouldn't actually recommend this to anyone, maybe just buy it anyway. Support the developers. I want to see another game from them. Built from the ground up for PC this time.

Also, gamepad support is kind of lacking and the video game references get a little shoehorned at times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037615853', 'num_games_owned': 985, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1417271964}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is a wonderful casual adventure game. You follow Lili on her quest to free the citizens of Geos from the Spirits by gathering items and collectibles. There's really no point in the game than to immerse yourself with the wonderful cartoon fantasy world while discovering hidden items and collecting flowers - white ones which you can get anywhere and red ones which you need to fight some spirits to get it.

I really enjoyed this game despite of the lack of gameplay and the linear story line. What makes this game so much fun is the great art style and the graphics, this runs smoothly on my 3 yr old gpu, and I can appreciate that.  There are collectable items in the game like hats, pets, and masks. It's a nice addition, but the dresses are just a change in color. It would've nice to see something different. 

The music is perfect for a game like this but sometimes it gets a little annoying, I would have liked it to be a little subtle while im exploring and want to hear more of those ambient sounds.

I can highly recommend this to someone bored of the usual games and just want to chill out and enjoy the fantasy world. But if your an average gamer who wants more gameplay and some serious satisfaction out of a game, this isn't for you. I'd say it's great for a collectible, but honestly not worth the price, since the game is too short and replay value is very low.

Graphics: 7 - I like the graphics of the game and the the world of Geos is beautiful. 

Gameplay: 4 - There isn't really anything to do here aside from collecting flowers to proceed with quests and maybe collecting  masks and hats.

Music: 7 - The music is above average and will keep you feeling like you are in a cartoon fantasy world, but it gets repetitive. I woud've enjoyed more if I was hearing a more soothing music and more ambient sounds.

Replayability: 3 - The game doesn't offer anything more after you've beaten it once, maybe just to pick up more flowers and vases for achievements, or maybe get those missable hats or masks.

Overall Impression: 7 - I still give it a 7 despite of all the negatives, there is a certain charm to this game the you can only experience once you start adventuring with Lili=)

author: {'steamid': '76561197978568130', 'num_games_owned': 871, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1417532282}
review:
It's very cute, and simple. If you're looking for a short distraction, it's a great choice.
I picked it up on a whim during the Autumn sale, sat down, and blasted through it in one sitting. 
I looked at it because of the visuals. For an indie game, it's beautiful. Stylistic without abandoning realism. Bright and colorful. Great lighting. The character models are also really good, and well animated for the most part. The NPCs do seem to have one or two looping animations that they run through, but there's a lot of different NPCs, each with their own thing going on, so you never spend too much time looking at the single animations.
There is a story in there. It's nothing fantastic, but it isn't horrible. Its a sort of basic hero story; you show up on this island for a school project, and are introduced to a class struggle between the spirits, who own the island. and the constructs, who were created to serve the spirits. It moves along pretty quick, and the "big bad" of sorts is pretty entertaining to deal with.
The gameplay is almost a QTE sort of thing. You run around the island, picking up collectables. Flowers, which can be traded for money, chests that have money and quest or cosmetic items, and vases that you kick open for money and achievement score. Then you come across spirits roaming the quarters, and jump on their back for the main gameplay, where you are shown flowers you have to pick. You pick the good flowers and avoid the bad flowers, and pick bombs to throw off as you progress. You can upgrade your Speed (movement, helps you keep up with the spirits), Grip (gives you more time to hang on to their backs), and Stealth (makes you harder for them to notice, allowing you to get closer to them before they see you and start running away). I upgraded Speed to max, and Grip about halfway, and never had much trouble. You also get scored on how well you did. Picking more bad flowers or letting bombs explode in your face take points away, and for every 3 star score you get, you get the spirit's mask to wear.
There are also quests to do for the constructs. Simple stuff, like find me an item (in a chest somewhere nearby), go take down a specific spirit, go find and talk to another construct. They give cosmetic items, hats mostly.
You get a lot of hats to choose from, mostly masks from the spirits, but a fair amount of regular hats or headwear.

TL;DR - It's fun, really short, and really pretty. I bought it for less than $5 and I feel really happy with it. I don't know if I'd agree with $20, but for $10 or less, its definitely something to pick up

author: {'steamid': '76561198025230476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1594339803}
review: At its core, the gameplay style of Lili: Child of Geos is a tablet game.  You pluck flowers off your target and the difficulty increases by increasing the required number of flowers needed to be picked and the introduction of dangerous objects that mix in with the object.  If my monitor had touch screen capabilities, I would be playing the game with my fingers.  Despite this simplicity the game is fairly enjoyable because it comes in combination with a fairly enjoyable setting and atmosphere.  If I were to compare it, it would have to be with the atmosphere of the first city you wonder through in JRPG games like Final Fantasy IX and Kingdom Hearts.  It has a joyous, adventerous feel that warms your heart.  Maybe not at full price, but I would certainly recommend this game if you want to play around in a happy setting with surprisingly well polished graphics and lighting.  I feel like this game is worthy enough for the developers to turn this into a series starring Lili in more adventures but with more RPG elements, more puzzle elements, and a larger world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035054806', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1417784217}
review:
Ok I love this game. Sure all you do is pick flowers, kick open chests, talk to wierdos, smash vaces, and wrestle spirits; but it's really great fun. Good graphics. Easy smooth controls. It has an interesting mix of tiki and the island of misfit toys going on.

Yes there is a lack of most voice acting and that is a loss but that's the only draw back.

A good game for kids or any adult wanting a non violent fun time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971316390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1510961275}
review:
It is hard not to like this game simply due to its strong sense of personality, sadly while it has style in abundance the variety of content is simply not there. There is a bit of a plot here but ultimately the desire to return to the game isn't strong enough and the reply value is almost zero.

This brings me to the issue of, "Should I recommend this game to others?" 
That is really a very conditional thing because there is money involved. 

Had this been a F2P game then I would wholeheartedly recommend it due to the fact that, in short sessions, the game is really very enjoyable and is a pleasure to look at. The visuals and style of the game just scream quality from the rooftops and there is enough tongue-in-cheek humour here to put a smile on even the most cynical of faces. If you enjoy games you will come across such a large number of references to other titles it is almost wrong to call them Easter Eggs since the game is saturated with them rather than having them hidden away. The developers clearly love Legend of Zelda and other Nintendo games because they not only attempted to create an Nintendo-esque art style but they also added music to the game which is clearly inspired by games such as Wind Waker. They achieved that goal with such success that you could drop Mario or Link into the game world and they'd look perfectly at home.

Unfortunately when it comes to paying money for this and wanting value for money from your purchase, Child of Geos has very little to offer. It reminds me of something that would work well as a casual game for a rainy afternoon but nothing more, as such I wouldn't recommend this game unless it was on sale for maybe ¬£2-3 at most.

What the developers have created here is really something which deserves a sequel though, while they missed the mark on gameplay they have set a new benchmark for style and quality for the visuals, music and presentation for an indie game. I sincerely hope that this isn't the last we'll see of Lili.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025299573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1417266406}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is a game I'd kept my eye on ever since it first appeared on steam. It's colorful and unique art style and character designs interested me enough to put it on my watchlist. Having had the chance to finally give the game a playthrough I can see it both met my expectations and also took them in a different direction. This isn't your typical RPG by a longshot. You won't really be level grinding or anything like that as there really is no battle mechanic. You play as a botanist and your typical task on the island is to pick flowers. The best flowers happen to grow on the backs of creatures known as spirits. Picking them off their backs as they try to shake you off takes the form of a mini-game. I hadn't known going in that the game was a revisioned port of an iOS game, but it by far feels like one. That isn't a bad thing however as this game is beautiful to look at and the 'battles' can get quite challenging when thorny flowers and bombs are thrown into the mix. The game is also quite charming with a very unique art style I greatly enjoyed.

I do have a few issues with the game however, the camera has a bit of a wabble motion to it that is noticeable which can't be turned off in the options. If you easily get motion sick, this may get to you at first as it almost did with me, but as you're moving around it becomes less noticable. The game is also dull in parts and repetitive. Especially at first but once the game gains momentum it becomes far more interesting. The game even has a fairly dark undertone which I enjoyed but doesn't ever drown out it's charming and humerous nature. The writing is a bit odd at times though with occasional typos oddly phrased sentences and punctuation errors that hardly ruin the gameplay. Dialog is easy to read and understand even for children, though item descriptions can use words a bit out of reach for younger players. The game also features an auto-save feature which can get annoying towards the end of the game when you're given two choices. I would have liked to have saved at that point manually to reload later and take the other path instead of having to play through again.

All in all, I enjoyed myself while I was playing and genuinely felt myself drawn into the world this game created. This game isn't for everyone and I wouldn't consider it an RPG as it's closer to a modern day point and click adventure. I'd recommend it to ages 10-15, especially to female audiences or Miyazaki anime fans as it has a similar world feel. It won't be a length sit. I finished the game in 5.5 hours, but it does have a branching path towards the end.

If I didn't have the backlog I'd maybe even play it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130308644', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1416700656}
review: I played Lili on the casual setting because I'm going to be honest and say I have no video game skills at all. It was still really enjoyable and the graphics were amazing even on low. I loved playing it and I'm sure I'll be doing another run through when I get bored. I recommend it as an quick RPG to get through if you have 5 or so hours and don't want anything long lasting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990725997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 360, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1508360462}
review:
In Lili: Child of Geos; you play an invasive, Lara Croft reject, hippie, feminist lesbian human that trolls the ruins of living wood to deflower teenage spirits for her own personal pleasure. 

Euphemisms aside (that is honest to God what the game is like), it has really great graphics and simple gameplay with absolutely no violence. It is a friendly atmosphere with some ominous overtones in some of the characters that are described as jerks (hence her inclination to want to deflower them). There are some cracks at "men" in the game with her pretentious misandrist comments which makes her look even more lesbian. 

Oh, she can wear hats you find. 

This game is excellent for anyone looking for some not so stressful gameplay, or a young child that is still getting the hang of gaming, but still understands the basic mechanics of controller function and objective navigation. 

If you see it in a bundle or on sale, get it! Twenty bucks is a little steep, but you would definitely be giving back to the developers that seem to know how to make an applause-worthy game with beautiful visuals.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139970478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1436688448}
review: Lili is a short but sweet game by Bitmonster, inc. It's a wonderful first impression for the studio and I honestly cannot wait for them to release more games. The game reminds me a lot of Zelda and Kingdom Hearts in its design which I enjoyed and I thought the goofy story line was cute as well. The cast will steal your heart by the end of the game and you won't really have a problem with that. There a few different areas on the island to explore which is surprising for such a small game. It's quite fun to unlock all the doors and see what's hiding inside. The combat system is interesting. Instead of hitting them or shooting at them you jump on their backs and steal their flowers. I thought this was a very unique take on fighting systems. Lili is beautifully designed and lots of fun to play though it is only about 8 hours long so I would suggest waiting for it to go on sale. If you're looking to blow off some steam this is certainly your game. One of the best games I've played in a long time! 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198088033314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1414438722}
review:
[h1][b]Botanical Warfare[/b][/h1]

[h1][b]Full Review at [url=http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=124]GameDragons.Net[/url][/b][/h1]

[b]Presentation[/b]
Lili: Child of Geos tells the story of a young botanist, Lili, set on a quest to the supposedly uninhabited island of Geos as part of a school research project, but as the stories never tell the whole truth until you live them, you will soon find out that the island is actually inhabited by creatures called the Spirits and their creations meant to serve them, the Constructs. It won't be long before your arrival will alert the Spirits as your presence starts to influence the lives of the Constructs and make them question their existence as servants, so you will soon be caught up in the affairs of Geos‚Äô locals. 

As much of a premise for a serious plot there is, the game chooses tell its story in a satirical way, adding jokes and references to other games every now and then, some which fail to deliver, making the entire story feel irrelevant after you realize most quests are there to fill in the space without an actual outcome in the storyline. As a game that focuses on exploration and the landscape it creates with it, it was disappointing to see how limited that exploration really is; it was exciting to find new items, meet new Constructs and see where else their quests will take me, but after a few minutes you will soon realize that there are only around eight additional sidequests, most which take no longer than ten minutes to complete and as for everything you see in the distance, you will never actually get there.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
As for how the game plays, well it certainly is different from anything you have experienced before, as your main objective is to defeat Spirits by jumping onto their back and picking the flowers that spurt from their heads. This is where the game shows its true nature, as it was originally made for tablets and picking flowers by dragging them with your finger across the screen feels natural and easy, but doing the same thing with a mouse can be a little bit tricky. 

Using a controller makes the whole thing a little bit easier as you can select the flower you want to pull using the action button, but at the same time it creates another problem, as you can only select from a range of four flowers, mapped to their respective action button, so later on in the game when you'll have to deal with up to eight different flowers, weeds and bombs at the same time, the controller will prove to be more of a burden than a helpful tool. Outside the battle the game works much better, using the keyboard and mouse or the controller to move around, collect flowers, look around for treasures and meet Geos' finest, but then again for an open world experience, there is a really small number of things that you can do outside the main story, which isn't that long either and the first glance at Geos will soon be shattered by exploration limits and the lack of new things to keep you going for longer or distract you from your main objective.

[b]Graphics[/b]
Looking back at the iOS version of the game, it's clear that the visual upgrade worked out for the best and Lili: Child of Geos looks amazing on PC, but the real beauty when playing the game comes from the art style itself, taking you somewhere between what a gnome village would look like and combining it with a good Pixar movie. The landscapes are simply amazing and as for the characters, even if the Spirits look the same except for their masks, the Constructs each have a unique touch to help you recognize them whenever you see them around Geos. The bad part in all this is that you never get to explore everything that you actually see ahead of you and the five different locations of the island can be completed within minutes as there is nothing else to do besides the main objective and a few chests scattered around.

[b]Audio[/b]
The soundtrack complements the visual art style, probably not in the best way possible but its better with it there playing the background as you move on than without it. The worst part on the audio side is the absence of voice acting, which is understandable since most mobile titles lack such things, but as a PC port it's hard not to complain about how great the dialogue could've been voiced by the right actors, and on the same note it could've made some of those lame jokes funny just by using the right voice. The sound effects are okay, but since there is a limited number of items and objects that interact with the environment and your character, it will soon feel like a repetitive and monotone experience.

[b]Extras[/b]
It takes around four hours to finish Lili: Child of Geos, which isn't nearly enough to justify a 20‚Ç¨ price tag, and aside from that and a few achievements that you'll miss on your first playthrough there really is nothing else to keep you around, no matter how beautiful the island of Geos is.

[b]Verdict[/b]
Judging by the first look, Lili: Child of Geos is beautiful and unique, but in this case the first look is deceiving, as the game won't last more than a few hours and as for the time in which it actually is entertaining, that's probably less than 30 minutes, but if that time is enough for you and you're just looking for a great view, Lili: Child of Geos delivers flawlessly on that side.

[u]Rating: 5.9[/u]

author: {'steamid': '76561198044037864', 'num_games_owned': 1252, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1414529755}
review:
Oooh boy, this is an odd one...

When I came along to see this game on sale, I thought what would await me was a cheesy, but pretty RPG with puzzles to solve and battles to win, much like the advertised likeness to Zelda and Psychonauts. What greeted me instead was an almost childish flower-picking simulator with the most gorgeous artstyle I ever saw.

And I didn't mind.

I bought this game, like some other people, because of the screenshots, and the promise of reliving some of the charm of the games of my childhood. I'm not normally a person who cares much for graphical fidelity in games so long as the gameplay is fun, however in this case? Quite the opposite. Something about the graphics style just makes me innately happy whenever I look at it. It puts my mind to rest for a while, which as a person with depression and anxiety attacks is a bloody godsend. The entire game is very colorful, vivid and nicely stylized, with very fluent animation, adorable little details and an overall just... happy feeling to it. It's easily one of the best-looking games I've played in my life, and it does so not through polygon count, but clever, passionate stylization. Don't get me wrong, though, the models are still pretty high quality.

With the graphics out of the way, though, let's address gameplay. This is where I initially felt cheated by the storepage claiming such close resemblance to the Zelda and Psychonauts games. I imagined adventuring, clever puzzles and dangerous trials. What I got was "Flower Picking - Collector's Edition", with the 'Collector' being quite literal. This is a game about collecting things and smashing pots. Collect flowers. Collect money. Collect conversation. Collect Collectibles. Every so often you'll fight a spirit, where the term 'fighting' is used much in the same way the term 'Discussion' is used for having a 12-year-old squeak into their microphone online in your FPS of choice. The spirits run away from you, because apparently a 16 year-old hipster florist apprentice is more dangerous than a mystical, 7 feet tall nature spirit with magic powers. Once you've caught up to the spirits, the fighting is technically a long, randomized QTE. They grow flowers from their backs. Sometimes they're good flowers, sometimes they're bad flowers, sometimes they're bombs. A button hovers over them and the game wants you to press the button that hovers over the thing which won't harm you like a parent presenting three hot stove plates and a plushie to their three-year-old and telling them to think fast.
Occasionally the gameplay is broken up through quests you get from talking carpentry accidents that more often than not involve walking to a specific place or talking to a specific person. Sometimes you need to defeat a certain spirit, which you would probably do anyway sooner or later.

What makes the quests, and the game in general interesting are the conversations. Despite the childish flair of the game, the writing is actually enjoyable for the most part, offering some casual humor around every corner. The characters are all quirky enough, and while not exactly believable, are enjoyable to interact with and had me talking to them over and over again to see more conversational options. Whether that was because I actually enjoyed the quirkyness of it all or simply because there's not much else to do I'm not quite sure, but it's lead me to finishing the game and doing so with a smile, so whatever it was, it worked!
On account of the writing, however, and the general presentation, in this case of the main character, I'll have to give a bit of a cringe-warning:
The game likes its references. Which is all fine and dandy, many games do it, and to great effect, usually in the form of little trinkets hidden here or there, or a quest resembling the story of a classic. Lili has a slightly different approach to that in some points, "slightly different" meaning "IN YOUR FACE". The game enjoys repeating how much of a gamer the main protagonist is, and how much she knows about casual video game trivia to the point where it had me sit in my chair, squeeze my legs together and groan.
"Look at us!", the game keeps saying, "We're gamers just like you, haha! See? We played some video games!"
"Alright, that's cool!", I replied with a smile and went on with my business.
"Oh hey, did we mention how much we love gaming? Hey, we're just like you! Gamer bro fist, haha!"
Alright, game, I get it. You guys made a video game, I kind of figured you'd probably have played one or two before.
"Hey look at how much we know about games! Man, games, am I right? We love games so much. We should hang out now because you play games, too!"

One last thing to consider before a purchase is the length of the game. I've completed the game with all sidequests in about 4 hours. It's not a terribly long game by any stretch of the imagination. You can beat it in a single afternoon if you're so inclined, and there's little reason to go back to it afterwards unless you just need a breather from grey reality and want to delve into a colorful, gorgeous fantasy island again.

All in all, however, it's a minor itch and completely ignorable. The game, while about as casual as a stroll through the park on a sunny spring day, was still enjoyable and while I would not recommend it for the full price, it's certainly worth a look on sale. Whether you're feeling down or just long for something lax to play while listening to a podcast or letting the day fade out, it's sure to put a smile on your face if you don't mind an experience that's more focussed on presentation than gameplay. It's an immensely impressive starting project for BitMonster and I'm looking forward to their next games already.

PS: BitMonster, if you guys could make another game with the same art style but more engaging gameplay, I would love you forever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000031091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1414985797}
review:
As usual with my reviews, let me start with the TL;DR version for those who don't have time to read a wall of text,

"Lilli: Child of Geos" is an astoundingly charming indie game full of colour and character. The gameplay is addictive but can get a bit samey, but, thankfully doesn't overstay it's welcome. While the $20 price tag is a bit high for a 5 hour long game, it's well worth a shot when on sale if you are into casual, colourful experiences.

Now for the meat:

	Lilli is one charming title. There is so much colour in this game to help make the island of Geos feel alive, making each of the characters you meet another interesting addition to the game. Just starting off this review, if I have to say what this game's strong suit is, it is definitely the art direction it took with aesthetics, I couldn't ask for it any other way.
	The gameplay, while somewhat reminiscent of "Zelda" games, lacks any sort of true combat mechanic. Even the game remarks at one point, acknowledging the fact that you will not "kill" anything on this island, even the bad guys. The idea predmoninantly is based around the idea of exploring the town (divided into 4 seperate sections) on the island of Geos. While in each section of the town there are various tasks to be completed: from independant exploration to find treasures, flowers, and pots to smash; to completing quests the various towns people have - most of these ranging in a form of a fetch quest, disappointingly.
	The game also features RPG-esque stat building. These stat points are there to help aid you in the core mechanic of the game, which is finding, capturing, and defeating "spirits". This involves using the mouse to click on flowers and plants to pluck from the head of the spirit while trying to maintain your grip on said spirit by not plucking thorny plants or getting hit by...-bomb flowers-....
	This mechanic works well enough to do the job, but is certainly not the highlight in quality for this game. The mechanic itself tends to get a bit monotonous after a lengthy playthrough with this game, as well as the 3-star rating system that seems to be unclear as to how to obtain a rank. Often times I found a well executed "plucking" of a Spirit would only reward 2 stars, while other times I was fumbling over thorny plants and mis-clicking, I still got 3 stars.
	When it comes to the controls of this game, this is probably the worst part, sadly. There are NO REBINDABLE KEYS. while the game doesn't use a lot of keys to begin with, I had many frustration that the "Interact" and the "mount Spirit" function were mapped to the same key, leading often to me talking to an NPC, rather than mounting the spirit I was chasing. Additionally there is some of the ABSOLUTE WORST mouse acceleration in this game. Even set to the "highest" mouse sensitivity, the game seems to have "camera smoothing" which results in the games camera and character feeling very, very floaty. I figured perhaps a controller would feel more comfortable for this type of thing, but surprisingly it was even more uncomfortable for me to play with a controller than a mouse. This is something that I hope the Developer will fix in later patches. Unfortunately, if you gathered with the 3-star rating system, addictive game play, colourful graphics, and wonky controls: Yes, this game seems to be intended for mobile platforms, and I think is quite a blemish on this game to have to comprimise competent, and proper PC graphics and control settings to aid with the underpowered mobile devices.
	Before concluding I would like to mention a HUD bug this game seems to have, which is most apparent on 4:3 panels. This game does not feature proper word wrapping or font-size adjustments. Often text will bleed off of the on-screen button or prompt - this looks unattractive and very amatuerish. 
	Additionally I want to make 1 side note: While I am not a professor of law, I think this game borders dangerously close to infringing some copyright, with blatant use of Nintendo IP titles and names, additionally a music track in Mill Hill is dangerously close to a track in the Sims 3.
	
	Lilli, with it's blemishes aside, is still a fun and addicting game to play. While the price tag is hard to justify for it's 5 hour campaign, if you find it on sale, I can't recommend it enough that you play this game. Give it a go if you want a happy, and very casual experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053210555', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1415411332}
review:
First, let's talk about game length... I heard this was pretty short so I held out for a good sale and finally picked it up for about $4. After almost 3 hours I'm maybe halfway through the game. I figure it should give me at least 5-6 hours of gameplay which is decent for that price but at full price you may want to hold off.

Anyway, about the game itself... The characters and the world are totes adorable. You'll find humorous writing, both light and even a little dark, video game references and great art direction. It's a good looking game with it's own style. 

It's not without flaws, though. The biggest one which may even make it difficult for some people to play this is the barfy mouse-look. I can't even call it mouse acceleration. It's way worse than that. The mouse-look lags way behind and then suddenly snaps into position. It's very awkward and even though I never get motion sickness playing games, this had my stomache rolling sometimes. 

Also, this game does not allow you set your game up via launcher or main menu. It dumps you into the game right away and you can fiddle with some minor graphics options once you get into it. The game did an adequate job of detecting my hardware and the game ran fine for me but for some others this may end up being a problem. Every game should allow you to configure your settings before rendering more than a menu just for safety's sake.

Another minor thing is the lack of voice acting. There are some voice clips, from Lili saying "hi" in 3 or 4 different ways to the other characters having their own little intros/outros to some grunts/barks during combat but aside from that none of the dialog is voiced which is weird since the voice acting that is there isn't bad. It would have been nice for a game this short to be fully voiced, at least the main characters.

Overall, though, it's a fun, cute little game involving smashing vases, stealing people's belongings out of thier homes, picking flowers and completing quests in good ol' RPG fashion. Pick it up on sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025024010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 153, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1474181406}
review:
Been playing for a few hours now, but I've got a new recommendation.
Lili: Child of Geos will probably appeal to fans of Chibi Robo, Banjo Kazooie, and other collectathon games.

It's very gorgeous, pretty decent core gameplay and interesting writing.

The controls feel a bit wonky at first but, other than the "boss fights" you aren't expected to be very precise.  

You just wander around, collect items, and help people.

The main character's cute and there's also costumes for completing substories and talking to characters in game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998532163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1414648492}
review:
I bought this game almost entirely because it looked really cute from the screenshots. After playing through the first two areas (so far), I must say I am very pleasantly surprised! The art is very nice, as I expected, but the detail is far greater than I expected. Such a lovely atmosphere! The world they've created is one that I am thoroughly enjoying exploring. You can tell a lot of love went into this game just from looking around.

But enough about the wonderful art. If I had to classify this game I'd say it's a point-and-click with some (very limited) RPG elements and quick time events.

The game's story is... well, it's silly, but it's interesting enough. The humor is where it really shines. From conversations to item descriptions, this game has a lot of laughs packed in.

Gameplay is a bit rough. I feel confident in saying that this game was made with touch screens in mind, so the controls are a little clunky and the "battles" can be tricky--after all, you only have one mouse instead of a handfull of fingers. Still, you'll get used to it pretty fast. I'm playing on the hardest difficulty and I can usually get 3 stars (the max number) on my first try, and I am by no means a hardcore gamer. I've only played the first two areas, though, as I said, so it will presumably get harder. Still, I'm sure this will be a turn-off to some, so I feel the need to mention it.

No major glitches so far, just some camera twitchiness when you talk to people as it switches from "world view" to "conversation view", and once where I could read a sign through a wall.

Music is adequate. Nothing to write home about, but works well with the atmosphere and isn't irritating.

Sound effects are good, but the random dialogue bits (the game isn't fully voice acted, but sometimes people will say a few words of their text) are sometimes odd. Such as Lili saying "Hello!" when she's actually saying goodbye in her text... or just randomly in the middle of a conversation. What up with that, Lili?

All in all, I am pleasantly surprised and really enjoying the game. Do recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998666646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1413470306}
review:
Whether or not this game is to your liking I can't say. However I can tell you about my own breif run in with this game. 
When I first opened the game it was in some obscure resolution that my screens couldn't comprehend. 
To later on find the options menu proved to be a difficylt task. As the game appearently was taller than my screen but still thinner. So I had to click around outside of my screen until I got the correct button. 
From there on things just got even more cryptic. For in regards to screen resolution you do NOT have the choice of 1920*1080. Nor any other that fits. 
Furthermore, as the final nail in the coffin (for me), this game gives you 4 buttons in regards to mouse speed. Going from Medium, High, Highest and "Tablet"..... 

The game look good, and for some it will probably also be a fun game. But not for me.
