author: {'steamid': '76561198001454789', 'num_games_owned': 2182, 'num_reviews': 258, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1412418271}
review:
This game is great. It's an adventure focused on exploration and it contains a few RPG elements. It makes fun of videogames and clich√©s, it has "fighting" mechanics I've never seen before and it presents some of the weirdest NPCs you'll ever meet.

Pro:
+ beautiful visuals
+ great soundtrack
+ innovative gameplay
+ good level design
+ lots of humor
+ many collectibles
+ the story is nice and it fits to the game...

Contra:
- ...but it's very short
- playing on after the credits isn't very exciting
- it isn't a good game for achievement hunters

author: {'steamid': '76561198021985302', 'num_games_owned': 967, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1412298030}
review:
A very cute little, casual game with nice graphics.

Sometimes i still get surprised by games, Lili: Child of Goes was one of these rare occasions.
Didn't knew much about the game, but upon starting it, i was dragged into it's nice, colourful and delightful atmosphere.

You're going to play Lili (much surprise ^^), a girl, stranded on an island with strange creatures. You're going to explore the different locations of the island and try to free the creatures from the bad mayor.

The locations are divided into semi-large hubs, which you can explore, find collectibles, hidden chests and solve smaller quests. The locations have a broad variety and do look very different and have their own charme.

The graphics and artstyle are very beautiful in my opinion, which is a great strength of the game.

The overall gameplay is rather simple and casual though. There is not much "puzzle solving" involved, you rather run around the island, explore the locations and stumble upon secrets without a bigger challenge.

But even if the gameplay is quite simple, i had my fun with it and enjoyed playing it.
The main storyline is rather short, i guess, though you do have some collectibles and achievements which might keep you busy for a while.

I'd also recommend this game for a younger audience, as it's rather easy and casual and violent-free.

Thumbs up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042259317', 'num_games_owned': 4316, 'num_reviews': 414, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1651216859}
review:
[b]Buy? Likely.[/b]

Lili: Child of Geos is decently ported iOS game about playing as a girl picking flowers....what am I doing with my life?!

[b]TL;DR: It is a fantastic looking game that is basically a collectathon without much challenge beyond hopping on the backs of enemies to pluck flowers from enemies trying to shake you off of themselves. It sounds silly, but probably worked well on mobile and worked fine as a PC mini game. Calling this game an RPG is a stretch -it's more like a platformer without platforming - adventuring and collecting really. I adore the world design and want to see more of it, and it's simplistic game style makes sense for being an original iOS game.[/b]

Lili caught my attention from a recent Groupees Bundle: The character is a unique female protaganist and the game looked like it had a nice Pixar-movie quality. I'm glad to say that at least visually and in terms of world building, it does have that quality. I've taken about 150 screenshots of this game, especially since I was captivated by the foilage, lighting, shading and texture effects. Sure, there are more graphically advanced games, but end result of the developers move to make the game look better on PC instead of being a simple port made the game a pleasure to look at and arguably one of the best looking games of the year.

The gameplay mostly boils down to exploring the island, collecting money from kicking pots and collecting white flowers, which are sold for money. The meat of the gameplay is near violently plucking flowers off the backs of Spirits in "combat" in order to get their red flowers for reearch at the school Lili is from. I like that the game has a simple story, but it is disappointing that in a game about flower picking, that there are only two types of flowers that matter in the overall world, excluding the green, coin, bomb, and thorns on spirits throught "combat". I use combat in quotes, because basically  Lili needs to steal the flowers off the back of the spirits haunting the living, wooden constructs by jumping onto their backs and plucking flowers that sprout from them while the spirits run around trying to shake her off. Thsi form of combat is really the only form of challenge in this game, which was fine for me since it's simplcity is what I was expecting. There is an RPG mechanic of increasing your grip, speed, and stealth, but considering how easy the game is, coupled with the easily obtainable items to augment these abilities (Not to mention that one guide highly recommended Speed and stealth, but I went with Grip and stealth with no problem), your progression will generally not matter unless you are just bad at the game.

While the gameplay is extremely simplistic, yet solid, the best part of the game to me is the overall game world. From the protaganist, to the cast of kinda-stupid but lovable NPCs, and the well design "levels". it made me interested in the world more so than the game. I'd be interested in seeing a sequel or a successor that incorporates the world into new gameplay, like a platformer or a Zack and Wiki style puzzler.

[b]Summary:[/b] I finished Lili in slightly over 4hrs and considering what little gameplay there was, I'm perfectly fine with that. More if spent time with the sidequests, though I didn't see a reason too since money or upgrades are only a problem in the earliest first half hour of play. There are plenty of achievements and all seem easy, though it would be a grind to complete them all. I have issues with the constant achievement popups, the lack of ability to change the resolution or remap keys (part of the game was cut off on my Ultra-wide monitor. I played it on a regular monitor, and it was fine. Then I went back to the UW on another play, and I didn't have the cutoff issue anymore), but despite that, I still enjoyed the game. It's shortness makes it an easy recommend for people with large backlogs, though the $20 price point is a bit too high for what is being offered.

review: If you like cute games that are not that difficult with easy-to-solve puzzles, this is the game for you. There is a story, but it isn't very deep and the gameplay is repeatitive. You basically go around collecting flowers and deflowering spirits until you face the Mayor...and deflower him and beat the game. The game is pretty, the side quests are a nice change of pace, but I really REALLY wish the ending was better and the story was a little less surface. All and all I would give this game 3/5 stars because there is definately some improvements that could have been made.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988444232', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1467763445}
review:
This right here is one heck of a SOLID short action adventure game. The team that made it was incredibly small, yet has more polish than I could have expected from even a AAA developer these days.
It's lighthearted, mechanically sound (if not terribly innovative really), artistically magnificent, and just altogether charming. As is the case with many indie games, it has a healthy dose of humour and 4th-wall-breaking, and more gaming references than you can shake a deku stick at. (I'm incredibly sorry for that one, that's my bad.)

Lovely, lovely game, and incredibly ambitious work for such a small group. I applaude you all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054644849', 'num_games_owned': 971, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1590237119}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043960246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1446734784}
review:
A very fun casual game, though a little short.

Lili‚Äôs gameplay is similar to RPGs at core: you explore the area for treasures, talk to NPCs and fight enemies. In Lili‚Äôs case, though, ‚Äúfighting‚Äù is replaced with a minigame where you ride hectically running spirits and pull flowers from their backs (it makes sense in the context ^_^; ), which requires some precise clicking but not hard overall.

In regard of game‚Äôs length, completing the game will likely take you some 5 - 7 hours, depending on how through you are with exploring everything and completing achievements.

The Island of Geos is a small place, with only 4 areas to explore. However, what little of game world there is, is thoroughly detailed: every place is unique and each of 4 areas, despite being a part of the same island, has very distinct feel to it. It is complimented by beautiful graphics, which makes exploration of the game world truly enjoyable.

If you are looking for a simple lovely game to relax with, there is a good chance that Lili is just what you need. However if you are looking for a more lengthy or challenging game, Lili probably isn‚Äôt for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076924830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1411330192}
review: It is very short, but I enjoyed the graphics, simplicity and quirky nature to this game (I also got it on sale). I personally always enjoy trying to get all the achievements and items (still working on it), but I also love Banjo Kazooie so that can be a part of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031342885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1411236429}
review:
Lili is a joy! The gameplay relies heavily on exploration and finger-puzzle sequences, set in a beautiful dreamworld. Uplifting woodwinds provide an expressive and evocative aural backdrop for Lili's adventure. Lots of nods to other games in the RPG genre. Lili herself is curious, independent, and spits on the infantilization of women in video games (without ever getting too heavy or serious). 

This game is a delightful fantasy, with pickup & go gameplay - use it as a relaxing respite! I laughed, smiled, and felt generally content while traipsing through Geos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149269076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1411259617}
review:
This game is beautiful. From the scenery to the music you can tell the developers put some time into this game. As far as gameplay goes it's kind of reparative. You "fight" the enemies the same way with little variety, and there is only one thing you collect which is flowers. You can customize the character but it does feel a little limited however

Pros-
*Beautiful scenery and music
*Peaceful
*Is a great way to kill some time

Cons- 
*Repetitive gameplay
*Not a big RPG element even though it says to be a RPG hybrid

Neutral-
*Relatively short, but it is a port of an IOS game
*One glitched achievement, neutral because some people won't care about that

author: {'steamid': '76561197964410359', 'num_games_owned': 5234, 'num_reviews': 273, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1409620029}
review:
Parfois on a envie de challenge, ou de criser pour passer un passage ultra difficile en jouant, et parfois on a juste envie de se d√©tendre. C'est dans cette seconde cat√©gorie que ce jeu intervient. Clairement pens√© pour un public jeune (malgr√© de nombreuses r√©f√©rences dans les dialogues), Lili est jeu qui se d√©roule sans anicroches, avec des objectifs simples, des events accessibles et un syst√®me de progression facile. 
Graphiquement c'est relativement joli et f√©√©rique, le jeu se d√©roule dans un univers qui a un minimum de background qui sera expliqu√©. Le gameplay est tr√®s simple, se r√©sumant √† un mix entre des qu√™tes du type "va chercher ceci" et des phases de "combat" qui sont en fait des QTE g√©ants, et de temps en temps un peu d'exploration au sein des 4 diff√©rentes cartes qui composent le monde. 
Assez court, assez simple, mais pourtant plut√¥t cher, au prix public c'est √† mon sens plut√¥t cher pay√©, mais obtenu dans un bundle, c'est une bonne occasion de passer une soir√©e au calme, et pour les acharn√©s, √ßa se 100% tr√®s bien sans hurler, pour une fois.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078204256', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1534796790}
review:
This game is beautiful. I love this game. 
It's obvious that the Devs love this game, and really poured over every detail. Some are saying that it's "light on story" And I'm here to tell you that that's a load of shit. It's one of those games the story needs to be pieced together, by finding items, talking to NPCs, and completing main quests. So if you're unable to pay attention for 5 seconds, you'll probably miss most of the awesome references and happenings within the game. But if your patient, and play the game the way it's meant to be played (Casually) you will experience the full effects of it. My sister who is a toddler will sit down (something she doesn't do often) and watch me play this game. It is so vibrant, and full of color it can capture the attention of a 2 year old.  Beautiful game, an experience that brought me back to some of my favorite games I used to play on my N64, and GameCube. 8.5/10. P.S: If you scroll up and this game is still on sale for 4$, BUY IT RIGHT NOW GODDAMNIT WHAT'S WRONG WITH YOU! LIKE SELL YOUR CS:GO SKINS OR TRADING CARDS!

review: If you're like me and you are attracted to colorful platformers, despite being a fully grown man, take note: This is not Beyond Good & Evil. This is not Ratchet & Clank. This is a kid's game that I beat in 3 hours. It's not a bad game, I just wouldn't recommend it to other adult G4M3R5.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971062058', 'num_games_owned': 1291, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1410572970}
review:
This game would probably be fun for little kids, as well as for perverted adults - its full of masked references to various aspects of sexual life (enlargement pills, silicone implants, olfactophilia, stalking... you have it all here if you look carefully enough :P). but mainly the game is making fun of various weird life, relationship and fashion habits and also has a message for the player in the end.
Sort of interactive fairy tale soaked with various references.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009326247', 'num_games_owned': 3699, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1410555762}
review:
I'm a 30 year old man and I still enjoyed this game. It's quite relaxing, visually excellent and you can find a few amusing innuendos for adults that children won't notice :) The core of the gameplay is exploration and QTE-style "fights" (quite easy to pull off using a X360 gamepad). You can' die or lose in any permanent way.
Minding the fact that I got it during -80% sale = double win.
7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198007665656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1410540359}
review:
One of the best-looking games I have played or even seen. Every graphical aspect really shines brilliantly in this game. The gameplay is simplistic but a whole hell of a lot more fun than yet another fps, or zombie horde, or other such nonsense game. 
This game actually has new, imaginative gameplay features, even if it is just grabbing flowers off some weirdo's back. 
The dialogues are pretty funny and the game knows it's space well, and uses it nicely. It may have come from touchpads but the controls are fine, and there are lots of camera options, and the graphics, as stated before, look fantastic. 

I wouldnt call this RPG at all, there are a few basic skill trees and cosmetic items but nothing I have seen so far really qualifies as rpg. Doesn't matter, it's fun just to be inside of these environs. 

Highly recommended on sale, or even near full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089478251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1439743690}
review:
By the trailer, I decided I wanted the game; but I wasn't willing to spend $20 on it. So as do all (*cough* most) of my games, I bought it on sale.

I have 4 younger siblings, and this game provides a safe, clean, game environment for them. As with most games, there was some humor pertaining to current society, but nothing that a younger child would understand. The graphics are spectacular one of a kind.

If you are looking to spend your money on longlasting game, this game isn't for you. If what you want is a clean and beautiful gameplay, I would definitely partake in the playing of this game. Though personally, I believe the game should be in the $5-$8 price range, the game is definitely worth it if you have young children (around 8 years of age) whom you want to play clean games.

To the developers:
You created something new here. Work on that. Create a franchise. Ease of the throttle of side quests and add more to the storyline next time. This game is peaceful, but it could still have such a sense even if you added more strategy without exactly adding more challenge. Add more customization to the strategy. More than just outfits, but outfit pieces that contribute to a better stat system. Invest in voice actors, it makes a huge difference. Look into adding a better ambient/light-trance music to the game to compliment the awesome scenery you achieved. Lastly be optimistic! You did awesome!

author: {'steamid': '76561198068849282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1436997019}
review:
--------WARNING!!!! --------- This is an exploratory item collecting game, not a fighting game.

I love this game so much! It's not terribly long, but not so short that you end up really disappointed (as long as you're trying to be thorough anyway), and the achievements aren't impossibly unreachable.
The graphics and characters are beautiful, and funny (packed with refferences), so I definately recommend this to the artistic or comedic! You'll do better at this game if you like talking to game characters (the talks are pretty short anyway so no worries). ;) 
As a side note, the mouse/camera is a little weird, but you can probably get used to it. 
++++ Put this on your wish list so you know when its on sale (its not long enough or with a rich-enough story to be worth $20, but for $10 or less, go for it!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025092004', 'num_games_owned': 1719, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1422803789}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023640271', 'num_games_owned': 1372, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1410258819}
review: I bought this game because I thought it would be an interesting, cheap game to try out. My expectations weren't extremely high, so when I actually played it I was really happy with the game. author: {'steamid': '76561198102452171', 'num_games_owned': 1007, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1549613811}
review:
I've barely put in an hour with the Steam version of this game but I already recommend it. I played Lili as soon as it came out for iOS and in my review of the game then I gave it high marks. I give them again this time around.

The best part of Lili for me is that it is full of humor and I actually had a very powerful emotional response to part of the story. It's really that good. But let me pause to point out the one flaw I see in the game.

Unfortunately, punctuation is sloppy and visually stands out against such a flawless graphical backdrop. Admittedly, I'm a stickler for quality writing with careful, consistent use of punctuation and spelling as much as an engaging text. Sadly, this is seemingly the only unpolished bit of Lili. Also, while I appreciate the quirky descriptions and tongue-in-cheek collectibles, there is unexpected semi-questionable content for astute readers.

That being said, I love the feel of this game so get ready for more gushing. The graphics are stunning with beautiful art direction and an immersive environment. This is even truer in the Steam version. It's funny that it looks as I remember it but then when I checked screenshots from my iPhone playthrough, I realized what time and effort really went into this port. The graphics are redone and gorgeous on the big screen!

Lili is a great hero and it's nice to see a nonsexualized female lead. She can be taken seriously and is genuinely likeable. She is also fun to control both on iOS and Steam. I like the control options and found the use of the mouse to give a bit of precision to the main "battle" mechanic of the game. I use quotes because there really are no fights other than plucking plants from the backs of spirits and this unique twist is actually very engaging and serves as both a sort of mini game as well as a well tuned challenge in progression.

Finally, I really like the new listings of characters because at the end of the day, they are what made my first experience with Lili so memorable. I look forward to playing through the rest of this game once more and hope you pick it up as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998799468', 'num_games_owned': 3639, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1456022499}
review: Disregard the developers' description of this game completely.  It oversells to an almost grotesque degree, as other reviewers have already explained better than I could.  That being said, I devoured this game in its (short) enitirety, playing it every free second I could. It's friendly, fun, and entirely light-hearted in a way you seldom see in a video game of this high quality. Playing it is like putting life on easy mode and just smiling the hours away.  As corny as that sounds, it's true.  This game turned me into a happy little girl from beginning to end and I would do it all over again. Highly recommended, just get it on sale because it's VERY brief.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034183306', 'num_games_owned': 1779, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1409858752}
review:
Certainly enjoyable, so I'll recommend it. It's quirky, and pretty.

However, it's very shallow (it's basically a bit of exploration and some QTEs), short (2 hours ish), and repetitive. Still fun, though. Moreso for a younger audience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032539699', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1403850989}

author: {'steamid': '76561198074005012', 'num_games_owned': 2430, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1409566601}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is gorgeous; like, really gorgeous. The art design mixes extremely well with the engine and there's just enough bells and whistles to compliment the overall look. Characters are lively and reminiscent of a Pixar film. Environments are vivid and pleasing to the eye. It is also clever in its writing and references to boot.
But alas, as pretty as this game is to look at, the main mechanics that hold the whole thing together are just not that fun. I don't need combat in every game; I don't need to kill, but the "combat" mechanics in this game (picking flowers) are not that fun and are extremely compartmentalized from the rest of the experience whilst also lacking any depth or nuance to speak of. The game would have been better having significant puzzle solving in the environments or even just making the combat a part of the interaction with the world instead of an activated sequence.
I can't recommend this game as anything more than a very pretty moving picture to boot up. That's not much of a recommendation for people looking for GAMES.

review:
Lili es un juego de aspecto simpatic√≥n, con personajes monos y en un escenario de fantas√≠a... y ah√≠ se quedan sus bondades. El t√≠tulo consiste en explorar una isla mientras dialogas con diversos personajes, y cumples varias misiones.

Jugablemente se limita a ir de A a B (se√±alado en la mayor√≠a de casos en el mapa) recogiendo flores, para posteriormente hablar con un personaje y poner rumbo a otro punto. author: {'steamid': '76561198075220826', 'num_games_owned': 849, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1409053012}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043563993', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1420412006}
review:
beautiful, but way too short. i finished the game in about four hours. i was really disappointed, because i wanted to see more of the island, and meet more of the locals. i walked across a bridge, saw a house surrounded by pine trees, and couldn't wait to get down there, but it had turned out that i couldn't access that area.
movement is limited; there are set paths you can take, and you can see some areas you would think you could venture into, but can't. it doesn't feel very open, i never really truly felt like i was exploring (which is funny, because sometimes lili describes herself as an explorer).

there's only one boss, at the very end of the game, but he handles exactly the same as every other enemy you've beaten in the game before. defeating him was a little anti-climactic, especially since he's only [spoiler]the mayor[/spoiler], and i expected some more powerful (both politically and in strength) enemies.

this game is full of memes and references. some of the enemy profiles will give you a good chortle, as well.

the way you need to defeat enemies is unique if you use a mouse and keyboard, but if you use a controller, all battles will solely be quick-time events. i liked how, with a mouse, you actually had to pull flowers out of the ground, but with the controller, you could just press A, and i found that significantly less fulfilling.

the story is mediocre.
there is no end-game.
you cannot max all skills (to my knowledge).
there are barely any guides for this game, so it's difficult to find help for anything not related to vanity items.

overall, like many of the $10 games on steam, it's only worth buying if you can get it for at least 50% off. if you can't buy it, just go look at some screenshots - you won't be missing anything.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090366497', 'num_games_owned': 710, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1408880006}
review:
So a rather mixed review, which in itself is odd because I rather loved this game. You play as Lili on an exceptionally child friendly island where you beat the baddies by plucking flowers from their heads, which temporarily ... well I'm not really sure, makes them go off in a huff? They are always available for a rematch if you want to. The island itself is beautiful, the gameplay is reasonable although it very much shows its phone/tablet based roots and the story is charming, although firmly aimed at a younger audience.

So what could possibly be wrong with it?
Well first up the price. It is a very short game with quite a hefty price tag. I got it as part of a bundle so I'm good, but in general I would not advise paying full price for this unless you really don't need... money.

Secondly it advertises itself as two things, one is an RPG. Whilst you have three stats that you can upgrade this doesn't make it an RPG in the sense that most people would understand. The other is the line that references "Zelda, Broken Age, or Psychonauts" all of which I love, but all of which have pretty much no bearing on this game unless it's something along the lines of "if you ripped practically everything out of one of those games and then shortened it massively... then here's Lili!"

So yeah... it's a beautiful, short, kid friendly game with lovely visuals, a fun story, funny characters, decent gameplay... but it's overpriced and very misleadingly advertised.

Some of the achievements are also a bit hiccup-y with one refusing to trigger, some not counting/triggering correctly, and unfortunately the grindy ones are tied to a single savegame which is a shame because shifting that to a global variable would have made replaying a great option rather than just running round a completed game picking flowers and kicking vases...

author: {'steamid': '76561198066339830', 'num_games_owned': 4107, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1408798805}
review:
While I have to praise the graphic quality, which is gorgeous and cute, there are some very notable concerns over Lili game as a whole.

Taking its former form as mobile games, Lili is notably short, prolly six hours or so. Ten if you intend to complete everything. No no, it's not a problem and sometimes I appreciate a short game. Then again, because there's a template of mobile game, you can immediately notice it. The gameplay revolves around fighting enemies with tap and drag combination mechanic - a pretty much suitable one for mobile. Not to mention the simplicity of the puzzles for game progression. Well, after all, this is aimed for casual game, so if you want more challenge forget it.

Moreso, there is no voice acting and so it's kinda annoying to see 'Hi' 'Hello' 'Hmpphh' being used all over the maps. This is for me a major negative score for Lili.

Story is... err... very forgettable.

The Developer took care and added gamepad support. Most of the times I'd use controller whenever a game supports it, but for Lili I'd rather go with KB/M - much quicker and precise that way. The control schema I used was WASD/MMORPG-like, and it was smooth enough for the whole time I spent here.

Still, for a buck I spent on it, I wouldn't complain. I got my money's worth (after all I've beaten the game, that's an... achievement by itself), and I'm sure you would also if you can find a bargain elsewhere. Not worth full price, however, because of reasons I wrote above.

Final verdict 6.5/10 - sweet game to take a break from your serious gaming session.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004269296', 'num_games_owned': 659, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1407295178}
review:
This game entirely changed the way I view gaming. Prior to this, I honestly believed a game just had to either have good gameplay or a good narrative to hold my interest. Lili: Child of Geos has neither of these things, but what it does have is an amazing sense of place and a beautiful aesthetic.

Gameplay wise, the game is mediocre. You largely wander around doing minor fetch quests while chasing ghosts. You can read other reviews for specifics on the gameplay, but what's important is to remember that this was originally an iOS game. Grabbing flowers off the ghosts while avoiding hazards is incredibly difficult and unintuitive with a mouse. It's not "unfun" but it's certainly not optimized for a keyboard-mouse style of input.

Narratively, the game is pretty average. I really enjoyed the characterization of Lili as a grad student, and some of the minor characters had a few amusing lines, but the actual story and characters are paper thin. If you're looking for a game with a story that leaves you wanting more or characters who you'll remember a week after you play it, this isn't the right place for you.

Aesthetically though, dear god, does this game have aesthetic power in spades. Just look through the screenshots and trailer to get an idea. The game is gorgeous and, on top of that, it has an art style that you can't really find anywhere else. Usually games that put all their attention into graphics go for a pure fantasy build, or something dark and gritty. This game pumps graphical power into childish whimsy and it pays off like crazy. You will never play another game with an atmosphere of innocence and fun like Lili imparts on its players.

Overall, I recommend this game to people who are specifically looking to enter a beautiful world unlike any other in gaming. I'm not sure it's quite worth the standard price, but it's well worth nabbing it on a sale if you can. However, if you're looking for the next big gameplay or narrative adventure, give this one a pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062239205', 'num_games_owned': 638, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1593867302}
review:
Got thru the game with most of the achievements in under 5 hours.
Although for some reason I didn't get credit for some of the achievements :(
Anywho, Lili: Child of Geos is a good casual game.
The only three negatives things I have to say about it are:
1. No back story/intro. They just plop you onto an island with no information and you piece most of the story together throughout the game.
2. No voice acting. Great, story telling games do not need voice acting, however this is not one of those games and even though the story was pretty good, it would of really elevated it if the characters had voices.
3. No replay value. You are basically playing the same minigame over and over again. Sure you can get a better score, but that gets tedious. You do have a choice near the end of the game that I suppose can give you two different endings, but since the beginning to that point would be the same, I do not think it is worth it.

I do recommend this game as it is interesting and different, just not at full price.

review: Bist du Mann genug eins der sch√∂nsten und kreativsten Spiele zu probieren? Traust du dich ein Gef√ºhl zwischen Urlaub, Kindheit und Traum zu erleben? Dann spiele Lili: Child of Geos!

author: {'steamid': '76561198085513425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1408213307}
review:
Ein Liebhaber von Rollenspielen war ich nie wirklich aber seitdem ich Kingdoms of Amalur gespielt habe,hat es mich doch gepackt! Auch bei Lili Child of Geos bin ich begeistert.

Die Story ist doch recht unspektakul√§r. Ein M√§dchen m√∂chte f√ºr die Schule Blumen von der Insel Geos haben und f√§hrt mit einen Boot hin.Gleich zu Anfang begegnen uns merkw√ºrdige Gestalten aus Holz,sie sind die Bewohner,sind meistens nett aber es gibt auch andere,wie der Mayor,der uns von der Insel treiben will.Sonst sammelt man Blumen,zerst√∂rt T√∂pfe mit n√ºtzigen Zeug drin oder Schatzkisten,die man auch mit Gl√ºck findet.Nat√ºrlich sind auch Quests erledigen,eine unserer Aufgaben.

Die Charakter sind,wie ich finde super gemacht,sehr herzlich und sch√∂n detailiert. Lili,unsere Charakterin ist sehr schlagfertig und wei√ü was sie will und das mit viel Hingabe.Au√üerdem gibt es die sogenannten Spirits,sie sind vergleichbar mit gro√üen Waldgeistern,die am Anfang unsere gesammelten Blumen stehlen,die wir uns aber zur√ºckholen.Spirits muss man im Laufe des Spiels immer wieder Blumen abnehmen.

Die Quest sind wie gesagt und Haupt-und Nebenquests eigenteilt,was eigentlich so gut wie immer so ist.Alle aktuellen Quest sieht man √ºbersichtlich im Men√º.F√ºr jeden abgeschlossene Nebenquest bekommt man eine rote Blume,die wir auch gerne nehmen,da sie f√ºr uns im Spiel sehr wichtig sind.

Die Steuerung ist,dank meines Gamepads sehr leicht und habe bis jetzt auch keine Probleme mit Laggs oder Abst√ºrzen gehabt.

Die Grafik ist so sch√∂n,die Insel ist wirklich gut gemacht und es macht echt Spa√ü einfach nur durch die Gegend zu laufen und sich alles anzusehen! 

Fazit: Sehr sch√∂nes RPG,meinetwegen kann ich stundenlang Blumen sammeln und mit den Leuten reden.Lasst euch nicht von der Spielzeit beeinflussen,im Sale sollte man auf jeden Fall zuschlagen.Spiele jetzt schon seit 3 Stunden und es scheint doch noch etwas weiter zu gehen.Klare Kaufempfehlung,f√ºr alle die ein sch√∂nes RPG suchen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198047193030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1702097787}
review: I started out unsure about this game but as I went on I loved it. The story is cute and the humor is great. It's not for little kids however I think it's great for many ages (coming from a college student)  The game is that it is a little short, under 5 hours. Also the controls sometimes freaked out if you walked into somthing at a certain angle, and the steam acheviemnts aren't always responsive (mostly the ones for using items). To be fair though I didn't complete all the sides quests, but I also spent a lot of time running around getting flowers to save up for items. Although I can clearly see there is much more stuff I can get. I really hope they make a second game (looks like they were kind of hinting at it) The art, the money system, the mini map, and character development were all amazing. Definitely recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032148476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1407697354}
review: Ein Spiel, was sich eher an das j√ºngere Publikum richtet. Das erkl√§rt die relativ geringe Komplexit√§t von Quests und Karten,  der seichte Schwierigkeitsgrad und die kurze Spieldauer. Auch ist das Setting recht gewaltfrei, Holzgolems besiegen und Blumen pfl√ºcken sind da schon das Grausamste. Das Entdecken der Spielwelt macht Dank der guten und farbenfrohe Grafik jedenfalls viel Spass. Eigentlich ein netter Titel f√ºr seine Kids...aktuell jedoch nur in Englisch verf√ºgbar  (nur Text; mit z.T. anspruchsvollen Vokabeln), da stellt sich der Titel selbst ein Bein.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071831157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1407777905}
review: Tout d'abord, attention √† l'√©tiquette "RPG", car Lili a moins de caract√©ristiques de jeu de r√¥le qu'un Zelda. Cela dit, il s'agit d'un tr√®s beau jeu d'aventure/exploration, facile, et qui permet de se d√©tendre sans prise de t√™te. Les environnement que l'on visite sont magnifiques et tr√®s vivants. Le joueur a √† collecter de tr√®s nombreux objets permettant de r√©soudre diff√©rentes qu√™tes pour les √©tranges cr√©atures peuplant l'√Æle Geos et de "combattre" des esprits de mani√®re assez originale. Le sc√©nario est basique mais les dialogues ne manquent pas d'humour. Dommage qu'il soit n√©cessaire de comprendre l'anglais pour savoir ce que nous demandent les personnages car, en raison de l'univers et de la simplicit√© du soft, je recommanderai tout √† fait ce titre pour des enfants (ce qui n'enl√®ve absolument rien √† la qualit√© du jeu, entendons nous bien) .

author: {'steamid': '76561198033154252', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1407794091}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos came to Steam directly from iOS. Actually the original platform is self-explanatory and in such a way you shouldn't expect from the game something different from simple meditative observation of an island, to which the main character comes with a purpose of picking some flowers for her "research". 

What features does Lili: Child of Geos provide in order to entertain the player? Of course, flowers collecting goes first, then we have talking with inhabitants of a tiny world (which, by the way, looks just wonderful), then goes pots smashing, chests smashing, taking away flowers from local antagonists. At last we have upgrades purchasing, performed in order to speed up and ease all aforesaid procedures, making them even more convenient in such a convenient game. Actually, that's all. 

On the one hand Lili: Child of Geos is rather simple, but on the other hand a player, familiar with its essence, doesn't require anything more as the game is very unobtrusive. You don't need to do anything else except pressing a couple of buttons. You should just launch it and admire the fabulous design and stunning graphics, greatly improved in comparison with the mobile version. 

Consequently we have a beautiful exploration game, perfectly suitable for children and for those players who don't have enough free time. However, if you are a hardcore gamer, then consider your choice carefully, because it is quite possible that you will have to buy something different.

As for me: I played the game on my tablet and now I look forward to complete it in Steam and earn some achievements which, by the way, are rather easy, but will take some time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092087634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1407770444}
review:
I been attracted by the graphic, concept & style, but once I am in the game, really feel disappoint, the intro into the game is really way too simple, or I should say there are no intro at all.

once you start the game, you can straight away feel that this is a RPG game base more on story rather than many action can be done, I am not taking about action game, I meant it as things you can do. But this game shows weak story, nothing attract you at start, kinda feel boring.

and wait for sales to get this game, $20 usd is really way too expensive for this quality.

hope they improve more on interface, interaction & animation

author: {'steamid': '76561198063013389', 'num_games_owned': 1076, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1409781915}
review:
This is an odd little game!
Lili - Child of Geos is an open world adventure with light RPG elements which seems mostly oriented to younger audience. You play part of Lili, quirky graduate who has landed on an island with intelligent humanoid trees and masked "spirit" creatures with the mission of picking up all the rare flowers for her graduation thesis. Problem is, the flowers grow only on spirit's back, so she has to chase them, jump on their back and pluck flowers while they run frantically away. But not to feel bad for the spirits, cause they're all kinda jerks to the tree people who are basically their slaves.
It has definitely got my recommendation. Firstly I'll tell what's good about it, then what problems does it have and lastly a conclusion. 
Pluses:
+Graphic. Hands down. They're not exagerating the marketing pitch, the graphic is very nice for such a small, tablet-ported title, nice particle and filter post-proc effects hold on even to AAA modern game standards, and framerate smoothness is commendable. I couldn't manage to lower it under 60FPS anywhere - on rare loading points, on great city panoramas, anywhere! The framerate stayed rock solid stable. 
+Characters. Tree-people are generally original, are interesting, have charm and personality, and are diverse. Just the way it should be in an imaginative adventure game. Lili is really quirky and charming heroine. A bit simplified characterisation and motivation, which again begs the conclusion this was intended for younger players, but one can see she was written with heart.
+Interesting areas. Areas are full of collectibles, small side quests (which usually give cosmetic colectibles) and secrets. It's fun to explore them. Again though, although one can wander around nicely exploring, the areas aren't huge, and can be completely scanned fairly quickly. The game isn't 10s of hours long, more like 4-8h (at the time of writing I had 1.7h registerd and, as I understand other reviews, I'm somewhere around the half mark. On the other hand, the areas are diverse and look lovely all in all.
+RPG elements. Although somewhat shallow (4 skill gagues with some 5 stages overall) skill acquiring is a nice touch. Other RPG staple, equippable items is just cosmetic, but is my hat collection is even this early vide and fun to collect. Could have been more deep and flashed out, but better to have it like that than not at all. 
+Gameplay. As said, exploring the world overall is fun, plucking "minigames" arecahotic when played with mouse, but not too hard with few skill adjustments and prizes are satisfactory. Overall it does it's job well enough, although, yet again is somewhat simple.
Now the minuses:
-INABILLITY TO CHANGE KEYBINDINGS! I'm a leftie, goshdarnit, and having no possible option to change movement keys to anything other than wasd bothers me alot (if this review were just for me, I'd put here two minuses, 'stead of one). Arrow keys are already used for camera movement (which I already do with the mouse), so they're in the code, I just need an option to change them with wasd, but none exists. Connected to that is 
-GUI. It seems shody ('seems', not 'is'). It gets the job done, but it's obvious this is a tablet port, the buttons are huge on FHD and some standard shortcuts and usability options don't exist here. Nothing game-breaking, but it could have been better. 
-Shortness. The game has potential, could have been something much greater, but in it's heart it's a tablet game with tablet shortness. People are reporting around 6h gameplay time. Shame.
-+Odd quirks. I... kinda can't describe in detail, but at the moments I'm experiencing strange tonal dissonances in the game. I can't put my finger for whom the game speciffically is. If it's for younger and/or casual audience, then why are there lots of standard gaming touches about modern computer games, and their respectable memes. And rest of the game is depicted like fairytale like fantasy setting. It's not entirely clear how this setting is connected to our world. Lili goes to magical university so 9/10 times I think I'm in fantasysetting, then suddenly the tone shifts to strange and disturbing. Not that I mind, disturbing fairytale has become regular trope in itself (and e.g. I love AM's Alice MR) but it kinda clashes awkwardly. The game doesn't want to commit fully to weirdness, but sprinkles it around in odd bits. It's not a problem, but sticks like a scrapwe on your keyboard you know you'll get used to eventually, but which distracts first 10 times you feel it...
-Prize. For such a short game 20‚Ç¨ is a bit much. I bought it within a bundle, so it's definitely worth it, but full prize is a bit too much. Just a bit, but still.

Conclusion: Interesting short casual experience with awesome graphic, great exploration and fun story. The game's not a masterpiece, but it doesn't try to be one. 
I recommend it without a doubt, IF it's on a discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005057754', 'num_games_owned': 1274, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 1031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1608096952}
review:
The official description compares this game to Psychonauts, which is fair.  Both games have similar styles in humor (everyone, from Constructs to Spirits to Ominous Fish, has something silly to say to/about you) and design, so if you enjoyed Psychonauts for that aspect (like I did), then you'll enjoy Lili.

The gameplay is also fun.  It's an rpg-esque exploration game, interspersed with an interesting little mini game involving ripping flowers out of the backs of malevolent spirits (never thought I'd say that before).  The scenery is gorgeous, definitely encouraging exploration just by being too darn beautiful to want to leave.  And the minigame was kind of addicting; I wanted to keep playing it and beating each of my high scores, yes, but I also wanted to keep playing it because it was fun.

My only gripe is that the game felt too short.  A couple more quarters to explore (and maybe a few more outfits to collect) would have scratched that itch.  But hey, maybe in the sequel, right?  ;-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198106810138', 'num_games_owned': 2232, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1407470932}
review:
There is much to love here, and only a few things holding it back from complete greatness.
Lili: Child of Geos is an adventure game where you go around a gorgeous island collecting flowers for a school report.
The island is populated by Spirits and the wooden Constructs they've created to be their servants, you'll likely be doing something about that balance along the way since Spirits have the rarest flowers growing on their backs...

Yep, not a normal game this. There's no real combat, in lieu of that there's a minigame where you run after spirits (or take them by surprise using enviromental cover / invisibility potions), climb on their back and try to grab their flowers.
In defense the Spirit grows thorns and bombs. You have to press the buttons that are attached the flowers (more flowers) and to the bombs (less explosions in the face) whilst avoiding the buttons attached to thorns (because they're thorns).

It's not the deepest minigame ever, and you'll be playing it a lot, but there's a charm to it too, as there is to the entirety of the game.
There are 4 gorgeous areas in the game, a beachside town, a night-time town, a forest and... another town. They are decently sized, and filled with a variety of constructs to befriend and help out with little quests (~3-4 per area).
Among the way you'll be collecting flowers that grow around the area, smash pots to find gold and items useful for the mini-game, use keys (also found in jars or traded for flowers) to explore sealed off areas and find treasure chests containing a sizeable amount of gold and a Lore Item (collectible with a bit of backstory / reference).
That all sounds great, so what's the catch? The game is short, and you'll be doing just the things written above. An area can be cleared in ~20-40 minutes, clocking in the total game length at roughly 2 hours.
Other than that there are some technical hiccups, mostly related to achievements not triggering but I also got stuck a few times where the objective didn't tell me the correct next thing to do. Some of the older reviews actually mentioned problems so severe they had to restart to continue, this has since been patched out but it's still not the most flawless piece of code.
It was done by a team of five people though.

So, to summarize:
Pro:
[list][*]Gorgeous world and presentation
[*]Great protagonist
[*]Great secondary characters, both 'good' and 'evil'
[*]A plot that keeps you entertained[/list]

Cons:
[list][*]Short, like really short
[*]Technical hiccups
[*]Somewhat monotonous[/list]

All in all I'm super happy I picked up this game, and I look forward to what the developers will come out with next.

Mara.

review:
Wundersch√∂ner und einfacher Zeitvertreib f√ºr Zwischendurch, wenn man dem Englischen m√§chtig ist. Ich hatte sehr viel Freude mit diesem iOS-Port, auch wenn er sehr kurzweilig war. Die fast 20 Euro, die an sich daf√ºr veranschlagt wurden, w√ºrde ich daf√ºr trotzdem nicht ausgeben! Im Sale, oder einem Bundle definitiv eine Kaufoption! 

Lili ist, wie bereits in der Beschreibung angegeben, eine Art Adventure-RPG-Hybrid. Beides kommt aber eher zu kurz und haupts√§chlich ist es ein Geschicklichkeitsspiel, bei dem man per Maus Blumen vom R√ºcken des Gegners in kurzer Zeit sammeln muss. Es macht definitiv Spa√ü, wird aber nach einiger Zeit wiederholend. Ansonsten erwarten einen sch√∂ne Grafiken und eine nette, kleine Story ohne viel Tiefgang.

Wer es hat und spielt...

author: {'steamid': '76561198001581508', 'num_games_owned': 5825, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1408447263}
review:
If you like exploring games, simplistic controls and a great simple story this game is for you. 

Controls are easy, just move around with arrow keys or wasd and use the mouse to click or interact with things. 

Story is very well picked aswell the characters roles and their personality. 

The main character is a girl, yes a good looking one tho. 

Everything else beside beating spirits to pluck their red flowers, kick vases and plucking white flowers. There are hats,pets  and outfits which are funny to wear. (note: you get a special outfit when you finished the game)

TIPS: Once you are able to buy things from the shop, buy the golden key and the treasure map and you are way to go. 

Of course you have to upgrade your items you wear too so you can walk faster and such. 

At least the game has one mini game which has a bug tho. If you are out of flowers and you get to the difficult select screen simply press escape and you play the game for free but you still get rewards if you won :P.


Just grab this game and have fun. Somehow this game keeps you hooked till you finished it.


The only downside of the game which isn't a real issue is the lack of voices of the characters. You might hear a giggle or someone saying hello or hi but thats it :(.

Last note: The game has replayability, because:
1: you need/want to get each spirit 3 stars (for achievements), 
2: upgrading the stealth skill instead of grip and speed only (achievement again :D), 
3: just for fun because the game has a nice story.


Rate: 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197980195240', 'num_games_owned': 2018, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1407217890}
review:
PREFACE: I picked this game up for $3.00 (included with 4 other games) from a Groupees game bundle.

I cleared the game in 4 hours while unlocking everything, finding all items and beating every spirit with 3 stars. I can say that the game is very simple but the visuals are incredible and fit perfectly with the game. I would say this game is strongly suited for casual gamers and children. All in all it was a pleasant experience and I hope more games get developed with this game's engine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100846283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1469119241}
review:
This game inspires such mixed feelings in me. 

It's rather attractive and at times really humorous. There's a conscious, snarky kind of wit to it at times that I think is one of the major strengths in this game. It's very much aware of the type of game it is trying to be and I've always had a fondness for games that break the fourth wall so there's definitely no complaints from me about that. I love it. Give me more of it.

Lili? I actually really liked her as a main character. One of the main reasons I kept playing was to see what kind of sarcastic, funny little thing would come out of her mouth. The rest of the characters as well (and there are a lot of them that you can talk to) were great fun and I loved going around and talking to all of them. This is definitely a game that made me want to explore.

That being said...the actual premise of the game was pretty grating and got boring way too fast. Almost the entirety of the plot is made up of what is best described as a mini-game where you pick flowers off of villain characters. It's something that I can see working well on an iPhone game but as a computer game it is a little obnoxious. Even the side quests really amount to nothing more than open up a chest that is easily found and return the item in it to the person who mentioned it offhand.

The in-game menu can use some work too. Your quests/side-quests are listed in the most basic manner without really giving you information about it. And honestly, it's just...clunky and awkward looking.

You can tell a lot of love went into this game and I can see it easily becoming something wonderful but at the moment it's just in an awkward place between iPhone game and computer game and it suffers greatly for it. I got it on sale and I'm glad I did. I wasn't really spend near $20 on it in the state it is now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034855534', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1488037083}

author: {'steamid': '76561198007553741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1402242486}
review:
Spassig aber viel zu Kurz

Ich kann dieses Spiel zu diesem Preis leider nicht empfehlen, obwohl es eigentlich eine menge Potential hat.

PROs:

+ Sehr sch√∂ne Grafik/ Gutes Design (gerade f√ºr ein ehemaliges Mobile Spiel)
+ Interessantes Leveldesign
+ Obwohl es eigentlich nur ums einsammeln von Objekten geht, wird es nicht langweilig

CONs:

- Zu kurz! Und zu teuer!
- Die Welt ist viel zu Klein
- Einige Grafikfehler (Der √ºbergang von Hemd zu G√ºrtel beim Link Outfit)
- Eint√∂niges Design (Sammle drei rote Rosen)
- Beizeiten nerfige Steuerung (Man merkt das es urspr√ºnglich f√ºr Touchscreens designt wurde)

Fazit: Leider nicht zu empfehlen.

 F√ºr 20 ‚Ç¨ ist das Spiel zwar nicht allzu teuer, doch leider t√§uscht die nette Optik nur sehr begrenzt √ºber das eint√∂nige Missionsdesign hinweg. Das w√ºrde mir jetzt eigentlich f√ºr eine 6/10 reichen, aber daf√ºr ist das Spiel einfach zu kurz, ca. 4 Stunden hab ich gebraucht, und ich bin ziemlich lahm.

daher: 5/10 Sch√∂n aber zu wenig Substanz.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071536453', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1579390500}
review: I was very pleasantly surprised by this game. Rarely have I ever enjoyed a game as much as Lili: Child of Geos. I actually found myself laughing out loud. It has a great sense of humor and includes some surprising game references, a little bit of dark humor, and even some social commentary. It is also self aware and of course makes fun of itself. However it does have character development, albeit a little thin but no less profound, as Lili discovers what she truly wants from life. Better yet, it features some amazing hats and customization. Another surprise came after the game was over when I was waiting for the credits and only five names were listed. The small team makes one appreciate the game even more, and it is clear that it contributed to the intimate feel of the game and the coding humor *tips fedora*. Five out of five; would definitely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011358834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1404904460}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is a beautiful yet very simple game that won't appeal to everybody.

As someone who was looking for a change of pace from the average brown, explosion based gritty shooter, Lili: Child of Geos was an amazing pallet cleanser. A nice simple story set on a beautiful island with some really nice stand out characters and an easy yet enjoyable mechanic made for an enjoyable yet short experience that I would recommend to people looking for something a little different.

As mentioned above, the graphics in this game are superb, every area is crawling with life and every nook and cranny seems to have been paid a lot of attention. The character models as well are all unique and portray an enjoyable visual style that makes them feel much more alive as characters, even despite not being voiced. 

The dialogue of the game is light hearted and fun, even going so far as to almost break the fourth wall at times when mentioning some of the games obvious limitations. 

Sadly, the game isn't voice acted which feels like a slight let down. I feel it could of been the icing on the cake here but as mentioned the dialogue is interesting enough to read through. 

The actual second to second gameplay involves a lot of fetch quest like objectives and the whole game is very easy, you can complete it to 100% in about 4-6 hours but the gameplay isn't the draw here and sometimes the IOS roots of the game can be seen.  

Lili: Child of Geos is an experience more than a challenge, a nice vacation from the stressful and grim games that most of us play a lot and I loved it, here is hoping for a sequel!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970858682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1405108896}
review:
*Gnome Seal of Approval*
The main audience for this is probably kids. But that doesn't mean older people can enjoy it as well. Some of the jokes are clearly made for young adults. You advance by 'fighting' Spirits. Jump on their backs and pick the flowers growing there while avoiding thorns and bombs. Some light RPG elements lets you increase your grip when fighting spirits, speed for chasing them and sneaking for sneaking past guards.

Simple fun, cute characters. Not a game for all, but gnomes like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069035308', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1404958867}
review: If you had told me 24 hours ago that a game about deflowering people against their will would be my favorite game of the year, I would slap you upside the head and tell you to go back to your dammned Sword Art Online. Even though the premise is silly, and it tries a little too hard to be a Nintendo game, it's an amazing game. Honestly, I wouldn't expect a game this beautiful with such a unique premise to be a Steam game! It's a bit small, I beat it 100% in a little over 3 hours, and it doesn't start out on a very strong point at all. It would've done better with some sort of intro sequence, instead of throwing you directly into gameplay. I also wish it would've had some platformer elements, or, you know, a jump button. With all of the crates lying around in Split Wood, the kid in me was just dying to hop up on them and see where they lead! I could easily compare this game to a watered down Zelda meets Shadow of Collossus, with some LittleBigPlanet-esque characters and graphics.

YOU CAN EVEN GET A COMPLETE LINK COSTUME! FAIRY INCLUDED! (Don't worry, she doesn't yell HEY at you.)

Do yourself a favor and buy this game if you're into adventures that are more about exploring and having some fun in a pretty-looking world. Seriously.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056978538', 'num_games_owned': 920, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1239, 'last_played': 1408432373}
review:
[b]2nd edit[/b] I played this through again for a couple of the achievements. I enjoyed it much more the 2nd time, even though I thought it would be a chore to play through again. The characters were still amusing, the art and model work were still beautiful, even the 'fights' were more enjoyable than they were on the first playthrough. I have no idea why this would be, perhaps it's because I knew what not to expect from it 2nd time round. (I didn't really want to make my review any longer, but since my first impressions kind of sat on the fence, I thought it only fair to update it.)

[b]*edited as I feel my 'not so good  things' list was worded a bit more harshly than intended, also added to the good things list*[/b]

[b]Good Things:[/b]
+It's beautiful, no doubt about that.
+The character models are really well done.
+You can collect stuff. (Hats and pets and masks are usable.) (Lore items are useless they just go in to a collection page, but the descriptions can be fun to read.)
+Some of the dialogue is very humorous, and I have genuinely laughed out loud a few times, which I think is quite rare in most games. The humor feels very natural and not at all forced.
+some of the quests are well thought out and very enjoyable to do.
+most of the characters are quite memorable. I quite like the information fish.
+Haven't come across any bugs at all, it's as well polished as it looks. (UPDATE: achievement bugged for the locked doors)
+ Rematched 'fights' will spawn the opponent in the zone you're currently in.

[b]Not so good things:[/b]

-My number one in this list has to be the motion sickness.
There's currently 2 choices of camera movement ...
fps style is bad if you suffer from motion sickness.
mmo style is better but the camera still swings enough and there's a motion blur to the sides when you turn that may make you feel ill if you have this problem. Sometimes Lili runs into things you weren't expecting and the camera can stop in a nausea and dizziness inducing way, so if you're one of those people affected by this I'd keep in mind that this [b]may[/b] be a problem for you before buying it. For me this is ok to play in short bursts.

-you can buy 'new' outfits, but they're not new, they're just recolors of the original one, which given the attention to detail in the landscape and models made this a bit disappointing when I first came across the shop, although I do find it hard to imagine Lili wearing anything else.
Perhaps if there was another area of body customization like accessories (bangles, necklaces, leggings, face paint, belts, hair accessories etc) even the same outfit but a patterned shirt, logo on the shirt, butterfly on the shorts....anything, instead of just being recolored, and ideally, for me, these items would drop with a fairly low drop rate (instead of being bought) to make vase kicking and the associated achievement more fun.
There wouldn't be that much work involved in altering the mesh to turn the shorts in to a mini dress either, which I think would quite suit Lili. (edit: I see at the very end you unlock an outfit that is exactly this, which is a shame since it probably means we'll never see this mesh recolored or retextured since it's a "special" item.)
I'm a fan of loot and stuff to equip, what can I say :P

-"Fights" are unique, but I don't enjoy them as much as I enjoy the quests, and since my play-time is limited due to the motion sickness, I've taken to ignoring them at this point (which isn't as game breaking as it sounds) and just doing the quests instead. I'll get them done eventually just for the achievements and the masks they drop (which are wearable) if you beat them with 3 stars.
I'd love to have the lore items be usuable as some kind of limited use tool in fights which would also make the collecting of those items and the fights themselves more entertaining.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
I think the developers are still adding things to the game, so I'm going to go with recommend as there's still a chance of new things being added, and hopefully a 3rd camera option that's motion sickness friendly =D

For me, to be worth it's full asking price, it really needs more usable items and, given the lack of a real talent tree, some more variation in ways you can play to win the fights, like I said previously, I'd use the lore items to achieve this, giving them a purpose in the process.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998159333', 'num_games_owned': 1346, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1404449691}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is a love letter to classic 3D adventure games but overall runs a bit long. You could easily burn through its content in a day but the majority of it sadly gets very repetitive very fast. At $20.00, it's a hard sell I'd argue.

You're dropped onto the island of Geos as Lili, a college student persuing a Vege-Magical degree, and become embroiled in a conflict between the island's ruling Spirits and their servant Constructs. Lili's pursuit is not entirely selfless (at first). She's here to study the flowers that dot the island, which most conveniently grow from the backs of the Spirits, forcing her to spend a majority of the game delicately plucking them from her enemies. 

As a central mechanic, the spirit combat is great and well realized. The chase to catch a spirit followed by the aforementioned flower picking is great fun, hampered only by the finicky controls thinking you want to stop and either pick flowers or smash jars when you're in hot pursuit. Lili's origins as a tablet game really show up here, as the plucking mechanic has you selecting a flower and dragging it away from a spirit to collect it.  It is fun perhaps the first handful of times, but given that there are over fifty spirits in the game to fight with little variety aside from the number of obstacles that crop up on a spirit, it does make the game's pacing drag if you are going for 100%. 

Geos has a lot of bright and colorful details to its world, and it is fun to just wander around the island and see what's in it as the Constructs go about their business. While not a fully realized world like in Deadly Premonition or Majora's Mask, where the characters all follow a set schedule, Geos nonetheless is a delight to get lost in for a few hours and take in the scenery.

It's also good to see Lili realized as a character; she has no love interest and she has no need of someone to come save her. As a plucky protagonist with ideas for what she wants to do with her life, Lili stands up for herself in a game that, while it has action, is at its core a non-violent experience, barring how you feel about picking flowers off the backs of monsters.

It's not a perfect game and suffers from having too many spirits to fight through, but for a quick delightful romp Lili's journey to Geos is one worth undertaking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022750630', 'num_games_owned': 1623, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1404222000}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is one of the bizarrest games I ever played: an open-world flower picking simulator with a stroke of the RPG-brush.

You play Lili, who visits an inhabited island to collect flowers for a school project. But she does not pick these flowers from the fields or gardens, she only picks the ones that grow along the streets and on the monsters.
Yes, this game features flower-picking based fighting. You chase a monster and then, during the actual fight, you pluck flowers off the monster. Maybe using the mouse makes it too easy, but I never lost one of these fights.
To be fair, this fighting model makes more sense on a touchscreen device. This is not as surprising since earlier editions of Lili: Child of Geos were published for mobile devices. And after all, it seems new and creative to me.

But the open world of Lili: Child of Geos offers a bit more than flower picking. You can explore, collect stuff, talk to people and solve sidequests which consist of exploring, collecting stuff and talking to people.
Lili: Child of Geos is rather short and small. It took me about three or four hours to do the main quests, all the side quests and get all the nonrespawning collectibles. 

On a more negative side, this game features no voice acting, only textboxes. 

So, was Lili: Child of Geos any fun for me? Yes, but not 20‚Ç¨ worth of fun, more like 10‚Ç¨. 
Conclusion: If you need a tiny charming open-world game for inbetween with an uhmm innovative fighting mechanic and this game is on sale, then give it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981102849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1564231086}
review:
This game is a port from the iOS game with the same name sans subtitle. It's not a shoddy port though; on the contrary, the graphics got a gigantic overhaul and it's very pretty to look at.

However, it is way too easy and very light on content. You are picking flowers, open chests for items (which have no value whatsoever aside from just collecting them) or kick pots for money (flowers can also be traded for money). Even the "combat" is a flower picking game. The money can be used for items that aid you in the game but it's so easy that it hardly matters at all. Quests are about going from A to B and back or finding something. That's about it. Even if you take your time in 4 to 6 hours you'll have found and seen about everything there is (that includes all side missions).

My other gripe is with the story / dialogue, which is inconsistent. Some of it is complete nonsense, and/or seems to not fit at all. Other parts hint at much more going on than what's actually happening, but there's no plot twist or real surprise. It also swaps back and forth between whimsical and serious far too often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117720401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1465010921}
review:
So Lili: Child of Geos is a quirky, lite RPG, and action-adventure game. The mechanics are simple and easy to understand for gamers of most ages (granted those gamers can read), and the rest of the game is made to be a family friendly adventure. Combat and violence is replaced with a fun little mini-game (which feels awkward on the mouse at first, but you'll get used to it) where you chase enemy spirits across the island, hop onto their backs, and pluck Spirit Flowers off to weaken them while avoiding the thorns and bomb plants that grow there as well. After defeating a spirit you can earn a score and a rating measured in stars, if you earn 3 stars you'll also get a colored version of that spirits mask (there are also fifty unique spirits to encounter, so that means 50 unique masks to unlock). Outside of that minigame, the rest of the game sees you running or walking around the island of Geos, slowly unlocking new zones to explore freely and to find new spirits to defeat inside. The exploration of these zones remind me a little of The Wind Waker, as the island is bright, colorful, and actually very pretty (especially on the highest settings). Unlike Wind Waker though, there are no dungeons to explore (unfortunately) but there are a lot of fun little puzzles to undertake, quests to do for the wood-construct citizens of Geos, and every time you enter a zone, a whole batch of Spirit Flowers (the same kind that grow on the heads of Spirits) spawns in random places for you to collect. Unfortunately a few bugs appear where flowers will grow inside walls or under bridges or just places you can't reach, and there are the occasional clipping issues that block Lili off from small areas she should be able to access, or temporarily stick her into the environment (only happened once for me, but it took me five minutes of running in a circle to get her free), and the zones themselves really aren't too large. However you will find yourself scouring these zones over and over while hunting for spirits, treasure chests, and flowers and the zones are well designed and so different from each other they surprisingly don't get old after a few hours of playing, and with the flowers you find you can sell them for gold coins (used to buy outfits, upgrades, and powerups for taking on spirits), trade them for keys (one key will open any lock on the island, but is destroyed after each use) so you can loot or explore the various houses and shops on the island, or you can use the flowers to gamble with in a minigame I found quite easy (probably just because I have good eyes and reflexes) to try and earn even more gold coins.
      I bought the game on a whim because it was on sale and looked cute, and surprisingly it is now my favorite game of all time, simply because it is so fun, cute, and happy it always makes me feel good when I play, no matter how poopy I feel before loading it up. I've already finished the game (it is rather short unfortunately, but I've heard you can play it for about 40 hours before collecting every single hat, outfit, lore item, mask, pet, and completing every quest) but I want to keep playing it and try getting the game's other ending and explore the bird poop mechanic a little bit more. Yes, there is a bird poop mechanic where if you run too fast while scaring birds, the poor things will fly away and poop all over Lili, leaving rainbow colored droppings all over the girls face and clothes (this always makes me laugh because she always has a calm smile on her face throughout the game).
     So would I recommend this game? Yes, however the majority of Hardcore gamers probably wouldn't like the game for much more than the billions of references to Dark Souls, Oregon Trail, Mario, Zelda, Minecraft, Prometheus (yes, the movie), and much more. Children would probably love the colors and characters, but a lot of jokes and dialogue would probably be wasted on them. But if you're a total nerd who wants to play a peaceful game that'll just make you laugh and give you at least 3 to 5 hours of sheer happiness (that's the minimum time to beat the storyline), you'll probably love it as much as I do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079845711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1403381775}
review:
Very nice graphics, the game is beautiful. The game is full of nice jokes and fun characters, though some moments have a darker edge to it, overplayed by the bright surroundings. Great colours, everything is shiny and bright, a joy to look at.

Even though the controls with the controller are neither configurable nor actually explained, it works well. Every key binding for the items are displayed for keyboard only which may lead to some item waste as you try and figure out which controller button does which. But control is tight and during the spirit fights the controller buttons are shown correctly.

There's no speech in the game, but that - for me - only added to the charm. I felt reminded a lot of the Wind Waker, one of my favourite games as a kid. The inspiration clearly came from that game.

Unfortunately, the game is awfully short. You only need 3-4 hours to collect everything and defeat every spirit. The items are not really necessary here - though I only played on normal. And even though the game is so short, the fights with the spirit get a tad repetative near the end. Defeating all 52 of them brings nothing to the game, and almost every fight is the same. And replay value is nigh zero, the story is linear and everything is collectible in the first run.

I have enjoyed the game so far but I can't really recommend it for full price. Though the game is beautiful, runs well and has a cute main character, it's just too short. Be sure to grab it on a discount, though.
