author: {'steamid': '76561197979084213', 'num_games_owned': 4499, 'num_reviews': 1010, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1400312476}
review:
Wow, the graphics for this game are just adorable. Colorful, cute, plenty of detail in the environments and (mostly) sharp textures. 

But gameplay wise you can tell it was designed with mobiles in mind, because there's a mini-game where you have to use the mouse to pluck flowers and the gameplay and story are rather shallow. 
The player has to find red flowers by chasing spirits and solve mini-quests ('quests' would be too big of a word, since they usually take a couple of minutes to complete), among other things (like plucking white flowers and opening treasure chests). That's all there is to it really. There isn't much to do, except for a couple of small sidequests.

You can also level up the character in several ways, but these character upgrades are mostly useless because I didn't seem to experience much of an improvement. Experienced gamers in general won't find the gameplay difficult anyway. There's no health bar, you can't die. The only thing that can happen is that you get thrown off the back of a spirit and even then you can try again without any problems. And there are also potions that you can use to speed up your character, make her invisible or that allow you to throw a bomb in order to stun enemies.

Lili Child Of Geos also isn't a long game. I was able to complete it in 2-3 hours. Which was more than enough because the gameplay becomes very repetitive after these couple of hours.

I still think the game is worth the money, if only for the beautiful graphics and for the first few areas. And who knows, maybe they can flesh things out for a possible sequel, make things a bit more interesting ? I'd like to see one, in any case.

[Rating: 76/100]

author: {'steamid': '76561198059265162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1399928874}

author: {'steamid': '76561197989970487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1400312113}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos. a gorgeous looking game that plays on the Island of Geos. An lushes island filled with friendly characters called Constructs. You play as Lili, a girl who traveled to the island to find rare flowers for her school project.

During your stay you will find out that the friendly constructs are being oppressed by the spirits, and mostly the Mayor of the island who is also a spirit. It is you job to help these constructs out and collect flowers and other collectibles a long the way.

Well i will leave it at there story wise, cause we would not want to spoil to much. While the game originally came out on the iOS, it does not feel like a mobile game. The graphics look amazing and you get really sucked in to the world of Geos. There are 4 parts of the island you can explorer, each with their own unique look and feel. You are free to explorer the island as you wish, and help the inhabitants of the island.

Gameplay wise you have to collect flowers and find loot on the island. You go around explorer and kick open chests or break vases, while also grabbing every flower you can. For people that are really into collecting items, and exploring every nook and cranny of games, this would be a must have for you. Picking flowers can also be done by jumping on the back of spirits and plucking all their flowers of their heads, to find the rare red flowers. A fun little mini game to spice things up with a bit of action.

The 4 hours i spend so far in this game have been awesome, and i really like the experience of it, by doing something different and bringing the story in a funny way across. The 4 hours i played also meant i finished the game, so it isn‚Äôt a long game, but well worth the money in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034199687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 332, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1399820467}
review:
Recommended with several "buts".

FIrst of all this isn't a Zelda-type ARPG like you might think (I'm the first being guilty to buy everything for PC labeled Zelda-like) by looking around the reviews as all battles actually take place in a wonky mini-game meant for touch-screens. It has the feel of Zanzarah without the fairy battles.
It's casual play, short and riddled with some bugs especially the achievements. You only have a single save-slot. At 20 bucks it's overpriced, should be 10 butr devs need to feed their kids and all that.

You do run around, talk to strange people, do them quests, smash pots for items, pick flowers and get equipment still I'd file this as an action-adventure. At the core it's a collectathon.

It is a pretty game though with a cute protagonist and an addictive gameplay so yes recommended. It's also safe for kids. Just don't go in having high expectations and get it when it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041714438', 'num_games_owned': 5288, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1400950485}
review:
Lili is a short, casual, visually exceptional 3D adventure game that's heavy on atmosphere and charm but light on story and variety. 

Pros:
- Visuals are gorgeous. It does not look at all like a mobile port and has some of the best visuals I've come across in an indie game.
- Fully 3D world that you can wander around in at your own pace.
- Nice atmosphere. The island is populated with lots of whimsical characters and the game oozes charm.
- Non-violent, suitable for children old enough to have a fair degree of reading comprehension but also accessible for adults. (I realize this may be a con for some who are looking for a more meaty sort of game)
- Unique. It's a bit different than pretty much everything else out there.

Cons:
- Not the greatest value considering the price to length ratio. I like short games but $20 for a few hours play feels a bit steep to me.
- Game play is rather repetitive. You do the same few things for the entire game, namely collect items and play the same sort of quicktime mini game in lieu of actual battles. This is somewhat forgivable given the very short length of the game however.
- The 4 zones are small and there's not much interaction with the environment.
- Story is rather thin and there is no intro; you just get plopped in.
- [strike]Only partial controller support. The developer states full controller support is in the works. At present you can run around the world, collect items, check your map and talk to npcs with the controller but going into menus and playing the mini game battles requires keyboard and mouse.[/strike]
- Full controller support has now been added. Sort of. They basically did a virtual mouse pointer that the left analog stick controls but it feels very shoehorned in as an afterthought rather than controls designed around a controller. Control directions in the UI still don't reference the controller when you are using it either.

Neutral:
- RPG elements are quite lite. That's not a con. The game is what it is, but calling the game an "RPG hybrid" while not technically incorrect, may give an inaccurate impression. There's some very minor leveling and skill progression but don't expect hitpoints, skill trees and such.
- No voice acting. The game is fine without it but I feel it would have added that extra bit to draw you in even more. Also it would allow for younger children to play. As non-violent games are somewhat rare, it seems especially suited for young children but the amount of reading creates a bit of an age barrier.
- Feels like a missed opportunity in some ways. The visuals and atmosphere are excellent and the game well done as is, but part of me feels like it could have been so much more with more variety and length.
- A couple of aspects still feel like a game created around touch input, namely the mini game where you pull flowers which is a major part of the game. Also the level up menus with the big wide buttons to hit and just the general sort of largeness of the UI. These do work just fine with a mouse though.
- The battle / mini games on the keyboard and mouse have a totally different feel than on the controller. The former has a more tactile almost Angry Birds type of feel with pulling while the latter feels more like DDR. I'm not sure which I like better. They're very different.

I enjoyed Lili for what it was, a unique, short, charming and visually stunning adventure game but part of me wished it to be more than it was, that it were much longer, the quests more complex, that Lili had companions, there were more choices etc. The game does end leaving future adventures for Lili a possibility so perhaps a sequel could be based around the PC platform from the beginning this time and more complex. It's a fun possibility to contemplate.

This isn't to say that Lili is incomplete. It's not, it's just a short and casual game. Sometimes it's nice to have those as a break or when you don't want to get into huge commitment with a new game. 

The $20 price point I feel is a bit high for the short length of the game but if this sort of game appeals to you I'd recommend it when it goes on a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989963376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1419775368}
review:
Lili is one of the most beautiful, addictive adventure games I have played in a while. The gameplay loop has an amazing difficulty curve that always keeps you challenged and the art direction and visual fidelity is a wonder to look at. 

I highly recommend Lili for anyone who is looking to get lost in a new (and often hilarious) world and never want to come back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042470569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1399749398}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos
4/10

First of all i have to say: If you buy the game, you probably won't get what you've expected. The game itself is a charming little piece of entertainement, but after reading the steam-description i just expected something completly different. I would not say that it's an RPG ( but some might call it one); To me, it just doesnt look like an RPG, more like a game that's made to have some points an RPG needs while beeing a mix of puzzle, minigames and collecting stuff. For example: You get something like a "Skilltree" but it doesn't really matter where you put your points, since you won't get any new abilities. As I said, the game is okay, its colorful, it cheers you up when playing it, but it is not what steam promises you.

The game itself is, as i said, a mix between puzzling, running around, minigames and collecting stuff (a lot of stuff). If you're into that, you'll be just fine, but if you hate spending too much time running back and forth while collecting items that add absolutely nothing to the game, then you'd might regret buying this. 

The Graphics are pretty good, but I was told to have low standarts. The Characters are lovely designed and you can feel that the developers really cared about every single friend or foe you face throughout the game. However, the story is rather basic. I don't want to spoil anything, so just let me say this: The story feels like a weak version of another game (if you know what i mean.. you probably don't.) There's just not much depth in the story, you spend way too less time with the characters to really get into it. When I first saw the game i kind of expected a heavy story, so i was a little disappointed. But again, not every story has to be deep.

The gameplay is very repetitive, but this does not matter that much because the game is rather short. Just let me tell you, the "quests" you get sound all the same, you have 3 items you can use and every "battle" is exactly like the one you fought before. 

Overall Lili; Child of Geos is a game to play when you don't want to start a biiiig, looong game with a deep story. Its a game you choose to play when you have little time but still want to enjoy a good game. I personally give it a thumbs down because it is a fine little game, but nothing like you'd expect after reading the description.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986850971', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1656632761}
review:
Charming, enjoyable.  It isn't that hard of a game but the appeal is mostly to explore.  It's a beautiful game, worthy of exploration at that.  Comedy in the game is just as charming as the game looks.  I enjoyed it.   It's a wonderful break from more violent video games.  

I dare not say more, there isn't much to say.  I have no choice to give it a thumbs up, definitely for how few actually worked on this project, they deserve that thumbs up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013453018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1399739961}
review:
Short but sweet, if I had to summarize in one sentence. A game I think people of all ages could enjoy depending on what they're looking for. For younger kids you have a virtually non-violent, beautiful and funny place to explore. Older audiences might find entertainment in the occasionally dark humor and the game's weird inhabitants. 

Gameplay-wise [i]Lili: Child of Geos[/i] is a very short game. I'd estimate around three hours of casual play. If you're going for collectibles and a perfect ranking against all enemies you may add two or three extra hours of game time. It's not a very challenging game either if you play on easy or medium. During the game you will attempt to "de-flower" spirits walking about the game world. You do this by playing a sort of minigame where you drag and drop flowers and other items off a spirit's head. You can tell this game mechanic was designed for the use of a touchscreen, which isn't too strange as this is a PC remake of a mobile game, but the developers made it work fairly well with a mouse. Depending on your skill, you'll master this part of the game quickly. It does get progressively harder as the game goes on, but it never reaches a level that will really challenge you and have you retry beating a spirit more than a couple of times. I have yet to play the hardest difficulty setting though. There are three settings, of which I played the middle one.

Controls are a bit wonky. Camera control takes a bit getting used to. Mouse sensitivity have only four presets which is the part I found the most annoying about the game. Some weird collisions here and there. Otherwise well made. 

Would I recommend it? Yes, but try to find a bit of gameplay to watch before you decide whether or not to purchase [i]Lili: Child of Geos[/i]. It's a game best enjoyed if you go at it with a relaxed attitude. If you're up for exploration and fun in short bursts. It would be easier to recommend this game if it had been cheaper. I don't really think the price suits the length or content of the game. But all in all I'm having fun with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971723254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1399724422}
review:
Having sailed to the island of Geos for a school project, you are tasked with gathering up rare flowers to report back to your professor.
However something is not quite right on the island and you soon discover that the constructs (creatures created from wood) are slaves to their masters; the spirits and their Mayor.

You decide to unshackle the local natives from their forced labour by doing them favours in exchange for flowers and other rare items. The island is full of life, its characters witty and charming where I couldn't help but laugh at some of the dialogue that was exchanged.

Where its similarities between Zelda lie are based around the Islands and town hubs which you would find in a Zelda game.
Imagine taking those areas from Wind Waker and putting them on this island. The exchange of dialogue is something you would find straight out of a Zelda game. Don't expect voiced characters but instead small sound bites like "Hi", "Bye" and other gasps throughout the dialogue.
Don't expect to be crawling dungeons and having a boss fight. This is not where its comparison with Zelda lies.

There are lots of Easter eggs to discover throughout the Island in treasure chests that reference some classic Nintendo games. Another character will throw some Video game trivia at you, asking you to guess what game it is referencing. "Praise the Sun".

Hats can be found in treasure chests and by doing services for the locals. Masks can be unlocked by beating Spirits.

As a collectathon it has similarities to Banjo-Kazooie. Achievements are awarded for smashing pots, finding treasure and picking flowers.
Fighting in the game is composed of hopping on the back of a Spirit and attempting to pluck flowers from its back while they put obstacles in your way such as thorns and bombs.

There is currently only partial controller support, with the mouse really only needed for the Spirit fights and closing menus. I'm sure adding a button binding for B to close menus will soon come in an update. I am unsure how Battling the spirits with a controller will work though. Its interaction seems more suited to a mouse or tablet, although the developers have said in the forum they are working on full controller support.

Overall I would highly recommend the game if you grew up playing Nintendo games like Zelda, Banjo or Mario.

While there is no platforming involved, a mixture of all these games can be found in Lili: Child of Geos.
The graphics are just downright gorgeous and full of colour. The music sounds like something that belongs in a Zelda game. It's a casual adventure game with some very basic RPG elements that involve levelling up your Speed, Grip and Stealth.

I haven't played a game like this since the N64.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961494531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1401097271}
review:
Lili: Child of Geos is a collect-a-thon that just exudes charm. I've never had such a fun time collecting flowers and strange garbage from chests in a long time. Just don't go into this expecting Zelda-like combat or something similar to Banjo-Kazooie. You're simply plopped onto a charming little island that can simply be described as something out of a dream.

Here's a Quick Look video to see what the game is like, since it's hard to describe with words. But if that's not your thing, then just read my quick and concise review below.

http://youtu.be/E2t3cuWZZs8

I'll begin by describing the basic mechanics of this game. You play as girl named Lili who is an explorer, and she comes to the island to collect flowers for a report she's doing. You get these special flowers by finding spirits--basically human logs with masks--straddling onto their backs, and plucking white flowers that pop up on their backs until you reach the red one that you need. A fun little mini-game that's somewhat challenging if you're going for the best rank. The other things you'll be doing to progress the story are exploring the village, talking to the inhabitants, and generally exploring for neat things to collect.

But what makes this game so charming? The game's art style is truly breathtaking. It makes the game's main feature of exploring even more enjoyable when there's so many interesting things to see. I even enjoy scaring away birds and laughing at the rainbow turds they leave behind occasionally. Even talking to the local inhabitants is a joy. They have no qualms making fun of themselves and enjoy pointing it out to you. I found it very refreshing to actually WANT to talk to every NPC and find out what their story was. Not many games can pull something like that off.

Other neat features the game has is the ability to chose how you want to upgrade yourself. You can choose to upgrade your speed, grip, or stealth however you wish to suit the playstyle you enjoy. You can also purchase upgrades in a wide range without much restriction. Personally I chose to get a map and key early rather than items to help me fight spirits since I just like exploring more. But if none of that is your thing, you can also just unlock different color swaps for Lili to make her look even more adorable. The choice is yours.

However, this game does come with a few negative.
*I found a game-breaking bug early on. I had collected all of the flowers on the map before hitting up the trainer, who wanted me to collect 5 FRESH flowers. And since none were left, I couldn't progress the game. (I've found out another work-around for this is just quiting and loading your save again. However, I still think it's an issue if you have to do such a strange thing just to continue the game, so I'll leave this as a negative.)
*[strike]Because of the above, I also found out that there isn't multiple save slots. I had to delete my old game if I wanted to start fresh.[/strike]
*There isn't an voice acting besides the occasional "Hi" and what not. While it's not really a big deal for me, I'm sure some people might not like the fact a game with such interesting characters in it aren't voiced. It could've added a lot more to the experience if they found voice actors to bring more life into this already vivid and imaginative game.
*[strike]While you can use a controller to play this game, it hides the fact that you can use it. And unfortunately, you can't even use the controller to play certain parts of the game. Sometimes you have to use the mouse to click off the screen when you collect a new relic. Or when you mount a spirit, you have to switch to the mouse real fast to play the mini-game.[/strike]
*Some people may take issue with the price of the game since it's cheaper on the iOS. However, you're not getting the same experience as you will here, and you can always wait for a sale. But still, I'll list this as a negative just so people know.

But even with those few minor negatives--and I say minor because it was only the beginning of the game where I had to start over--I highly recommend anyone to pick up this game if they want a laid-back adventure with good humor. This game makes me feel like a little boy again. I was just curious about everything, and it's been a long time since any game has done this for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999898359', 'num_games_owned': 1272, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1399697741}
review:
Beware...

I just dropped the full asking price for this game only to then find out its 1/8th of the price on IOS. However, that is not my biggest problem... The game is simply not what you are likely expecting from reading the store page and looking at the videos and screenshots. Like they mention in the store, I was expecting a Zelda like experiance and that is simply not what you have here...

I feel the game is aimed towards 5 - 10 year old children and the mention of "RPG" while accurate by definition it is NOT what I think 95% of you guys out there class as "RPG". 

If you have children and you want to get them a simple game that you can play together then this would be perfect... However, if you are the "typical 13-30" year old bloke... There are likely games much cheaper that would give you more enjoyment. In short... Not the type of game the store page would leave you to believe. Would be great for young children, parents and people that enjoy their point and click/collection games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965467305', 'num_games_owned': 5869, 'num_reviews': 312, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1400411812}
review:
At first I was a bit sceptical due to this originally being an iOS game. As ports go, many developers do not do a high quality end result. But I have been surprised as it has clearly been reworked with higher texture packs, a new UI and more content.

There are 2 things that could do with some work. The mouse control feels laggy and takes some getting used to. The other thing is how often achievement popups occur. It feels far too frequent.

Over all I am enjoying Lili. It reminds me of Legend of Zelda and Banjo Kazooie.

Unsure if it is worth $20 but that is up to you to decide.
